content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												This game is awesome. It features stunning graphics, a perfectly blended score and voice acting far superior to most games I've played in my whole life (really, in my case that means something, gaming since the glorious CBM 64 times!).The game is so well crafted you could easily find yourself lost in playing it for only enjoying the fabulous scenery. In fact it is so damn good the game could easily feature the Disney logo in front and it would be an honour for the company that brought to us so many lovely and memorable movies (and I'm quite sure it would be an honour for the developer to ... ;).There is love and workmansship squeezing out of every detail of the setting and aspect of the game. The only letdown is that it's relatively easy, so don't expect something like a Castlevania or Metroid out of it gameplaywise, but keep in mind that this very game here was made merely by one person only during a period of four years devoting all his developing skills to just this one game. And you don't get to see things like this happen very often these days anymore. For 20 years now I always thought that this is a good sign for quality in games and seeing this game now is the proof that my believe is right.And the gameplay ... omg the gameplay ... To say it in one word it's gorgeos. You can control the game perfectly with whatever input device you throw at it. The player and the enemy animations plus the scrolling are fluid like golden butter in the mildness of a sunny summer's evening driping from a bunch of freshly cutted bread.For my part I even enjoy the story very much. I can't understand the complains of some of the other reviewers. For a game like this it is absolutely fullfilling all of my deeds I have to a decent action platformer with RPG-elements like Dust is. You got the whole pack here: Tragedy, Revenge, Mystery and Suspense. And that's only the main story line. On top of that there are many sidequests offered by various NPCs from within the games different locations. And the NPCs are so well and lovely implemented in the game, with so much heart that has been put into their design you will have no other choice but to help 'em out.For me this game is one of the best games I've played for a few years now. The only concern I have about it is that it has an end, and like with everything as good as Dust it will most likely come too soon ... But what the heck ... at least you've got two more difficulty settings if you played it through on normal. And for the not so pro-players amongst us, there is even a Casual difficulty setting so that really every single player can enjoy this game independently from what their gaming skills might be.If you enjoyed games like Aztaka you should absolutely get this.If you played this game through and want some more you should probably get Aztaka ... :)I got my copy of the game on a discount sale but I'd say it's easily worth even the full price.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19
												Calling this an "Indie Title" feels like a bit of an insult since most indie titles that are highly regarded tend to be lazy 2D pixel art with gameplay that is merely either old 2D Mario or some 2Deep4U minimalism disguising mediocrity and low budgets. Even IF this game was mediocre, the fact that it was entirely made by one person (minus the music and some voice acting) would explain why it was so.But it isn't. Kudos to actual effort on the part of an indie dev.I will say that some of the choices in voice actors were sub-par, and the art style looks like a weird mixture of 90's antromorphic western cartoon characters placed in a typical anime setting, so it comes across as odd. You juxtapose the serious with the Looney Tunes-ish and it comes across just as “Loonatics: Unleashed” did; which is to say it's off putting. But your mileage may vary and you may or may not like it/mind it. I'll leverage that critique by saying that the soundtrack is expertly done and worth a download.With that out of the way, what he have here is a 2D hack and slash with some light (and I mean very light) "Metroid-vania" elements. You have various maps that branch off to different pathways that eventually lead either to a dead end (boss fight, treasure chest, etc) or to the world map screen. You have quests that villagers give you, and these are typically “on the way” so they're easily completed as you're moving the story along, you merely have to explore the maps fully and not go directly to the next objective. When you gain the ability to slide and the ability to climb moss, you can fully explore maps and might want to backtrack a few (emphasis on few) to go up areas you previously couldn't. There's exploration here, but not a TON of backtracking.Unlike Metroid-vania titles, the map isn't one huge map either. Rather, you have a world map screen where you can select the various areas in the game, which keeps all the backtracking and exploration in 'sizable' chunks that are easily done with. It keeps things 'cleaner' and I definitely enjoy it. It's a game about exploring linear maps that branch off but not a lot of back-tracking, so “light Metroid-vania”.The combat is so-so. I don't have any complaints, but I do wish there was more complexity. Since most enemies hit for very little and have very simplistic attacks I can see why your own battle mechanics are simple. Even the bosses are easy to take out (shockingly easy), so there's no need for complexity when everything around you is so simple. Later on you'll most likely just fly over enemies to move to the next map screen, since there's nothing exciting here, albeit nothing is broken and all works as intended. You CAN have a lot of options in combat whilst maintaining the inputs and mechanics simple and basic, so a few points off for that only because games like Muramasa have spoiled me on how good combat can be.I'll also give a critique on the levelling up system: I can't go down a strict attack route and have to have my lowest stat be no more than 4 points behind my highest stat. It's not a HUGE deal but I never put points in vitality in most games, and being forced to is a bit annoying.Overall I'd say the main draw of the game (at least for me) was exploring the maps fully and fulfilling quests. The combat is lacking, but it “gets the job done” and the exploratory nature of the game leaves you something to fall back on and enjoy. The quality on this game is impressive for a team of one, and it ultimately stands on its own as an above average experience in the 2D hack and slash department that carries its own weight. Holding it back a bit is the so-so combat, but otherwise it's an enjoyable experience. If a sequel gets released I'll definitely purchase it...maybe on a slight discount, but I'll be there. Above average: 6 out of 10.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												To be honest, this is one of the best games I've ever played so far.Initially, I was rather skeptical of how this game will appeal to me as I was never a big fan of hack & slash games and the slow and mundane plot in the first few minutes almost confirmed my suspicion. Thankfully, things caught up quickly and soon I found myself lost in the world of Dust.The artworks and soundtracks used in this game are top-notch from the start to the end. I thoroughly enjoyed the aesthetical aspects of the game and I applaud the developers for putting their efforts. The story as a whole was excellent and the characters are among one of the best written ones I've seen. You'd need to play this with a gamepad though as playing on a keyboard may not be ideal in numerous fights and can give a different (or perhaps  a less enoyable) experience as a result. Anyway, there is also a pretty good variety of combat skills to choose from and you will be able to use them in various situations such as searching for treasures or going against different enemies. It's a rather big world out there so do try to explore all parts of the map.The only negative I could think of were the lags during the cutscenes. I've already experienced it twice during my playthrough and I had to reload a save and complete the level/fights again to watch the cutscene once more. Not a potential game-breaker but they can be annoying.In a nutshell, I highly recommend people to try this game out. I got it during the sale so it was definitely worth the money. However, even without any discounts, its price is still rather acceptable for a game of its calibre. An amazing game that will give you a whole lot to think about when you play it.Ashes to ashes, dust to dust!

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014



YouTube™ Video: MOB Review: Dust An Elysian Tail 

			Views: 112		

			Dust An Elysian Tail is a slight RPG, Platformer, action side screen scroller. On Steam here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/236090/ Join us at Twitter or Facebook if that is your thing:...		

Dust, An Elysian Tale is an action platformer in a MetroVania style.  The game follows a character searchingfor clues to his past, as he travelsthrough a country and helps its' citizens.The art style is beautiful and unique,the UI is clean and efficient, the crafting system is balanced, and themerchants scale their gear as one progresses through the story.  The platforming elements in the gameis balanced well and functions as anaddition to the game, as opposed totaking precedence over other aspects.As the player progresses through the game, they face a variety of monsters and atmospheres, keeping gameplay from becoming monotonous.The combat is fluid, and respects theplayers strengths and weaknesses in its' available techniques.  The leveldesign is done in such a way as to givethe player options in how they getfrom point to point without seeminglinear, which adds to the enjoymentand variety of the game. Bottom line, the game is very fair; itsfluidity offers a sense of power to theplayer, and it respects your time. I can easily recommend this game.For more details, see the linked video review, as this is a basicsummary of what I cover in my video.Thanks for your viewership and support for more videos check click here.http://www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

content:
Posted: October 8, 2016
												a simple and beautiful 2D platformer action RPG that you must have. if you love action RPG, don't think again to play Dust: An Elysian Tail, and when you start the game, you can't resist to complete your epic journey on this game.things that make this game fantastic are the art style, all of the sounds from this game, and the story.really, the art style is very unique and beautiful to me. your visual experience with this game is too hard to compare with another game because of it's uniqueness. maybe not all of you will find this kind of art beautiful, but i am sure you will surprise that this kind of art can deliver an action RPG game very beautifully (yeah, all of the action is very beautiful on this game).a great visual and a great sound is a perfect match. can you imagine, a game that feels like very real, it's like you really talking to the person on the game, swing your sword, and the massacres (you will often do this on this game, but still, beautifully).and the story. a great visual and sound, need a good story to complete a well written epic journey. with a visual and sounds like you have in this game, you can't help yourself from falling to the story. 	the story is twisty, a great onethose three, the art style, the sounds and the story, will always accompany you on this game while you enjoy the story. followed with many secret / side missions this game is almost perfect, the leveling and upgrade system is very fun too. but just one thing that less enjoyable from this game, that is the combat which is very repetitive. but it's okay for a beautiful and very cool combat, it's like the combat in Kingdom Hearts (at the very first time i played the combat, it was remind me of KH), repetitive combat still can be fun. you will want more story in the end of the game, but with more combat choice absolutelyoverall this game is one of the best action RPG for me, 9.5/10

content:
Posted: May 27, 2013
												It's a gorgeous, moving, clever, and often funny work of art, AND a very very fun game.  The animation and artwork are fantastic, making you feel like you're playing an animated movie; the (fully voice-acted) dialogue is well-written and tells the story effectively, and the gameplay is a thoroughly explorable Metroidvania-style experience, with a combo-based combat system that allows you to either engage small groups of enemies with parries and suplexes, or sweep across a room, moving from group to group to bombard them with magic and spinning slashes (or both at once).  Gameplay pacing is done well, navigation is done well, all the "little things" are done as well as the "big things."  I'm only about halfway through it, and the only complaint I've had was one particular room filled with spikes that was a pain to escape.  Amazingly, it was mostly done by one person, I can't recommend it enough.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												This game definitely scores a 10/10.Dust: An Elysian Tail kept me playing. I started out using a mouse and keyboard, which worked well, but when I remembered I had a Logitech F310 USB controller lying around, the game really began to shine. The different difficulty levels add a boat load of replay value; a fight you had no issue with on your first playthrough suddenly becomes more daunting on your next playthrough, all because you upped the difficulty this go round. If you want long fights, max out the difficulty. If you're just in it for the storyline, set the difficulty as low as possible and the game does all but walking and jumping for you. Controller support is phenomenal, the levels are beautiful, the storyline is gripping.There was one small issue, and that's the placement of one mission. During this mission, you are tasked to hit a high hit combo, but I noticed that, generally, you've leveled up quite a bit before you even make it this far. This creates an issue where, by the time you get your combo halfway there, you've knocked out all the enemies. Luckily there's an item in game that weakens you, but that seems to be the item's only purpose. As stated previously, it's a small issue, but it does tend to be a nuisance.Despite this, I can only hope for a sequel.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2016
												To me, this is a passion project game born, but made in the wrong time in a way.If it we're made during the Jazz Jackrabbit time, where it was cool to be a furry animal blasting people, without thinking about people dressing up as furry animals and jacking off to the idea, this wouldn't be a thing to even think about, and to enjoy the game for what it is.If you still choose to enjoy the game for what it is, and not think about the stigmata of it being somehow related to anything furry involving rabbits, you will find the result of a one-man project. And, this game is pretty damn good.You play as a fella named Dust, who has amnesia, and you are aided by a weird winged creature that guarded a talking sword that you now own, after it came to you. With that information in mind, you are supposed to figure out what happened to you, and what to do as you go on your journey.The game itself is pretty damn simple and good, and the secrets, although few, are either are well hidden (especially the indie darling group), or require a powerup later on in the game.Overrall, It's a pretty simple exploration game that deserves a playthrough.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2014
												3D will never hold the same place in my heart as 2D, and this might be the most beautiful 2D game I've ever played.  The environments and character animations are absolutely gorgeous, completely immersive.  And beyond that the gameplay is just plain fun!  I'm a complete sucker for the "Metroid-Vania" style of side-scrolling combat with light RPG elements, and "Dust" nails everything that makes that particular school of design so enjoyable for the obsessive-compulsive "must find everything" backtrackers like me.  That having been said, it's not perfect.  The bosses, as have been noted by many others, are a bit lackluster (none quite so much as the final boss); the anime cutscenes can't live up to the beauty of the in-game animations; and, much as I hate to say it, the main story arc didn't quite live up to its full potential.  It's the last one which will probably get the most people up in arms at me, as the story has been near-universally praised from what I can tell.  And don't get me wrong, I'm not saying it's *bad.*  The characterization is fantastic, and all of the little moments with Dust and Fidget in particular are both amusing and, occasionally, touching.  It's just that these little moments, I think, work better than the big ones.  All in all, the highest praise I can give to "Dust" is that it left me wanting more.  I would LOVE to see a sequel.  If this is what Dean Dodrill can accomplish virtually single-handed, I can only imagine what he would produce with a dedicated team.  I absolutely loved this game and know that it is one which I will be revisiting over and over again.  Well done.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												This is a game that knows exactly what it wants to be and delivers it in style. A straightforward, side-scrolling platformer with simple button-mashing combo-style hack n' slash combat, pretty graphics, and a relatively interesting storyline. It's got a very stereotypical anime-esque appearance, but there's beauty in the simplicity of the game. It's extremely well developed, easy to pick up and play, and nicely eyecatching. The animation is wonderfully smooth, with very subtle background effects, and a wide variety of environments to move through as you open up more of the wider map. I tend to think of this game as being a bit simple, but it's a work of art and it's hard to believe that it was entirely the product of one person. It must have been a labour of love, and that effort shows through. Dust is an interesting character and, almost despite myself, I became engrossed in his story and the way in which it unfolded. I was expecting something very basic and repetitive as this is a 2D platformer I bought during the sale, mainly because I'm a sucker for pretty artwork in games. I didn't expect much beyond a couple of hours of simple gameplay and levelling up a few times before polishing off a boss and ending the game all in time for tea. A week later, after running through the game twice (I upped the difficulty level the second time around) and earning all of the achievements, proved me totally wrong. At first I was skeptical; I found the characters to be a little bit twee and stereotypical, but as they and the story line developed I got hooked. It's suitable for all ages so don't expect any gore or adult themes, but there's a certain appeal in the innocence of the game; it's certainly not boring, and there are enough challenges and changes to keep you interested despite the fairly repetitive nature of platform gaming. It may appear cartoonish but there are some serious moral themes discussed and life lessons to be learnt. Picking up new abilities throughout the game gets you returning to previous maps to complete things you couldn't do earlier in the game, which nicely prevents it from being a linear run-through from one level to the next. It's hard to criticise this game because it doesn't promise any more than it delivers. You don't feel short-changed by the simplicity of the game play or the slightly "cutesy" characters. It's easy to play through, which might be disappointing if you're looking for more of a challenge. It is fairly repetitive but the enemies do get tougher as the game develops, matching your character's development. The challenge arenas are the only places where you can really push your skills to try to get that elusive four-star rating. The other downside is the boss fights - it's a button-masher so just keep hitting the combos for long enough and the boss goes down, it's as simple as that. But again, it's hard to criticise because the game delivers exactly what it promises. It's enjoyable but not astonishing. I recommend it as a pleasant and pretty game to play, a nice bit of simple escapism that isn't going to challenge or frustrate you.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2013
												It's a gorgeous, moving, clever, and often funny work of art, AND a very very fun game.  The animation and artwork are fantastic, making you feel like you're playing an animated movie; the (fully voice-acted) dialogue is well-written and tells the story effectively, and the gameplay is a thoroughly explorable Metroidvania-style experience, with a combo-based combat system that allows you to either engage small groups of enemies with parries and suplexes, or sweep across a room, moving from group to group to bombard them with magic and spinning slashes (or both at once).  Gameplay pacing is done well, navigation is done well, all the "little things" are done as well as the "big things."  I'm only about halfway through it, and the only complaint I've had was one particular room filled with spikes that was a pain to escape.  Amazingly, it was mostly done by one person, I can't recommend it enough.

												To me, this is a passion project game born, but made in the wrong time in a way.If it we're made during the Jazz Jackrabbit time, where it was cool to be a furry animal blasting people, without thinking about people dressing up as furry animals and jacking off to the idea, this wouldn't be a thing to even think about, and to enjoy the game for what it is.If you still choose to enjoy the game for what it is, and not think about the stigmata of it being somehow related to anything furry involving rabbits, you will find the result of a one-man project. And, this game is pretty damn good.You play as a fella named Dust, who has amnesia, and you are aided by a weird winged creature that guarded a talking sword that you now own, after it came to you. With that information in mind, you are supposed to figure out what happened to you, and what to do as you go on your journey.The game itself is pretty damn simple and good, and the secrets, although few, are either are well hidden (especially the indie darling group), or require a powerup later on in the game.Overrall, It's a pretty simple exploration game that deserves a playthrough.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												What can I say that hasn't been said about this game? Coming from someone who has yet to play Castlevania or Metroid for that matter, I found this to be an amazing game. The soundtrack and the visuals are outright gorgeous. The story is also a great tale to tell; dark, yet humorous at the same time. Not only that, but the characters are also great, varying in many memorable personalities. I don’t mind the choice of art used, especially as I feel it would change the story too much if it was otherwise. My only problem with the game is that the combat can be a bit repetitive at times, but not too much, thankfully. This is literally why I am going to learn about programming; if one man can create nearly everything aside from the music and voice acting, and turn out something that gets such ratings as it got (9-10/10’s), this paves the way for others to do so too. I completely recommend this, as it serves not only as a great game, but as a pillar for others to follow their dreams as well. Thank you, Dean Dodrill; for everything.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a RPG-Metroidvania where you take control of "Dust", a misterious creature who seems to have lost his memories. Without an aparent reason he will be followed by a flying "batcat" and a talkative mystic sword, who will help Dust and guide him in order to know his purpose in this world, as also as to get his memories back. The game also provides a background of war and its consequences.Graphics: 8.5/10 - This game is absolutely gorgeus. Every visual thing is extremely polished and colourful, as well as an awesome handprint. This game proves that sometimes you just don't need a 3D graphics, triple A game to say "wow, nice graphics". Soundtrack: 8/10 - The soundtrack is also amazing, yet it comes to be quite secundary because of the pace of action the game is exposed to. All tracks goes into an epic/orchestra path and they're all as beautiful as the game looks like. Nevertheless, and as I said, this game is so fluid and fast that the own game's FX sounds overrides the soundtrack, making it hard to appreciate how good it is.Controls: 8.5/10 - As a non-casual player of Metroidvania games, I was pretty satisfied with Dust controls. Movement is fluid and once you learn its mechanics you won't have a problem here. Every mistake I experienced in this game was my own fault and not the game's one. Combos are really cool and they are set to let the players make their own strategies with all different movements. Duration: 7.5/10 - Dust: An Elysian Tail will provide you more than 5-7h of storyline (unless you rush it), and about another 5-7h if you go for the extras, such as new skills, completing sidequests. finding treasure chests, etc. As many Metroidvania games, this game has some RPG features, like character level progression, which can lengthen your experience and gameplay even more (it is always nice to farm your level!). Moreover, the storyline is surprisingly interesting, and might keep you playing without pause until the end. And yes, the whole story is pretty good. Definately not a disappoint.Difficulty: 6.5/10 - This game, compared to my idea of the average difficulty of its similars, is basically "not too hard, but not too easy either". Four difficulties can be chosen from the start and can be changed during your gameplay, and that means that on higher difficulties less HP recovery items will be spread, stronger (yet not faster) enemies, tougher bosses and HP damage, etc. Overall Dust: An Elysian Tail can be played by everyone and shouldn't disappoint either new players or the veteran ones. OVERALL: 8.5/10 - I was kinda hyped when I finally purchased this game and my expectations were dangerously high. However, Dust: An Elysian Tail answered to them VERY well. This game is another demonstration that a small company can make huge things into the gaming industry. I'm really happy I decided to try out this game, it was worthy and I feel this can like you all too because I found it really hard not to enjoy it.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
-Quick Review-Dust: An Elysian Tail is a 2D Side Scrolling action RPG game, which has great voice acting, and a nice quest system that you can play through in a little less than a day.WARNING: Make sure to save, and not trust the Autosave. The game autosaved over my original copy; I had thought that it was my own save that was updating… this was regrettably not the case. Good bye days worth. Please learn from my mistake. -Detailed breakdown review-Story:  Dust: An Elysian Tail starts off very confusing, the story just kind of drops you into the game and says “Hey, you’re the hero, here’s a talking sword and an annoying fairy thing, go save the word!” Now that I think about it, this isn’t really an uncommon trait in video games.I won’t spoil the story, but I like how the main character looks, the game is very Asian-cultured,  you have your annoying side-kick who just makes your character look better, it has all it needs to have to be a good game… The only down side is that the game goes by really fast.Game Play:  The game play starts out very fast paced, I knew before I left the starting zone that I was going to enjoy it. The game is based on gaining exp through “combo’s” which you obtain through getting hits on enemies. You’ll figure out neat ways to go about doing this while you play the game and unlock new abilities.Fidget (The side-kick / flying wombat / fairy-thing) throws magic, Dust uses a Magic sword and you use those two in collaboration in the air or on the ground. That’s what the game comes down to. Knowing when to fight in the air, and how and when to fight on the ground.Achievements: The achievements on this game are fun. I started the game right away on Normal difficulty, got nearly everything then reset my game and descided to replay on tough to get the final few achievements I missed.When I started the game on Normal I was very over confident and thought I could just zip through the game without needing to learn where my heal button is… That didn’t work out so great, so it’s not “easy” but it’s not “Super Meat Boy”. Most of the achievements can be obtained relatively easily once you’re familiar with the game.Price: Dust: An Elysian Tail at normal price is going for $14.99, I would say that the game is priced fairly for the quality you will get. I only put 22 hours into the game, but I did rush a bit and had to look up a guide for the “find all your friends” achievement… The price might still be a bit high for someone with a strained check book.As I say on most of my reviews, you may want to wait for this game to go on sale before you buy it, but it is definitely worth buying. Additionally it is currently in the Humble Bundle for the next eleven days! You might want to jump at the chance to get it now with a few other indie games: https://www.humblebundle.com/ Conclusion: I enjoyed this game, I felt that I got my money’s worth out of it, the story was excellent, the quality was impressive, the game play was fun. I don’t know what else you could ask out of a game like Dust: An Elysian Tail. I say this is a “Must Have” for anyone who enjoys 2D Indie Games.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Итоговая оценка - 4,43/5Более подробный разбор ниже.Когда небо было голубее и трава зеленее, мы играли в классические нынче платформеры. Эта игра перенесла меня туда, и я вспомнил, что меня "цепляло" - всё было интересно и в новизну. Проработанные и красиво нарисованные локации населенные, такой же, проработанной и красивой фауной. И да локации весьма разнообразны: от зелёных лугов с разрушенными остатками былой цивилизации и тёмного подземелья, до заснеженных горных вершин и вулканических земель - всё очень ярко и запоминающееся. По всем канонам платфомеров присутствуют и секретные локации, на которые попасть не всегда просто и очевидно. Если для некоторых просто необходимо пройти дальше по сюжету и получить новую способность (да тут способности будут выдаваться по мере прохождения сюжета, но об этом дальше), то для других нужно воспользоваться как чьими-то записями или же просто интуицией. Когда Вам в последний раз хотелось пройти игру открыв все секреты и локации? Я уже давненько не помню такого. Именно это отпечаталось у меня в голове после полного прохождения данной игры. Ибо автору удалось облегчить поиск секретов ровно на столько, что бы это оставалось интересным, но не вызывало мучений.Боевая система же в игре сделана, по-моему мнению, в угоду возрасту игрока (рейтинг 10+), без наличия рек крови, но вполне интересную на высоких уровнях сложности. Среди обзоров наткнулся на фразу о том, что все бои проходят за одной, изредка двумя кнопками. Странно видеть такие замечания к слешеру, коим по-сути и является этот платформер в боевой части. На самом же деле в игре присутствует парочка комбо, но действительно хотелось бы больше комбинаций т.к. со временем эффектная анимация приедается и становится немного скучно. Скуку помогает разбавить сложность, т.к. протагониста могут положить на лопатки всего несколько ударов, а так же наличие нескольких нетипичных врагов, к которым необходим особый подход.Так же присутствует и РПГ-составляющая: система уровней с прокачкой одной из характеристик, которых 4 (на самом деле их 5, но прокачивать можно только 4) и которые не могут разниться между собой не более чем на 4 очка; а также система экипировки персонажа артефактами которые влияют на все 5 характеристик и еще несколько игровых моментов.Как платформер игра не так хардкорна, как тот же Mario, Darkwing Duck, но на некоторых местах заставляет изрядно понервничать и сжать контроллер покрепче. Да я сказал контроллер, игра пришла к нам на ПК-платформу прямиком с Xbox360 и изначально была "заточена" под геймпад и в процессе игры ни разу не хотелось пересесть за клавиатуру. Ну да ладно, вернемся к самой игре. Чтобы собрать все секреты необходимо открыть все способности протагониста, поэтому придется возвращаться вновь на локации. Кстати, после зачистки локации, враги появляются вновь стоит только выйти за её границу. Это сложно отнести к явным недостаткам, но создает некоторое неудобство, которое по мере прокачки протагониста будет всё меньше и меньше.И наконец сюжет. Он имеет как излишнюю пафосность и какой-то детской наигранностью, так интригующую составляющую (сюжет не по книге/фильму/игре, а свой собственный, хотя и имеет в себе парочку-другую штампов) и юмор, который действительно способен вызвать улыбку. Но всё же он сделан , по моему мнению, опять же в угоду возраста игрока.P.S. Игра проходится за 8-12 часов. Я же столько наиграл банально из-за низкого уровня знания английского - что заставляло меня перманентно держать в оверлее гугл-переводчик (хотелось просто подтянуть уровень английского, а происходящее было вполне интересено, чтобы не отбивать желания понимать происходящее).P.P.S. Кстати интересный факт, что над игрой работал по-большей части один человек около трёх с половиной лет. Я думаю это и помогло стать игре такой какой она задумывалась...

content:
Posted: March 20, 2016
												A short, beautiful game that tells an unexpectedly satisfying, meaningful story. As a platforming beat-em-up, it's not particularly difficult or complex, but the strong vocal performances propel the game forward in an immersive, compelling way. Upgrades and new abilities are well-paced throughout, allowing you to choose whether you'd like to keep pushing forward, or backtrack for hidden treasures. I will separately note that the musical score is also extremely strong, with Hyperduck providing BGM that is memorable and very much a pleasure to listen to.With so many games featuring a laundry-list of tacked-on features or grindy content filler, it is refreshing to play an exploration game that gets to the point by focusing on its core competencies, and does them well. This game was recommended to me, and I now recommend it to you.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												First of all, it is mind blowing how smooth this game plays. It has the feel of a professionally made game by a well known team. If you enjoy action rpg in somewhat of the style of "Metroidvania" Castlevania game, then this game is for you. If you act now(at the time that I'm typing this), you can get the game for only 3 dollars. It is a steal for how well made this game is. Plenty of action, material to collect to make new items, quests to do for npcs, etc.The only issue I've had so far was the game crashing on me upon going to the world map to chose a new area to go to. It doesn't always happen. I suspect it will be resolved at some point, and it isn't too gamebreaking, as long as you save often. I am thorough pleased with my purchase of this game, and I highly recommend it to anyone else that enjoys these type of games.Edit: It should be noted that the crashes on world map only happened the first two times I tried to go on it. It has been fine after that, So it was probably just my comp, since I was on it for a while.Edit2: Having finished the game, I may have some minor nitpicks, but nothing major. Mostly the artwork in the final scenes looked odd with the eyebrows and eyes going through the hair. It makes it look out of place, compared to how professional everything else looked. Other than that, this game has been really solid all the way through. Touching story, and leaving the door open for a sequel. I've had a blast, and I still gotta play this game through again on a harder setting at some point and finish up what is left of the achievements. I probably would have paid the original price. But hey, this is on steam, so 3 dollars was really nice for the amount of fun I've had with this game.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2014
												Dust has truly captivated me. Not only the character but the game as a whole. Dust as a character is a young man struggling with his past, present and future. He wakes up not being able to remember who he is or how he got there, thus starting a journey in the search of those lost memories. Sounds quite cliche, but it has been fabulously executed, exceeding my story-related expectatives.Dust as a game is impressive. The story is simple but deep, everything you do and everyone you meet have something to do in this game, the backgrounds and BGM are breathtaking and the gameplay is intuitive and absolutely great. Even the english dubbing has been properly done. The various side quests it includes (Cirelian Trials, secondary missions, finding treasures and friend cages, finding materials for building your own equipment, etc) add up to the game experience.A must-play game. Give it a try and you'll be fascinated by the beauty it holds.

Posted: July 25, 2014
												After I saw the trailer for this game I was really excited to play it, so much so my boyfriend bought it for me in an attempt to get me playing more PC games. Although at first I thought maybe it was a little too childish for my age, I quickly forgot that! Dust creates an exciting world that completely immerses the player and pulls them along. I found this game was hard to put down and from discussing it with others I found they also had the same experience. It might seem like a more Kid-friendly game, which is how one friend initially described it to me, but I find it appeals to a large audience of all ages.  I loved the story line and the art style and music. Perhapse I might sound too biased towards the positives of this game and not really elaborate on flaws, but as I said before this game is addicting and I don't think there are any major flaws that would really turn a person off from this game. I find myself going out of my way to complete every little aspect to perfection just so I can get more playing time cause I'll be sad when its finally done. =) I really love this game and if you're hesitant to buy I hope this review helps.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												First of all, it is mind blowing how smooth this game plays. It has the feel of a professionally made game by a well known team. If you enjoy action rpg in somewhat of the style of "Metroidvania" Castlevania game, then this game is for you. If you act now(at the time that I'm typing this), you can get the game for only 3 dollars. It is a steal for how well made this game is. Plenty of action, material to collect to make new items, quests to do for npcs, etc.The only issue I've had so far was the game crashing on me upon going to the world map to chose a new area to go to. It doesn't always happen. I suspect it will be resolved at some point, and it isn't too gamebreaking, as long as you save often. I am thorough pleased with my purchase of this game, and I highly recommend it to anyone else that enjoys these type of games.Edit: It should be noted that the crashes on world map only happened the first two times I tried to go on it. It has been fine after that, So it was probably just my comp, since I was on it for a while.Edit2: Having finished the game, I may have some minor nitpicks, but nothing major. Mostly the artwork in the final scenes looked odd with the eyebrows and eyes going through the hair. It makes it look out of place, compared to how professional everything else looked. Other than that, this game has been really solid all the way through. Touching story, and leaving the door open for a sequel. I've had a blast, and I still gotta play this game through again on a harder setting at some point and finish up what is left of the achievements. I probably would have paid the original price. But hey, this is on steam, so 3 dollars was really nice for the amount of fun I've had with this game.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a game that by this point in time really shouldn't need any introduction. The game has won multiple rewards, received much praise, and delighted many gamers, but how well does it hold up to all that hype?In my opinion, very well, Admittedly the game does have its flaws, but when you stop to think about the fact that the vast majority of the game was made by one man, said flaws become much more forgivable. That said, the only note-worthy flaw with Dust: An Elysian Tail is the story, as it is rather generic. That's not to say that it's bad, but it's certainly nothing that you haven't heard before. However, that doesn't prevent Dust: An Elysian Tail from being a highly entertaining gaming experience. While the story may not be all that fresh, it does still manage to be entertaining, thanks mostly to Fidget, who will be your faithful companion throughout the game. You may have heard certain folks compare Fidget to Navi from The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, but I have no idea where they're drawing that comparison from. Fidget isn't some annoying creature with no purpose but to point out the painfully obvious and pester you every 5 minutes by reminding you of what you should be doing to advance the plot, but a fully realized and fleshed-out character with lots of humorous dialog. Without Fidget, Dust: An Elysian Tail would be far less entertaining in the story department, but thanks to her and her dialog/commentary, Dust's story becomes far more interesting.Gameplay-wise, Dust: An Elysian Tail is more or less your standard "Metroidvania" fare, with side-scrolling action, lots of areas to explore, platforming, you know the drill. However, Dust: An Elysian Tail also has RPG elements, such as stats, a Level Up System, Magic, loot, crafting, and items that will increase your stats. Granted that Castlevania: Symphony of the Night also had RPG elements, but Dust's feel a bit deeper than that, more in line with games like Muramasa: The Demon Blade than SotN, albeit the combat isn't quite as deep as Muramasa.Graphics-wise, Dust: An Elysian Tail is beautiful game. All of the visuals were hand-drawn by Dean Dodril (the game's creator) himself, and they're gorgeous. However, words alone can't do it justice at all, so take a peek at the Screenshots and see for yourself.Sound-wise, Dust: An Elysian Tail is beautiful as well. Hyperduck Studios did an excellent job on this game's soundtrack, and they really deserve more recognition for their work. Every bit of music in this game hits its mark, perfectly reflecting what's going on in the game around it.There's really not much more that I can tell you about the game, it's really something that you'll have to experience yourself. At $14.99, the game is well worth it, and I'm sure that you won't regret it.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												     So my Good friend Taylor told me about this game.  My first impression was that it looked too cartoony and childish for me, then I saw the trailer.  My curiousity peaked at that point.  Taylor bought me the game and I started to play it and here I am telling people to get it.  But some people out there ask why I believe you should.       Dust: An Elysian Tail is about a man named Dust who wakes up in the middle of the woods with no prior memory, a magic sword, and a cute sidekick named fidget.  His memory restores throughout the story.  The story has a common foundation but with an amazing twist.  I do not want to spoil any of the AMAZING story so the topic will end here.       The Gameplay and art style was unique.  Dust is an action-RPG hacky-slashy game where the premise is simple, bonk the bad guys with the sword and they die.  That's atleast what I thought it would be until you unlock the "K" move.  The game then becomes the most pleasureable display of explosions and lights I have seen since beat hazard.  The amount of hits you can get in a single fight will make your jaw drop.  The enemies dont scale as well as they try.  They see to go from easy, to semi easy, and then straight to down right annoying!     Verdict:  I Strongly suggest anyone pick up this game.  If you love explosions, a beautiful artstyle, anime, and a one of a kind story.  BUY THIS GAME AT ONCE.  9.5/10                                                                                                                                                   -Amerika

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
												So after 2 and a half years of development, we'd finally get this game: Dust: An Elysian tail.And please tell me if you get the gabe newell reference, but this game was worth the wait in every way.Throughout the game, i'd search for plotholes and flawed gameplay mechanics, and needsly to say, i couldn't find any.Dust's controls are the opposite of stiff. The game is really responsive to controls, and it leads to some fun platforming and fast-paced gameplay. And while this game does have a rush bros disease of slow walking and fast rolling, I had an easy time ignoring it to the game's combat.Not only are you given a however small variety of attacks to dish out pain with, there's loads of combos that you can test yourself to execute and memorize with your keyboard, and you get rewarded for each combo. Not only do you get extra experience, you also get achivements, and your enemies of course die faster. While that does sum it up, this game also has its way of disapointment. At the beginning of the game, you're given the blade of Ahrah, Fidget, And dus'ts glorious control to utilize and THATS. IT.Later in the game, you're informed ahrah is only ONE of the blades of elysium; Why couldnt we find and use the others? I wouldve liked more variety than just being stuck with 2 weapons to use. Fidget got more than one mode of attacking, why cant we?Gameplay aside, the graphics, which are hand drawn by the way look GLORIOUS. They dont cause any eyestrain and there isnt a spam of color palette like rush bros had. The game is really pretty to look at and i hope you buy it for that reason.Now, lets go to the plot. In the beginning you see an unknown warrior charging through a variety of people for an unknown reason, and later find out he's killed by a child. In the next scene, you see our main character, dust, kneeling in the middle of an unknown forest. This is the game's first point of♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥you off. You know why? THERES NO REAL CUTSCENES UNTIL NEAR THE END OF THE GAME. Otherwise, all you get is pictures that might as well mimic a slideshow along with text, it really made me depressed toward how such good artwork was put to waste. Anyway, we're introduced to our 3 protagonists, dust, fidget, and the blade of ahrah, which as i said earlier is the main weapon you'll be using throughout the game. We then see that dust has forgotten his past and that he summoned ahrah for yet another unknown reason. Dust doesnt even know why he did it, but he chooses to ignore it and go on a quest to find out more of his past, kill a bunch of racist knights, and simply bring justice where justice is needed with the help of fidget and the blade of ahrah. This is why i like indie games like this, they keep the plot simple and fast to keep the player wanting to play their game. You might call it lazy, but it works. So after all that said, I do like this game for a variety of reasons, (One i'd rather not say) And also, I think that this game has perfect potential and setup for a sequel. If there were a game called Dust 2 (No pun intended), I really hope they'd keep what made this game good and add onto it.

content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
- A lovely platformer with beautiful art style, visual pleasing but a tad repetitive combat at times and a main plot that will keep you interested till the end.Review score: Recommended Game⇓ Personal Review ⇓StoryYou play as Dust, a warrior who got woken up in a forest by a magical blade named Ahrah and its guardian Fidget who from there on are your companions throughout the rest of the story. In short; Dust must work towards retrieving his/its memory in order to bring Justice to a land terrorised by monsters, war and other events you'll encounter. In the beginning and mid game the story was not really something to write home about BUT it was interesting enough for me to keep playing the main plot line and it got more interesting as I progressed towards the end. I can't comment on side missions, didn't play them.GraphicsEach area has it's own unique environment and beautiful art style with accompanying enemy mobs. None of them are in my opinion dull or generic. Aside from the beautiful 2d graphics the combat graphical effects are pleasant to watch at and fit right in.GameplayCombat itself was interesting for me due to the variety of enemies encountered. There are enough guides to explain the easy to remember combos for you to use. There could have been a bit more complexity on that part but that gets balanced by the enemy's difficulty as you progress through the game. In the beginning and mid game most of them are easy to beat (depending on difficulty mode) but towartds late game I died a lot =).Aside from enemies there are some environmental dangers to be dealt with in certain areas, each specific to the level you're playing in. They're not super unique but it does give more depth to the gameplay.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												This game is both figuratively and literally a work of art. The beautiful music, painstakingly detailed environments, and passionate voice acting blew me away. Then Fidget and all 304% of her adorable-osity sealed the deal. At first the story didn't really spark much interest--being the typical "all powerful mysterious warrior with amnesia traversing the land helping it's people while trying to regain his dark and mysterious memory"-- but as it went on it started to pull me in. It's best described as a cross between Okami and Rayman Origins with a little bit of Kingdom Hearts sprinkled on top. (Pros and cons below.)Pros:-Beautifully orchestrated music-Painfully detailed environments and weather effects-Very touching and emotionally impacting. Feelings of pain, sorrow, love--concepts of life and death are handled maturely like they should be and conveyed to the player-Excellent, passionate voice acting-Exciting and tense momentsNeutral:-The humor is 50-50. There are some funny jokes. There are some dry jokes.-Storyline may or may not provide the player with much interest.-The difficulty fluxuates. Some areas are very easy, some areas suddenly♥♥♥♥♥♥you.Cons:-A bit on the short side-Typical hack'n slash with redundant combat-VERY few combos to use; especially for a hack n'slash-Hordes of respawning enemies can be a bit overwhelming and annoying at times-Boss battles are complete jokes. Normal enemies are more life threatening than the bosses-Practically no replay valueConclusion:-6.5/10. While the gameplay and hack'n slash elements are regretably limited, this game is a work of art. It's a 2D game that has infinitely more heart and soul put into it than most overrated 3D Micheal Bay games out today. It is TRULY a work of art and deserves as much support and recognition as it can get for its BEAUTY instead of gameplay which unfortunately is below par. Of course artistry isn't for everyone. This game is not for everyone. But that doesn't stop it from being truly beautiful.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I had some good fun with this indie game. A large majority – perhaps all of my enjoyment – comes from its fun combat system. Chaining together extremely large combos is very rewarding. I also admire the fact that *one* person did all the programming and art, that’s extremely rare. You go, Dev! That said, I played at least half-way through the game, and don’t care at all for the story. So, if you’re looking for good combat, I would recommend this game…but if you’re looking for an engaging story (or any at all), I can’t recommend this game.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												I don't want to finish this game.I just want to lay down on the grass, and bask in the sunlight by a lake.  I want to make a home in the village, join the people in their way of life. I don't want to fight anymore.  I don't need to figure out who I am.  I'm happy with just being Dust.  But it can never be like this.  I know that if I don't keep fighting, there won't be anyone left.  And that's the hard part.  It's a choice between me or the humble people of these lands, and the answer is obvious.I hope they'll remember me.Goodbye, Dust.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Note - I originally played this game through when it debuted on the Xbox Live Arcade and only recently had a Steam copy gifted to me.In short, Dust: An Elysian Tail is the best 2D platformer/brawler story-driven experience I've ever had. Period.Gameplay-wise, this game is very easy to pick up and takes a lot of focus to master.  Granted it's generally possible to breeze your way through the game by maxing Fidget's magic first, the melee combos and building chains is great fun.This game is also aesthetically pleasing to the maximum, I couldn't fault someone for thinking this was a professionally animated movie (maybe because it almost was) for the beautiful character and environment design.Throughout the story things evolve from very tongue-in-cheek tropes to the very serious and emotional later stages.  All along the way humor is balanced with serious moments perfectly.As far as I'm aware Dust is largely bug free, and the options menu is something to take the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of even modern AAA titles.Seriously, if you haven't already get your hands on this game.  It's cute, fun, sad and well worth the price even now.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Even though I am not much into furries, this is now one of my favourite games. And explaining why seems to be the most difficult thing I've ever written.Let's start simple, the music is pretty damn gorgeous! There are only a few games that fit flwalessly to the game and are really enjoyable to listen independetly as well. None of the tracks gets annoying over time and they support the game flow from start to finish.The story is well-written, and even though I normally prefer darker and more brutal atmosphere in my games, having a fairy taler occasionally can feel refreshing. And this one really does! The two main characters are really fun to take through the solid yet somewhat simplistic main story, their interactions with each other never fail to characterize them both and their bond. Some of the supporting characters are not so strong, though, but it didn't really bother me.But the real meat here is the fighting system and especially the controls. I've never played a game with as tight control set as Dust. If you die, it's your own fault for making a balant mistake. You really feel like you are in control at any time. The system itself is really simple, yet it never got boring in my first playthrough. Every fight was thoroughly satisfying and the platforming, while I usually hate it, felt natural and fun to play.The only bad thing I can say is the difficulty level, which is too easy for me. And the fact that after completing this game, other games feel dull and colourless... =DDust is easily the best game I've played for quite a while. If there is any chance you'd enjoy a good metroidvania platformer, give this one a try. I give it my biggest recommendations!

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Phenomenal. This game was an absolute blast to play through, especially for a genre I generally don't enjoy (this being the Beat-Em-Up aspect of the game, not the Metroidvania aspect of it). The world is highly open and fun to explore, with absolutely incredible atmosphere and a slightly cliché though very well polished story. The music as a whole is solid, though admittedly I only really found myself truly attached to a few songs in the game. It fits the world though, and it knows when to pick up and when to slow down. The characters are pretty enjoyable, each of which having their own unique qwerks and characterization to make each individual character in the game so compelling. It helps that the voice acting is honestly pretty good. The anthropomorphic-animal-type character design is offputting at first, but it really didn't detract from anything.All of this is topped off by one of the most fluid, reactive, and satisfying combat engines I think I've ever played. Combos are given to you relatively early so you have plenty of time to practice using them, and I'd be lying if I didn't say I haven't sent chills down my spine for some of the absolutely insane stuff I've been able to pull of. Despite having one weapon (two if you count his companion Fidget), Dust has a huge variety of ways to handle pretty much every enemy in the game, and very rarely does mowing down hordes of minions ever get stale. The artstyle helps ludicrously in this department, making each hit feel rewarding and managing to maintain a long-lasting combo stupidly satisfying. This game has its share of Action RPG elements in it as well, with stuff like shops, level ups, and various equipment options to choose from as the game expands.All of this made the game such an absolute thrill to play, and if you can manage to snag it for the deal I got it at (Three and a half dollars!? What!?), there's no question as to whether you buy this game or not. This game is nearly flawless.Oh, and pretty much all of this game was made by one person - Dean Dodrill. Incredible.

												It's just a beautiful ARPG that is a mix between Metroid and Muramasa.The sound and musik is wonderful, the game runs really smooth and the gameplay is fantastic. 												Dust: An Elysian Tail has the soul of PSX/PS2 living within it, the entire time I played I was feeling very nostligic and happy, reminded me of all the great 2D hack/slash RPG games from back in the day, "Castlevania: Symphony of the Night" "Valkyrie Profile" and "Odin Sphere" spring to mind.The smooth animation and beautiful backdrops are very pleasing to the eye, loads of special effects and carnage litter your entire screen with the screams of the 1000's you slaughter from start to finish, Sound design is very good overall, voice acting was a little weak in some areas, great in others, the games soundtrack is very solid as well, every tune fit each occasion and was wonderfully executed.Lots of sidequests, a dozen "friends" to be rescued, loads of treasure, a decent amount of magic spells and equipment with plenty of upgrades to keep you busy, fight after fight the game kept a great pace, enemies never felt too overwhealming nor did they feel to easy, overall I had a blast playing this game, even tho it's not perfect, it's well worth the purchase and I'll be looking forward to any sequels in the future.8/10

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2013
												Dust is a 2D action-exploration game in the famed 'Metroidvania' style, with some pretty cool elements to it. It actually reminds me a lot of "Muramasa: The Demon Blade" (if you've ever played or heard of that). As with Muramasa, the first thing you will notice are the stunning hand-drawn visuals and animation. The look of the characters and backgrounds during gameplay are quite beautiful. Additionally, the characters all have detailed animated portraits that appear on-screen during conversations. It just looks fantastic all around. The characters themselves are all pretty good, assuming you can stomach a cast full of anthropomorphic animals (and a seriously cutesy flying bunny-type-thing sidekick). The voice acting and plot are generally good as well. Gameplay consists of 2D sword combat with light platforming elements. The combat also has a few cool twists - your sidekick has projectile attacks that can be combined with a special sword technique, resulting in some spectacular combos and on-screen fireworks. It all looks and feels really cool once you get the hang of it. Eventually you will become just  ridiculously powerful, making the game very easy, but it's still good fun. As with similar games, you progress through various areas that unlock as you gain additional abilities. There's also a ton of extra stuff to do (such as side-quests), if you are into 100%-ing games or completing achievements. If you are a fan of this type of game, this one is well worth your time. Highly recommended. A-Technical notes: I highly recommend using an Xbox360 controller for this one. Although I haven't actually tried the keyboard controls, I just can't imagine them working well enough to easily pull off the actions required by the game. Plus, these types of games just control better with gamepads anyways. Anyways, just be aware of this... you've officially been warned.

number of helpful: 11 of 19 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is an action adventure side scrolling game that has strong story element. If you're looking for the game as such with fair pricing then this is a good one for you.Playing the game from the start to finish is truly a rewarding experience. The story writer knew how to make an engaging background history, to implementing the plot through the game progression (and of course having full voice cast and interesting character developments). And I gotta say, the voice actors did make a wonderful job. They could show that a voice can deliver strong emotion throughout the game. Moreover, the ending truly was well written, and a strong point to playing Dust: AET until the finish.Graphic is is is,.... bad... for furry chars and cartoon haters. Ha. Well no, I'm kidding, the graphic is an incredible touch. I love how they designed the levels and the characters. Dust is cool and tough, Fidget is irritating when she starts to whine but she's especially endearing to see. The animation overall and the level designs are flat out gorgeous, full with lightnings in battle and vibrant colors. Gameplay, though, is a bit too easy and repetitive. Being an 'easy' side scroller platformer, you literally can overwhelm enemies with Fidget + Arrah's combos and that's all you need to win thru the levels. That's with the hardest difficulty btw. Bosses can be a bit tough, but unlike we have seen on other platformers. Once you know how to block and spam the combos, the game's piece of cake. A bit skill is required when playing the challenges - but it's a sidequest anyway.Other Side Quests, sadly, don't offer much added value. There are maybe 20 or so, but none of them are memorable for me. Mainly just give you some small rewards and a joy knowing you've completed what the game has to offer.There's a small RPG element - mainly you can level up Dust (and get him extra HP/stats) and equip armors on him. Blade is not replaceable - you can only arm Arrah, the rest is replaceable. Not much I can say, it's kinda shallow mechanic as there's not enough varieties on armors to make it interesting. Just equip the best ones and you're set.As always, playing with xinput based controller for all Microsoft-related games is recommended. The button mappings feel natural, so there's no need to mess around.Game length is a bit short for my preference - only about 10-15 hours even for completionist. Being short, and of course the major lacking point is replayability. My recommendation would be to pick this game up. Can't go wrong playing Dust - it's one of great indie games that everyone must play.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												After just one playthrough, Dust: An Elysian Tail proves to be an absolutely beautiful game with a very satisfying combat system. The amount of destruction you can do by the end of the game is mind-blowing. It's basically an action RPG with the elements of a Metroidvania and it works extremly well. The game is also very user-friendly in terms of sidequests and treasure hunting, making a complete run of the game really fun. I still have a few treasures left to find, but I'm very close. The story is great, the soundtrack is great, and the characters are great. Although, I will say that some cutscenes do go on for a long time. You can skip them, but for anyone who enjoys a good story, there's a ton of dialogue in this game, despite the game being fairly short for an RPG. So, be prepared for that. If I had to say one negative about the game, it's the fact that at times, when there are a ton of enemies and attacks on screen, it's hard to keep track of where you are. This isn't a dealbreaker, but I did die a few times due to now knowing where I was. Overall, if you're looking for a very solid RPG with beautiful art, an engaging story and cathartic combat, look no further than Dust.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												10/10I have played this games for hours upon hours now. The graphics, for being such a simple game, are very, very well done. The characters are fun, creative, and delightfully comedic. There is also quite a bit of story to the game.The puzzles are not the most difficult, but they are fun. The game gets progressively more challenging as time goes on, but it is still not difficult to play. So anyone that plays will have a good chance to learn the game while it is still simple enough to play.I love the story, I love the characters, and most of all I love Fidget.(Edit 1/2)As of now, I've completed both Tough and Hardcore mode of the game. I'm deathly in love with the story, and more so with the ending. The challenge in Hardcore is NOT to be underestimated and it is seriously something that demands the utmost effort. The mastery trinkets at the end (the x2 Attack and x2 Defense) I would recommend the Wisdom pendant (x2 Defense) for the sake of surviving against Gaius in Hardcore mode.  Hardcore genuinely presents the most challenge I've had with a game in years.I've put in a total of about 40 hours into this game. There isn't, I confess, much replay value unless you're a challenge ♥♥♥♥♥ and you just really enjoy burning your way through a game on the hardest difficulty. The Lightning attack is probably a bit overpowered, even in Hardcore because of how easy it is to distance-target enemies and just hide on ledges that they can't reach you on when you link it with DUST STORM.All in all, this is my favorite game of 2015. Absolute, hands down. I highly recommend this game. I've played "big name release" titles like DMC that present fewer hours of play time than this.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												After reading some positive reviews for this game, I decided to pick it up during the Steam Winter Sale and I am glad I did! The core of this game is the fighting and the fighting is great. You will be flying around the maps (literally) swinging your sword hitting enemies. It looks awesome, feels awesome, and is just awesome in every other category. The game also gives you several combos that each have their uses. Your companion, Fidget, also gets a few kool spells that can combo with your sword swinging. To be fair, let's throw in a downside. Fidget's damage is so minute compared to Dust's damage until the very end of the game where items give crazy bonuses to her damage. I really just used her spells for style (and it does stagger enemies for a little bit so that's always helpful). This game also looks beautiful and has great music. However, we need to address the graphics style. The characters are all anthropomorphic animals (I wanna say they most resemble a cross between a dog and a fox?) in an anime style which may turn some people off. Back to the music part, I would look forward to completing an area just to listen to the World Map music.The game has a wide variety of settings to customize to your personal preferences and your computer specs. There were a few moments (mostly towards the end) where my frame rate took a hit but with the amount of particle effects and action going on, it was understandable and it didn't last long. The controls are solid and can be played with a keyboard/mouse or a controller. The game even allows you to switch your input method on the fly and which adjust tooltips accordingly so. Now for a quick lists of things I did not like. - Fidget's damage is lackluster until the latter parts of the game.- You will almost never be at full health. I played on the Tough difficulty and was always around ~25% health the whole game.- Some monsters deal absurd damage (one particular enemy will just snipe you with it's tentacle and pretty much insta-kill you). No matter how much health or defense I had, enemies just seemed to kill me in just 1 or 2 hits.- There are some exploding enemies which resemble Bombs from Final Fantasy which are just annoying.- The healing system is questionable. You have a hotkey for healing items (food) which instantly refill your health. You can spam this button as long as you have enough food to eat. It makes the game very easy if you have ready to eat.- Last one, I promise. In some parts of the game, the camera just seems way too close to Dust. I wouldn't mind it if the camera just moved back a little bit so I can where I am going.(Please note that although these are things I see as problems with the game, the pros FAR outweigh these cons. These issues will rarely take away from the game.)

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												10/10 Imo and I'm gonna tell you why.(I especially think it's worth a buy as it holds as much if not morecontent of most $60 single player games)-Graphics-I seen one minor glitch but it didn't hinder gameplay and it only happened once.Elsewise absolutely clean game.So textures vanishing,blur effect spazzing,endless screenshaking glitches.None.Everything blended beautifully and the cutscenes were no different.-Character and development-As much as I'd like to say story,anything that I say can be held as a spoiler relating to story considering you start off completely blind to the ways of this world.But the characters my goodness the development is fantastic.I've never seen such consistant realism in character personality and development in those who change as the story goes.The developer nailed it from amazing voice action,to perfect emotion in every line!Alot of people don't like Fidget but personally she's a favorite.She's only annoying if you don't like comedy reliefs going off things inside the game.Dust,the main character develops dramatically in his own away along side afew characters as you go through.Even Fidget.If you want great characters and story theres a setting in the game for players just playing for the view and...well story.There aren't alot of NPC but there are plenty enough to have their own voice actors,motives and cares.Has a actual "Village" feel to opposed to your average "run to town to shop and leave."-Combat-Fluent,smooth,extremely responsive.So responsive I went back to afew other games and almost thought I was lagging.On higher difficulties than normal combat is brutal,relentlessly pressuring and even fustrating at some parts because your first move can easily be your last.It doesn't feel like your fighting trashmobs you just run through.Feels more like most these enemies are boss minions.Unless you grind or over powerthem,it's gonna be a nice run for your money.The game does lack a solid defense when can be handled with parry system (holding your light attack to force a clash) or by jump cancelling/dodging.This is beginning stuff so no spoilers ;P It's harsh but it brings out the challenge later game.-Leveling system is fairly simple.you level up and you choose between Fidget,Defence,HP and attack.Matters alot in the beginning because it will define how you fight thingss.Which is great for diversity!It's simple,much like the gear.So you'll spend more time clashing than having your eyes glued to pause menu or wik looking for gear to farm.-Bosses-I know how people feel about it so I'm not gonna name.But...I would normally take a point off for this...yet I'll keep it legit.All but afew bosses felt very easy...like incomplete.Maybe it was my position that trigger a ai to spam 1 move.But I've only died against about 2 bosses.1 of which was my own fualt for being so hasty xD.Maybe I got bad ai that run.But the ones I struggled against was epic.Gotta see it for yourself though,no spoilers :P-Replay Value-In my opinion I say this game has medium/high replay value.Based off how seriously you play this at first.I cleared this 100%.I may someback and do it on the hardest difficulty another day.In the end this game comes out 10/10.It knew what it wanted to be and it was that.It plays great,story is awesome,your promised to lose track of time playing this game with headset on.It's graphics are fantastic and even I have to admit.This is nothing in this game that really complain about except 1 boss...not a spoiler but the boss is artifically difficult on a bull scale.But I dout that'll kill the fun of this chaotic game.I hope the developer does another.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a game to which I have no bad words to say. It is a 2D hack-n-slash action RPG in which you play as Dust, a somewhat confused warrior with no memory of his past, as he journeys through the land of Falana in search of his identity. The story is well-written, moving, intriguing and exciting right to the end.The combat in Dust is simple but effective, with a depth to it that keeps it from ever growing stale. The enemies, too, are delightfully varied, with many requiring different techniques if you want to fight them effectively.The game is populated by many memorable characters, and all of them have their own superb voice actors and unique personalities. Some of them can seem two-dimensional, yet they are all believable characters, helping to make the vibrant world come to life. Most notable is your constant companion, Fidget - a cute, lovable and entertaining little creature who never annoys and is amazingly helpful, especially towards the end of the game.But what really stands out about Dust is the beautiful environment. Each area has its own aesthetic, perfectly realised by the scenery and complemented by an excellent soundtrack. Moreover, you are encouraged to explore this world, with over twenty side-quests, XP bonuses just for talking to new people and dozens of little secrets littered around the world, some of which are very interesting in their own right.If I had to make one criticism, it would be that the blacksmith is not as useful as she perhaps should be, since her fee for crafting an item is the same as you would get for selling it. However, this is a small complaint, and not one moment of gameplay is a disappointment. I count Dust among the best games I have ever played.
