content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
												An absolutely beautiful game with fluid animations and solid brawler mechanics.While there is very little in the way of weapon variety, you're still provided with a range of options for taking out enemies from your basic brawler combos to parrying and aerial throws, all of which are animated gorgeously. Despite being limited to one weapon, you do earn additional magic powers and movement skills, such as double jumps and wall clinging, as the game goes on, which help open up new areas to explore places you couldn't before.The majority of the skills you learn in the tutorial will be your bread and butter through a majority of the game. Thankfully, enemies later in the game do test everything you've learnt, so relying on a single tactic won't do you many favours, with some being only vulnerable to parries and others to magic attacks.Combined, the combat looks and feels great and doesn't outstay it's welcome for the 9 to 12 hours it takes to beat the game.The game also borrows a lot from RPGs with a level up system, side quests and a crafting mechanic, allowing you to build upgrades from blueprints dropped by enemies and found in chests. The upgrades usually add an additive or multiplicative effect to stats, item drops or health regeneration, which doesn't occur naturally otherwise.The entire game is fully voiced, which is an impressive feat for an indie title of this size. There are points where the dialogue feels forced, which can be chalked down to a problem with the script at points, but the main cast do a pretty spectacular job with their characters and help compliment the animation work nicely.If you have any experience with videogames in the past at all, I'd highly recommend playing the game on the Tough difficulty setting, as the Normal difficulty is far too forgiving. The Tough difficulty gives you a good reason to buy and use consumables without piling things on enough to make you ever feel overwhelmed.Mentioning the game is programmed and animated by one person is a moot point, but one that's bound to be brought up if you read up on the game on other sites or reviews. The game easily oozes enough quality and polish that, outside some late game cutscenes, you'd never realise or believe one man did all that work over four years.I highly recommned this game so much, that I even spent time writing out a review of this length. Hopefully, it's filled with enough information to make you consider trying it out. :)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												A true masterpiece of a game. Dust looks great. has amazing soundtracks, badass and smooth looking combat filled with a ton of effects, precise and well made controls, an interesting story and tons of optional content to explore.Dust itself plays like a highly polished metroidvania game - you make your way through areas, later on you get new moves that allow you to discover optional paths and treasures in areas you have already visited before.During your explorations, you will meet some civilians that offer you sidequests which reward you with additional items and experience points.This, ofcourse, makes Dust stronger in a variety of ways. Experience Points are self explanatory, you collect them and get level ups (level cap is 60), each level up rewards you with one skill gem that can be used to upgrade your health, attack, defense or fidget (fidget is your companion and can be treated like a magical stat).Every skill can be upgraded 15 times, but the game limits you in a way that your highest skill can only be 4 skill levels higher than your lowest one (your defense is on level 1, so you can't upgrade anything else past level 5).This sounds like a big limitation at first, but it helps alot by keeping the game challenging throughout all areas, otherwise you could just max out fidget and oneshot everything while ignoring all other stats.In addition to leveling you can also get stronger by finding / crafting / buying new equipment.Every area has different enemies that drop different items, and every area also has some places where you can buy and sell items. Enemies can also drop material items, those can be used to craft your own gear (if you have the required blueprints which also drop from enemies and from treasure chests).Equipment slots that you can fill are the following : armor, sword augment, amulet, 2x rings.Dust only has his sword in terms of physical damage, and if you equip yourself with a sword augment you will increase your physical damage output. the other items can also provide various other bonus attributes - automated health regen, better chance for item drops, more experience gain etc.The icing on the cake however is the absolutely amazing soundtrack. Rarely do you find a game where the soundtrack adds so much to atmosphere and fun. You enter a new area and listen to the music, and you are just like "damn, that sounds amazing". Even with Dust being an extremely colorful game, the music still manages to provide a dark and mysterious atmosphere when needed, which really makes it a joy to play. example track : 


YouTube™ Video: Dust: An Elysian Tail OST - 09 - The Sorrowing Meadows 

			Views: 63,797		

			Buy our music at the links below! - http://hyperduck.bandcamp.com/album/dust-an-elysian-tail-original-soundtrack - http://www.loudr.fm/release/dust-an-elysian-tail/RqVDh Original Soundtrack from...		

Depending on the difficulty level (4 available) you choose, you will get around 10-15 hours of gametime when going for 100% completion - and trust me, you will go for 100%, since the game manages to make backtracking and exploring a lot of fun.No matter who you are, i can only recommend Dust to you. It has been the best game i have played for ages (since the release of Final Fantasy 10 i guess) and you will definitely not regret spending money on this masterfully crafted gem of a game, especially if you like metroidvania games with stylish combat and great music.10/10 would buy again.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												I always love a game with a well-written, compelling story and deep, memorable characters.  This game has them in spades!  I admit in all honesty that the ending to this game nearly made this 40-year-old man cry.  Fidget is absolutely adorable, and Dust himself is a conflicted character with a mysterious past that will surprise any player who loves a good story.The action is fun and varied, with challenging, satisfying combat sequences and some light puzzle-solving.  If I were to take the traditional 2D concept of Metroid and put it into a rich, colorful fantasy world full of anthropomorphic animal characters, I would approach what Dust: Any Elysian Tail has to offer.Moreover, I am still astounded that all of the code and artwork were done by a single developer.  Check out this game!

But that's me being nit-picky.Overall, this is a VERY good game and if you like story games and action games, this is a good one to play through. Awesome, I loved it.-SG7 ( :) )

content:
Posted: September 19, 2013
												What every other Indie game should've been. A fun, exciting and creative idea for a game that strays away from your typical Minecraft/Infiniminer clone and utilizes an art style of its own instead of your typical "SNES Style" graphics you'd see in almost every release that other developers churn out and brings out a story line and soundtrack that you'll remember throughout your life. This game maybe another sidescroller fighting game, this game still brings out a challenge to everyone and allows you to find secrets within the game if you're up for it. If you don't feel up for a higher difficulty and rather spend more time on following the storyline, they give you the option for a lower difficulty. For best experience, play it with a controller and not a keyboard. Be careful though, if you're using a certain move too much, you'll take damage. This may be a pain for people (like me) who have a nasty habit of mashing buttons while battling creatures. I recommend this to anyone who's looking for an indie game that doesn't play off the fame of Minecraft and the likes.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												Very polish game. It has great combat and great art.Attacking, launching projectiles, juggling the enemies to keep the combos up, evading if you notice the enemy starting their attack animation, and parrying. These are the essential for combat. And Dust has polished its mechanics to perfection. It's a lot of fun doing all the above. It makes you feel like a badass once you start to get into the rhythm.But its a relatively easy game for action players. I've finished the game in tough mode on my first try. If you've played other action games like Devil May Cry, I'll suggest going straight to tough mode.I'm a completionist, so it took me 15 and a half hours to finish (plus 30 mins to rush a new game on the casual difficulty to get to a certain quest to get 100% achievement). But I've noticed a lot of ways to speedrun this game and I think it can be beaten in less than 5 hours if you don't do the sidequests.Summary: Highly recommended for the great combat. The game is very polished.

content:
Posted: March 19
												Just a quick note at start: I may forget mentioning something in this review, I played the game over 2 years ago when which was the time when I was not reviewing any games. But now that I started making reviews as a small hobby, I figured I'd review this game too.Anyway, let's get into it:Dust: An Elysian Tail is an amazing game, a masterpiece and one of the best games I've ever played. It's a 2d game (by that I mean there's only left, right, up and down). You're playing as Dust, awakening in a forest, not aware of what happened to you or what you're doing there. You meet a little creature that I would describe as bat-squirrel called Fidget, who will be your companion for the whole game and with her, you set off on an adventure to discover your past. (There's a lot more in the story but I don't want to spoil it)Gameplay:Basically, four directions, left ; right ; down ; up, you are playing with an ancient sword called Ahrah and doing various combos with it by combining different keys, in order to get past your enemies. There's a lot of jumping, timing and precise button combining involved as the game can be sort of hard, BUT, you don't have to worry about that too much, there are a plenty of options, one of them being making yourself revive everytime you die, so basically invincible, if you only want to play for the story or find some part of the game too hard.I played on normal mode and easy (the invincibility one) against the final boss and the game took me 12 hours to beat, not to mention I did not do all the quests and didn't find all the easter eggs. So definitely, a lot of gameplay for the game's price. If you aim for all the achievements on steam it may as well take you around 20-25 hours, if not more.Graphics, design, art:Beautiful. The game looks exactly how it should in my eyes, the backgrounds, character artworks and everything fit the athmosphere. you have a lot of graphic options, even allowing you to move your "HUD", being a healthbar on the screen, so many details make the design of the game just perfect.Music is astonishing, I listen to the music creator's tunes to this day over and over, some of the songs are the most beautiful things I've ever heard and I don't think they'll ever get too old.But, the most astonishing thing of that all:The entire game (with the exception of voice acting and similar stuff) has been made by a single person! I know a lot of games made entirely by a single developer, but this is definitely the best one for me.Optimization/Controls:Perfect! I cannot complain about anything there. Can be run on a low tier laptop with no problem and the controls have no flaw.Summary:Pros:- Great story, tears almost rolled down my cheeks because of it after I finished the game (in a good way)- A setting that literally allows you to play the game just for chilling and story- A long gameplay, the main quest will probably take you at least 6 hours if trying to do it as fast as you can on easiest difficulty, if playing in non-invincible mode and wanting to do sidequests it may take something between 10-15 hours. Playing on hardest difficulty and for all the achievements could take around 20-25 hours?- Amazing music pieces- Well-memorable characters all throughout the game- Perfect graphics/art- Flawless gameplay- Great narration- Flawless optimization and controls- Pretty much made by one personCons:- I cannot think of any, haven't seen anything worth criticizing in the gameConclusion & reviewer's final words:If you like stories, games of this type, option to make yourself unbeatable in games, good stories (of course not everyone may see the game's story as good as I thought it is), just generally chilling gameplay combined with great tunes and want to support a talented game developer, then I'd say go for it. If I'm not wrong, this game is fairly often on a bigger discount. I believe I saw it for something like 2,5€ before? Don't take my word for that though, not completely sure about it though. If I knew what to expect of that game before, I would undoubtedly go for it even for its full price, would be worth it for me. Thank you for reading my review and hope you have a good day.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2014
												I have to admit, at first, I really didn't like this. Even right through to the end I found the characters and their art and voices to have an extremely amateur flavour. The entire thing seemed like a bog standard furry Flash on Newgrounds. Your companion especially is pretty much godawful throughout, with the occasional humourous quip. However, I persevered, and with a second launch of the game I started to overlook that initial shortcoming and start to get into what is in fact, a very good game. The settings and backgrounds were gorgeous and varied (why couldn't the artist that did that do the characters?) and I also liked the majority of the monster designs. The levels had a satisfyingly open feel with a nice sense of scale and immersion; I especially liked the zombie meadow level. The combat, levelling and crafting systems work well (although my completionist nature did seem to make my character rather overpowered towards the end of the game, making the final boss fight extremely easy), and the game has a decent amount of varied and interesting equipment to kit out your character with. While primarily an action game, I found many of the hidden treasures and their puzzles quite satisfying, and especially liked the secret 'Friends' and their bonuses. The hidden Trials were also quite a lot of fun to master, giving a little bit of extra to the game. I also found the story good with an interesting setup, although suffering from the standard aribtrary development stifling (AKA "You'll find out later because no reason other than it'll make the story longer").Overall a good an unique contender in the Metroidvania genre, worth picking up if you're into that sort of game and don't mind the characters and amateurish aspects.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												I could not bring myself not to do a review on pretty much one of my favorite games. This game is one of the best platformers I have ever seem. Or Brawler.. or RPG.. or all of them. It is really mixed on what it is.Now, the fact that, in my opinion, that you are buying a $15 (Or Regional Equivalent) that took 4 years, and only by ONE person.  ONE . (His name is Dean Dodrill, praise him fo what he created)It's backstory in sales that it was an XBLA Title, during the Summer of Sales (Or whatever the hell it was called) and it was ported to PC. Which, most say the PC port is the best because of how much its graphics are better and run smoother. Christ, I even am playing this on a laptop with max settings and it runs just the same with the lower graphics! Pros (Settings): Full on great graphics. Everything is hand-drawn, and the fact that there is just SO much great graphical abilities, it just oozes creativity.Great Controls. The game has easy-to-learn controls. LMB is to attack, RMB is for Dust Storm, MMB is for Fidget's Projectile attack. Don't have a mouse or have one of the worst mouses out there that scurries away before you plug it in? The game also binds a couple of keys on the keyboard when you need them! It also comes with Gamepad Support.Cons (Settings):No "low" resolution. It means that if your framerate sucks (Which I doubt it would), it can only be put to normal, and then you have to turn down resolution all together.Now, the gameplay is great. It has one of the tightest responses there is. Breathing on your "D" key would make him move mabybe 1/1000 of a millimeter (Not really) And it just has a great system for combat. It is simple, and easy to play.Pros (Gameplay): Easy to learn combat system. It even gives you a move list in the "How to play" option.Responsive Controls. Can't explain that further.No ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Quests. Sure, there are fetch quests, which almost every RPG has, but it does it with a twist, either meaning you have to get a certain ability or you have to defeat a certain enemy and hope they drop. Or, if you are like me, you cataloug every material you have.Catalouging System. This system is simple. Sell a material that vendors don't have Catalouged, come back later, more of that come in. There are 42 items to cataloug in all, ranging from rare drops from strong enemies, to extermely common, *cough* Maggots *cough*, and easy-to-find ones.Pretty much a 3 basic attack system. 3 basic attacks. Swordplay, Fidget's Projectiles, and both combined using Dust Storm.Cons (Gameplay):A buggy "No Escape" system. What happens is that if a group of enemies are nearby, you can't move on to the next area until you kill them. Which is good, but the fact that you can just do a perfectly-timed Dash and go through it.Lack of weapons. Your only weapons are Ahrah and Fidget's Attacks, no bows or shotguns, or special little bombs. This is 45% good, 55% bad, as for the fact that enemies can kill you in the air or with cheap high-damage attacks with no block ability.The Story is a great narritive. It truly is. It's not a yiff and anthro fanfic like most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ would expect, but instead it is a great story of loss, death, and redemption. I rarely see how even the character is actually something else than he thinks.Pros (Story):A highly believeable story. This story is actually like as if you knocked your head on something, went into a coma, had terrible amnesia, remembered your bad deeds (or at least what you think you did), and redeem yourself for what you did.The furry/anthro undertone can be removed and nearly nothing would be changed but the mood. Things are usually explained. As I mean this, either what happens is explained through dialouge, notes, or the unfolding story. I.e. There is a large enemy known as a "Trolk", and they ae explained that they can only be killed by stunning them, mainly because how thick their skin and sheilds are.Cons (Story):Independent Voices. This is only reflecting the bad of it, which is the microphone and recording quality. They are actually different, some are obviously extremely far from their microphone, while others are actually talking in the right sense.No real "Choices". The only choices you really get are that, in a side quest, you choose to add poison ivy to an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥'s clothes. (Either way is an achievement). Sure, there is only a "Good" ending, but that means what would be the bad? Overall Score:9.5/10This game comes so close to being perfect. It really does. It is just annoying that you can't really feel fully immersed if the guy you are speaking to sounds like he talks in a very soft manner for a large person, or that it caught a small background noise. This game isn't meant for speed running, hence why some mechanics are in place. I truly recommend you buy this, because this is a masterpeice of a game.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Not too accustomed to writing reviews, so forgive me if something seems shortsighted or off-kilter here.That being said, I feel the need to give this game the recognition it deserves. It isn't often that a game comes along and leaves me with my mouth agape, shocked at the ratio of quality to manpower given to bring something to fruition. It was basically a one-man job, with a few exceptions to music, voice-acting and parts of the writing. This is not a game that makes you think that at all.Beautiful, strong, crisp, varied, colorful aesthetic that leads to gorgeous graphics. Music that evokes that classic, childlike sense of wonder of exploring, excitement, and adventure. Every time I would just bring up the map screen to teleport to a different area, it's evoke a powerful sense of nostalgia from me.Combatwise, everything is done with a blade and elemental ranged attacks, with ways to mix and match them all together. It's basically like a side-scrolling, platforming brawler with a nice degree of variation on enemy types and available tactics on taking them down.The story starts off somewhat simple, and feels like it's treading familiar territory for a little while, but quickly becomes more complex as it goes on. I won't give any spoilers, but needless to say, I wasn't expecting the game to do what it did later on, close to the finish.If I have any nitpicks, they are few. The lip-synching on the characters is a bit off, without much difference between the few mouth movements available. The voice-acting, while quite good overall, tends to give certain characters voices that don't quite fit, in addition to there being rather uneven sound quality amongst the performances. Still, these are both very minor issues, and I stopped noticing them after a while. It's just something I thought I should mention.Honestly, I could go on with this, but I don't want to keep you waiting. Overall, Dust: An Elysian Tail is one of the best games I've played in quite a while. It was a stellar experience, and I think that anyone who is able to make a game like this almost by themselves definitely deserves support. I recommend it to just about anyone.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												Developing video games is tough, even from the outside that seems obvious. It's not impossible, but it's one hell of a challenge, one that takes patience, time and talent to name just a few of the requirements to make it in the industry. So designer Dean Dodrill's accomplishments with Dust: An Elysian Tail is one to be applauded. Having developed the vast majority of this charming action adventure game himself, it's clear throughout that this is Dean's baby, resulting in a game that's beautiful, fun and one of the most captivating 2D side-scrollers I've played in years.Dust: An Elysian Tail tells the story of Dust, a being with little knowledge of his past or his own identity. He's Awaken from slumber by a talking floating sword called Ahrah and the swords protectorate Fidget, a flying bat slash cat creature thing. This strange partnership must band together to help Dust figure out both his past and future in the lands of Falana, which have been beaten down by the terrors and horrors of war. For a story, it's one that nicely contrasts against much of the games visual design and isn't afraid to touch on some mature story points from the death and killing of innocents to the terrible physical and mental impact of war on those that survive it. I found myself surprised by the direction taken by the story till the very end and it's an area of the game that held strong throughout resulting in a story that benefits in developing the world as much as it keeps the tale chugging along.Now upon it's release Dust received some criticism for its art style, which to some degree I can understand. It's most certainly not an ugly game by any regard, the wonderful 2D landscapes are gorgeous with an impressive level of attention given to almost every level of the game, but some might find themselves turned off by the furry like characters that popular the lands of Falana. Personally I was charmed with it's interesting cast of characters all voiced to an high degree resulting in a world that's more interesting than you'd think it had any right to be. Dust's small but useful sidekick Fidget in particular is an high point thanks to some great dialogue and cute voice work by Kimlinh Tran. It all results in an high level of polish that you can't help but admire considering the time and effort put in by the mainly one man development team.An action packed side-scroller, Dust is primarily inspired by the likes of Castlevania and Metroid with it's walled off sections that make traversal and map navigation part of the challenge. Anyone who's spent time with the genre will feel right at home here thanks to the fact that navigation is a breeze and finding all those treasures and secrets as always been part of the real fun with these sorts of games. An Elysian Tail is no different and while you'll be traveling a large variety of regions, you'll find himself traveling back to lands you've already visited in search of treasures that were once inaccessible to you. On his journey Dust will have access to new and varied powers that can be used to discover and access these treasures and even be used in combat. The powers range from the ability to slide under walls to secondary jumps to be able to double jump and reach higher points in the landscape. What's great about all these powers is that there just as effective in combat as they are when platforming.Falana is a land filled with a nice variety of baddies to swing your magical sword at and thankfully combat remains fun for the most part, even if I did find myself button mashing most of the time. Enemies will reappear if you exit and reenter an area so it's possible to grind your skills and levels if you wish. One note I'd add is that on normal, Dust can be a little to easy and whilst there are a few challenges here and there, it's not exactly a difficult game so you might want to consider playing are a harder difficulty level if that's your thing. Leveling up and enhancing skills is a fun addition, as is the ability to craft and equip new items to wear, although some might find crafting items becomes a nuisance once you near the end. All that said, every gameplay mechanic at work plays well together resulting in an highly polished experience and one I had fun with until the very end.So Dust: An Elysian Tail is an impressive achievement by Dean Dodrill and his team of various contributors in the two years of development. It's an impressive achievement because you wouldn't guess that the majority of it's development was worked on by only one man. Rich in content, visually beautiful and sounding great, not to mention a story that's more memorable than you've come to expect from the genre, it all results in a game I'd highly recommend you play for yourself, even if you're turned off by the character designs. Dust: An Elysian Tail is one of the most charming games I've played in quite a while.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												tl:dr - BUY IT.I'm a gamer for more than 15 years and this is one of my favorite games of all time.Graphics - Absolutely gorgeous. Music fits the graphics. Fighting system is simple but very enjoyable. It's fast, easy (From complexity standpoint) and visually appealing (everything explodes, shines, combos goes up to few hundrets). It's a metroidvania with a light RPG elements. Story is kinda generic, but it's satisfying, The only problem I had was how the characters looks like. Enemies looks relatively good, but NPC have that very cheap furry/cartoon style. I would rather like to see more "direct furry approach" or at least better quality of them  (shading, color pallete, more details, etc.). The only good looking NPC is Fidget (that flying cat/bat thingy... She's a Nimbat.). Characters are very good written. Oh, and Fidget is The Cutest character in video game I've ever seen. A want a plushie of her :3  (so I can keep her foreveeerrr....) 	 Anyway, Game took me about 13h to fully complete it, it's relatively hard on "hard difficulty", I haven't encountered any bugs or errors. I was playing it on Windows XP (Steam says it requires Vista/7). No slowdowns. In other words - Works good. Nothing much to say, really. It's a fantastic game, you should go and buy it. It's definitely worth your money.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2013
												So, where do I start... Possibly amongst the best games I've ever played in my entire life. It has some minor flaws, including a bug in the final boss fight which forces you to fight the boos all over again but other than that it's a masterpiece, a well polished PC port and a fine work of art. The soundtrack is relaxing and fits the game atmosphere very well. The combat is surprisingly satisfying, it combines brawling with hack and slash, in other words I can say that this is a Metroidvania ARPG Brawler. The combos are pretty good and the attack variety is somehow doesn't have alot of variety but it doesn't feel boring. The story is pretty great and overall that sells this game for me. I'm sure that pretty much anyone can enjoy this game and if you don't feel like paying full price for it, wait for a sale and then get it. I got it during a 50% sale but now I can safely say that the game is worth the full price, but this is only a matter of opinion. That said, please buy and play this, support the developer and MAYBE in the future there will be more games like this one.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a game to which I have no bad words to say. It is a 2D hack-n-slash action RPG in which you play as Dust, a somewhat confused warrior with no memory of his past, as he journeys through the land of Falana in search of his identity. The story is well-written, moving, intriguing and exciting right to the end.The combat in Dust is simple but effective, with a depth to it that keeps it from ever growing stale. The enemies, too, are delightfully varied, with many requiring different techniques if you want to fight them effectively.The game is populated by many memorable characters, and all of them have their own superb voice actors and unique personalities. Some of them can seem two-dimensional, yet they are all believable characters, helping to make the vibrant world come to life. Most notable is your constant companion, Fidget - a cute, lovable and entertaining little creature who never annoys and is amazingly helpful, especially towards the end of the game.But what really stands out about Dust is the beautiful environment. Each area has its own aesthetic, perfectly realised by the scenery and complemented by an excellent soundtrack. Moreover, you are encouraged to explore this world, with over twenty side-quests, XP bonuses just for talking to new people and dozens of little secrets littered around the world, some of which are very interesting in their own right.If I had to make one criticism, it would be that the blacksmith is not as useful as she perhaps should be, since her fee for crafting an item is the same as you would get for selling it. However, this is a small complaint, and not one moment of gameplay is a disappointment. I count Dust among the best games I have ever played.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
 Dust: An Elysian Tail  Story and Characters: 9/10 Dust: AET has one of the most engaging stories I've ever had the pleasure to experience. Characters are varied and all have some special quirks that make them all memorable. The dialogues in this game have these "quirks" just the right amount to make these characters seem more like individuals that you are interested in rather than just a squad of generic beings that you come across and smash A to skip the dialogue as fast as you can. Voice acting is great overall but at times could be heard that some of the voices weren't necessarily by a well-known professional, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but definitely noticable. Gameplay: 8/10 There is not much to say about the gameplay. Quite generic "smash buttons until baddies disappear". There is a special "move" called DUST STORM that you get quite early on and that is probably what you'll be spamming for the next 8 hours or so. I played the game on NORMAL difficulty and I would suggest NORMAL for this game if you're looking to play it for the story, since it has some of the epic moments of "Oh god. I'm gonna die soon but so is the enemy" but it also makes moving between areas easier and more relaxed since you don't have to spend 10 minutes per group of enemies. Graphics: 8.5/10 This game isn't filled with a billion small particle effects or four tons of bloom and still managed to amaze me in nearly every area I went to. The cutscenes have a charming hand-drawn look to them that is beautifully executed and that makes them nothing to sneeze at. Music: 10/10 Down right amazing. The music always fit the feeling I had while playing. Epic soundtrack. Can't say much more than that.You'll most likely get 8-12 hours out of the campaign but will probably get 20+ hours if you plan to 100% everything and get all achievements (I don't know for sure, haven't done that yet) . Overall: 9/10 This is definitely a game that I will remember and will most likely play through again in the future. I'd definitely say this is one of the best games I've played recently, and even one of the best I've ever played. Even though the gameplay aspect becomes quite frustratingly repetitive towards the end, the story kept my interest in the game very high. I definitely suggest picking this up if you're looking for an engaging story-driven game with beautiful visuals that is not too hard for a casual gamer.

content:
Posted: September 19, 2013
												What every other Indie game should've been. A fun, exciting and creative idea for a game that strays away from your typical Minecraft/Infiniminer clone and utilizes an art style of its own instead of your typical "SNES Style" graphics you'd see in almost every release that other developers churn out and brings out a story line and soundtrack that you'll remember throughout your life. This game maybe another sidescroller fighting game, this game still brings out a challenge to everyone and allows you to find secrets within the game if you're up for it. If you don't feel up for a higher difficulty and rather spend more time on following the storyline, they give you the option for a lower difficulty. For best experience, play it with a controller and not a keyboard. Be careful though, if you're using a certain move too much, you'll take damage. This may be a pain for people (like me) who have a nasty habit of mashing buttons while battling creatures. I recommend this to anyone who's looking for an indie game that doesn't play off the fame of Minecraft and the likes.

content:
Posted: March 19
												Just a quick note at start: I may forget mentioning something in this review, I played the game over 2 years ago when which was the time when I was not reviewing any games. But now that I started making reviews as a small hobby, I figured I'd review this game too.Anyway, let's get into it:Dust: An Elysian Tail is an amazing game, a masterpiece and one of the best games I've ever played. It's a 2d game (by that I mean there's only left, right, up and down). You're playing as Dust, awakening in a forest, not aware of what happened to you or what you're doing there. You meet a little creature that I would describe as bat-squirrel called Fidget, who will be your companion for the whole game and with her, you set off on an adventure to discover your past. (There's a lot more in the story but I don't want to spoil it)Gameplay:Basically, four directions, left ; right ; down ; up, you are playing with an ancient sword called Ahrah and doing various combos with it by combining different keys, in order to get past your enemies. There's a lot of jumping, timing and precise button combining involved as the game can be sort of hard, BUT, you don't have to worry about that too much, there are a plenty of options, one of them being making yourself revive everytime you die, so basically invincible, if you only want to play for the story or find some part of the game too hard.I played on normal mode and easy (the invincibility one) against the final boss and the game took me 12 hours to beat, not to mention I did not do all the quests and didn't find all the easter eggs. So definitely, a lot of gameplay for the game's price. If you aim for all the achievements on steam it may as well take you around 20-25 hours, if not more.Graphics, design, art:Beautiful. The game looks exactly how it should in my eyes, the backgrounds, character artworks and everything fit the athmosphere. you have a lot of graphic options, even allowing you to move your "HUD", being a healthbar on the screen, so many details make the design of the game just perfect.Music is astonishing, I listen to the music creator's tunes to this day over and over, some of the songs are the most beautiful things I've ever heard and I don't think they'll ever get too old.But, the most astonishing thing of that all:The entire game (with the exception of voice acting and similar stuff) has been made by a single person! I know a lot of games made entirely by a single developer, but this is definitely the best one for me.Optimization/Controls:Perfect! I cannot complain about anything there. Can be run on a low tier laptop with no problem and the controls have no flaw.Summary:Pros:- Great story, tears almost rolled down my cheeks because of it after I finished the game (in a good way)- A setting that literally allows you to play the game just for chilling and story- A long gameplay, the main quest will probably take you at least 6 hours if trying to do it as fast as you can on easiest difficulty, if playing in non-invincible mode and wanting to do sidequests it may take something between 10-15 hours. Playing on hardest difficulty and for all the achievements could take around 20-25 hours?- Amazing music pieces- Well-memorable characters all throughout the game- Perfect graphics/art- Flawless gameplay- Great narration- Flawless optimization and controls- Pretty much made by one personCons:- I cannot think of any, haven't seen anything worth criticizing in the gameConclusion & reviewer's final words:If you like stories, games of this type, option to make yourself unbeatable in games, good stories (of course not everyone may see the game's story as good as I thought it is), just generally chilling gameplay combined with great tunes and want to support a talented game developer, then I'd say go for it. If I'm not wrong, this game is fairly often on a bigger discount. I believe I saw it for something like 2,5€ before? Don't take my word for that though, not completely sure about it though. If I knew what to expect of that game before, I would undoubtedly go for it even for its full price, would be worth it for me. Thank you for reading my review and hope you have a good day.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												Let me start by saying I cried twice while playing this game. The second time it took me a while to stop.Never before have i played a game with a story so strong and heart-tugging that i had to constantly stop just to take a deep breath.Dust: An Elysian Tail is a side-scrolling adventure like no other. The character development. voice work, and plot are so prefected i can't even begin to describe it.The gameplay is smooth and flawless. While yes, you can only have one sword (It's essential to the plotline), its one hell of a sword. The enemies, minibosses and bosses are colorful and unique, and through my 10 hours of playing my first game i never stopped experimenting with combo's. (That 1000 point combo.... damn!)Your little companion, Fidget, has to be the most adorable character i've ever seen in a game of this type. I fell i love with her sarcasm and tough-girl act immediately. Her range moves also helped me through many a tough spot. But really the main reason i like having her around is becuase i can always count on her to make me smile in the darker parts of the game.This game may be rated E, but thats a stretch. Some moments in this game really play your heart strings. Like i said before, i cried twice, and i dont cry often. The story makes this game, it really does.The item and shop system is a masterpiece. I found myself returning to familiar places to collect up on new supplies to sell, trade and send to the blacksmith for better stuff. There are hundreds of items from sword augments to armor to food (Don't eat the Mysterious Wall Chicken. It's mysterious.) to jewelry. The soundtrack hit spot on in this game. I did, more than once, find myself standing still on a level just to hear the beautiful, spooky, or just plain awesome music.The average playthrough of this game is about 10 hours. That;s how long it took me. If you rush you could probably do it in 8. if you take the time to do all the side quests and collect all the best items you could be at this game for 50 hours or more.It's worth it though. NOTE: Once you complete the game, you cannot return to the world. make sure you do everything you want to BEFORE you take on the ending.This game is (If played in normal or higher) not a cake walk. It's a hard game that challenges you to experiment and get creative. There are moments where you will be gritting your teeth. The final boss battle was so intense i was off my chair. (If you play on casual, the game is MUCH more relaxed, since the death sysem reverts to a "Lose EXP, but keep playing" system.)As far as visuals go: My god. The game is beautifully crafted. Never before have i seen a side-scroller quite like this. It's just breathtaking, it really is.All in all, this game is a masterpiece that deserves far more attention than it gets. Buy it now, i promise you you will not be sorry.10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is an elegant masterpiece.I actually bought this game on a mere whim, when I felt I wanted to try a new game, and this was on sale, so I decided to give it a shot. That has turned out to be one of the best game purchases of my life.So, why should you buy Dust: An Elysian Tail?First, the beautifully hand-crafted art is to die for. Second, as an action-packed platformer, the combat system is easy to learn but hard to master. You'll take awhile before you learn how to snag achievements like That's More Like It (Successfully complete a 1000+ hit combo) and The Stuff of Legends (Earn a Four-Star Rating in EVERY Challenge Arena), which makes it that little bit sweeter when you do.Third, apart from it's main storyline, there are many side-quests and secret locations to conquer and discover. Looking to uncover them all? Don't stop at 100% completion, it goes up to 117% completion. Amen.Last, but certainly not least, is the compelling storyline. There is a fine balance between humour and drama. You'll be hooked to follow the storyline up till the grand finale.Your parents probably told you to never talk to strangers, but I need you to trust me and do yourself a favour by purchasing and playing this game. You have no idea what you're missing out on if you don't.

												I'm not very far into Dust: An Elysian Tail yet, but my first impression is that this game is beautiful, to put it simply. The artwork, character design, and level design are created with a level of detail that is breathtaking. Mechanics wise, this game flows well. There are several different ways of playing: with an Xbox controller, keyboard, or mouse and keyboard - I went with the final choice. It does feel slightly "button mash-y," but the game still requires a level of skill and adaptation, as there are several different combos and attacks that can be used with different combinations of keys.Overall, this game is worth every penny that you would spend on it. I can say this with confidence after only playing the game for 35 minutes. Oh, and that number won't stay at 35 for long.

												Dust an Elysian Tail is a wonderfully constructed game that I would recommend for anyone who has the cash to spare. Right of the bat you are immersed into a bright, colorful world with environments that are ever changing.The voice acting is superb and  helps really breathe some life into those whacky animal-like characters that are littered throughout the entire game. As far as replayability value goes there are different difficulty settings and the level up system forces you to spec your hero in certain ways, adding weight to each point you spec with. The game has over 20 different sidequests each with there own different challenges assuring the player that they will never be bored. Slap an entertaining plot ontop of the above and you get Dust.Overall I give it a 8/10 Graphics +Content +Replayability +-

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I played through the game on Hardcore difficulty and enjoyed it. This is one of the best Indie games I have played. It has amazing artwork, great sence of humour and intersting characters. The story keeps you interested and you will want to know what will happen next, who is everybody and why things are happening. There are some references from other games (some are very well hidden) but not too hard to find if you use your head. Some negative points worth noting:I used xbox 360 controller to play and sometimes found that using analog stick to perform certain actions might cause you to do the wrong move. This is really annoying when you try to do trials where time and precision is crucial. I failed so many times when my character jumped instead of ducking and sliding or vice versa. I do however recommend playing with a controller even though keyboard and mouse works great, controller is still better.You will probably want to play it once because once you know the story there will be no point in playing again so if you played on casual you are simply wasted your time because it was too easy and you can finish it in few hours. There are, however, 25 sidequestes which you can complete and you won't get all achievements unless you do them all.Difficulty curve is not ideal. On harcode mode is really hard to start that will cause you to die over and over until you reach some levels or keep killing same enemies over and over. Later on it when you level up and get some items it becomes too easy. Simply be patient and you will enjoy the game without any annoying issues.Overall it is great game that is worth your time. I spent over 30 hours and got all the achievements.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Now, I'm not one for side scrollers, but chalk this up as one of my exceptions.  If there's anything this game lacks in, which in my hours of playtime I found little lacking, it certainly makes up for in its ... well everything!  The artwork is fantastic, the characters are all loveable, everything is properly balanced and the storyline is as rock solid as it comes.  But, those aren't what had me so enrwrapped in this game.  The emotional rollercoaster that this game puts the player through marks this as one of my all time favorite games.  The high and low moments that lead up to the ending scene leave the player cherishing all of those good moments and snarky conversations.The only thing else I can say is to buy it, buy it, buy it!  Seriously, I don't think I could stress enough that if you don't already own this game you're missing out on a fantastic story.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail looks a little different than your typical action/adventure game, but its similarities should keep you around for a while.The game begins with you, "Dust" waking up to find yourself in a forest with no memory of your past or how you ended up at your location. As if it wasn't strange enough, a magical sword finds you and speaks to you, followed by a small, annoying creature. They accompany you on a journey to find who you are, why you awoke with no memory, and why you were chosen to wield a magical sword.Presentation: 8/10The story isn't groundbreaking but is enough to get anyone to wonder what's in store for a protagonist with amnesia as he travels through the country. Dust is a kind character, who helps those he can (if you complete the quests) until he finds his past. The game adequately tells the tale from start to finish, but you can never really tell how much of an impact you're making by the end.Graphics: 7.5/10Cute cartoon artstyle settles well and takes your mind off the fact that Dust: An Elysian Tail was designed and programmed by a single individual.Sound: 7.5/10The pleasant music never stuck itself in places unneeded, a good addition overall. The voice acting was good for some characters, but never made Fidget any less annoying.Gameplay: 8/10Fluid, fast-paced and with different options to attack your enemies, the combat was well received. There are many items to acquire, along with the secret non-playable characters hidden throughout the game. My only gripe is the hideous transitioning of the camera as you fly through the map.Overall: 7.8/10A good purchase if you're looking for some action/adventure. With only limited replayability, the game can keep you busy for several days before you find yourself with not much else to do, but for a well-polished game, its price is definitely worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												This game wasn't quite what I expected.  It's one of those titles where the enemies are pretty tough & do a lot of damage, but are slow and telegraph their attacks.  Your character, on the other hand, is fragile and doesn't hit very hard, but can attack with great rapidity.  So, your only chance of winning (esp. on the higher difficulties) is to keep your foes stunlocked  with an all-out assault, chaining hits and special moves together to never give them an opening.  As I've stated before, I don't really like fighting games, where you have to pull off specific key combinations with millisecond timing.  This is pushing things a little, but I was still able to use the combos they had programmed in, which is fortunately not that many.  This does limit the depth of the system and mean the combats can get very same-y after a while, though.So, it feels kind of incongruous.  Your protagonist is basically a walking abattoir, chewing through monsters with gusto.  Except he's also supposed to be a rabbit, I guess?  And all the other characters are cartoon animals too?  The story similarly veers back and forth between srs bzns and light-hearted banter.  It doesn't help matters that the game is one of the worst offenders in the Cutesy Sidekick That Never Shuts Up category.The art and animation are top-notch, considering this is a small-budget title.  It's not quite up there with the Odin Spheres of the world, but damn close.  The whole game is a bit on the short side, and probably much shorter still if you don't bother  hunting down all the sidequests and collecting everything.  That said, I had a lot of fun with it, and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys action-RPGs.

content:
Posted: June 10, 2014
												A Metroidvania with RPG elements. Visually, the game is amazing, bringing gorgeous graphics and animation, excellent gameplay. However, it has (so far) a clichéd story we've seen several times before, delivering yet another amnesiac protagonist, which is the game's weakest point (really, we don't need another of those)...But that being just one low point, this game is still very much recommended, especially if you're a Metroidvania fan. As an extra recommendation, ignore Easy and Normal difficulty modes entirely and start playing on Tough for your first playthrough. It's the one I started on, and it seems to deliver a good balance, being challenging at times but not to the point of being unfair.And if you need something more to convince you, it has Mysterious Wall Chicken.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												It's so hard to believe that this beautiful game was constructed from the ground up by the hand of a single individual over the course of nearly five years of his life as a passion project. Smooth animation, amazing sound quality, beautiful artwork style and music tracks, responsive controls, and brilliant gameplay. This game is the shining example of what the indie community is capable of doing. This game in indie game standards is nearly 100% perfect. The voice acting in the game is not as bad as people may claim it to be. Granted at some times during cutscenes, some voices are a little hard to listen to at times, meaning its not the best but its not bad by any means. The art style choice of the game may give some thick-skulled individuals on the internet a bad first impression. People should look at the art design as NOT being a nod to the furry community, but rather look at it as what the art choice was for some early Disney films like Robin Hood or Lion King. This game caters to several game genres including RPGs, Metroidvanias, hack & slash or beat em' ups, platformers, and even puzzle games.There is no reason why anyone should have to miss out on this incredible expierence. Whether its on sale or at full price, this game will show you that its worth every last penny. There is only one complaint I can honestly say about this game. Though it has several difficulty settings, if you are familiar and well-aquainted with Beat em up side scroller games than this game can be very easy for some of you. The only time the game can be honestly challenging to everyone is on the hardest difficulty setting. Other than that one complaint, the game is sheer perfection. If you buy this game, you will not regret it.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Step into the shoes of Dust, another hero with amnesia, and travel a Metroidvania-esque world to slay monsters, talk to NPCs and find hidden treasures!The gameplay is, all in all, rather simple. You run around, jump and kill a lot of stuff. You kill stuff by swinging your talking sword and employing the abilities of your flying squirrel-thingy Fidget, which sometimes bears resemblance to such annoying sidekicks like Navi from the Legend of Zelda.The fighting itself is pretty simple. Your standard attack is a 3-hit combo, on the ground and in the air. Combine with your special ability and your sidekick you create some nice combos. You will also learn some new moves along your way, but they're primarily for traversing the world, which - in best Metroidvania-manner - has a lot of places you can't get through until you have the ability needed for it.If you want to explore and get absolutely everything, you'll have to do a LOT of backtracking, but you can also use teleport stones that make it a bit easier.Besides fighting and finding treasures you'll also encounter many NPCs you can talk to. Talking might reveal information and sidequests. You will also get experience from talking to NPCs, which I find a really nice little feature.Crafting is also present. Defeating enemies or opening treasure chests might get you blueprints and material to craft the items from the blueprints. To make that a bit easier you can sell material to the shopkeepers, who then add them to their inventory, which makes it possible to purchase those materials from them. Quite handy if you can't or don't want to find them on your way around.The game looks absolutely incredible btw. Beautiful levels accompanied by a nice soundtrack.Not a big fan of the character design though. I don't mind antropomorphic animals in the slightest, but I just didn't like how many of them looked.Also worth mentioning is the voice acting, as it's quite good. Not all were that good, but mostly it was very well done.All things considered a really nice game with a decent story, good gameplay and gorgeous visuals :)

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a masterpiece, plain an simple. The world of Dust is presented with amazing scenery and hand drawn and animated characters accompanied by beautiful music. You take control of an amnesic swordsman on a journey to discover himself and every character you meet along the way is voice acted and memorable. Not the least of is Fidget a character accompanies you the whole game and provides much of the game's needed comic relief. There is a real sense of joy as you uncover more of the story as you play, and help Dust learn more about himself (as well as hear what Fidget has to say about various encounters).Gameplay wise Dust is a 2D metroidvania platformer. As you slice baddies you earn experience which you can use to improve your stats as you see fit and equip and craft items to further enhance your stats. Over the course of the game you and Fidget also gain further abilities to allow more freedom in not only disposing of your enemies but also reaching new areas. Apart from the main story there are a number of side-quests as well as hidden arenas to test your skill. And it is all a blast to play. I would really recommend a gamepad to play, especially an XBox 360 Controller.The most impressive thing about Dust: An Elysian Tail is the fact that apart from the music, voice acting and part of the story, Dust was created, programmed and drawn entirely by one man,  Dean Dodrill. So in a way Dust is like an American equivalent of Cave Story. I know that may sound like a stretch, but honestly this game has brought me a lot of joy and fond memories and I would highly recommend this to anyone.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a masterpiece, plain an simple. The world of Dust is presented with amazing scenery and hand drawn and animated characters accompanied by beautiful music. You take control of an amnesic swordsman on a journey to discover himself and every character you meet along the way is voice acted and memorable. Not the least of is Fidget a character accompanies you the whole game and provides much of the game's needed comic relief. There is a real sense of joy as you uncover more of the story as you play, and help Dust learn more about himself (as well as hear what Fidget has to say about various encounters).Gameplay wise Dust is a 2D metroidvania platformer. As you slice baddies you earn experience which you can use to improve your stats as you see fit and equip and craft items to further enhance your stats. Over the course of the game you and Fidget also gain further abilities to allow more freedom in not only disposing of your enemies but also reaching new areas. Apart from the main story there are a number of side-quests as well as hidden arenas to test your skill. And it is all a blast to play. I would really recommend a gamepad to play, especially an XBox 360 Controller.The most impressive thing about Dust: An Elysian Tail is the fact that apart from the music, voice acting and part of the story, Dust was created, programmed and drawn entirely by one man,  Dean Dodrill. So in a way Dust is like an American equivalent of Cave Story. I know that may sound like a stretch, but honestly this game has brought me a lot of joy and fond memories and I would highly recommend this to anyone.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Now, I'm not one for side scrollers, but chalk this up as one of my exceptions.  If there's anything this game lacks in, which in my hours of playtime I found little lacking, it certainly makes up for in its ... well everything!  The artwork is fantastic, the characters are all loveable, everything is properly balanced and the storyline is as rock solid as it comes.  But, those aren't what had me so enrwrapped in this game.  The emotional rollercoaster that this game puts the player through marks this as one of my all time favorite games.  The high and low moments that lead up to the ending scene leave the player cherishing all of those good moments and snarky conversations.The only thing else I can say is to buy it, buy it, buy it!  Seriously, I don't think I could stress enough that if you don't already own this game you're missing out on a fantastic story.

Posted: July 16, 2014
												I got this game on sale with low expectations, but was blown away.  I really enjoyed the colorful and bright environments.  I thought the voice acting was well done.  The story was alright, I thought it became a little predictable after a while.  The gameplay was very good.  I played with the keyboard only controls and didn't have any problems.  Combat is fairly simple, I found myself just executing the same combo's after a while, but the game does attempt to throw you off with differing enemy types in each new area.  The puzzles were somewhat simple, but well executed.  Another nice thing is it runs fairly well on older computers/laptops.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is an elegant masterpiece.I actually bought this game on a mere whim, when I felt I wanted to try a new game, and this was on sale, so I decided to give it a shot. That has turned out to be one of the best game purchases of my life.So, why should you buy Dust: An Elysian Tail?First, the beautifully hand-crafted art is to die for. Second, as an action-packed platformer, the combat system is easy to learn but hard to master. You'll take awhile before you learn how to snag achievements like That's More Like It (Successfully complete a 1000+ hit combo) and The Stuff of Legends (Earn a Four-Star Rating in EVERY Challenge Arena), which makes it that little bit sweeter when you do.Third, apart from it's main storyline, there are many side-quests and secret locations to conquer and discover. Looking to uncover them all? Don't stop at 100% completion, it goes up to 117% completion. Amen.Last, but certainly not least, is the compelling storyline. There is a fine balance between humour and drama. You'll be hooked to follow the storyline up till the grand finale.Your parents probably told you to never talk to strangers, but I need you to trust me and do yourself a favour by purchasing and playing this game. You have no idea what you're missing out on if you don't.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												I have over 600 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game. One Hour Reviews #52 - Dust: An Elysian TailI found Dust to be a really easy game to pick up and enjoy. The gameplay consists of a mix of exploration and combat.  Combat is pretty fun.  It does involve a lot of button mashing, but there are lots of different button combinations you can use to perform different attacks.  It starts out pretty easy but once you start getting into your first boss battles, it will start to present a challenge.  But really casual players will appreciate the inclusion of a difficulty setting in the options.  It does include an easy mode for people who just want to enjoy the story without too much of a challenge.I'd say the strongest part of the game is definitely the art. The characters and backgrounds are very well done.  Dust is a beautiful game, which is great given the emphasis on exploration.   There is some platforming involved as you explore, but I didn't find any of it particularly difficult.  Dust really seems to go out of it's way to be broadly accessible, without feeling dumbed down.This is going to end up being a short review, as I'm really challenged to come up with anything I didn't like about Dust.  Everything from the art to the music and sound to the fighting and the story just all come together.  This really feels like a game that anyone can enjoy.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												This game.. this game man.Dust: An Elysian Tail is a very mysterious game at the beginning, of which then things slowly unfold and make sense at a fair pace.  You'll constantly want to know how or for the matter why Dust is here and why he's able to do all these moves and fight like a warrior.  Anything described story wise is a serious spoiler and you really, really, really do not want to spoil this amazing game so it's being skipped.Gameplay wise it's a hack n slash with some RPG elements thrown in that actually mix well.  You have your health, stamina to do specific abilties, can craft items once you find a blacksmith, sell materials to a shop owner so they can restock up on them for you to buy later.  Obviously you level up too, where you can set in skill gems to tailor towards what you want to have on a high priority.  Still gotta put in some gems on the lower leveled ones in order to keep building up Dust to a powerhouse.There's plenty of sides to do, things to unlock and discover, all the while enjoying the incredibly detailed and well drawn art.  The art alone is a very colorful and well done style that is impressive for a mostly one man game.  Almost could say it inspires some to get into drawing.Don't let all the talking anthro animal stuff fool you, it's like An American Tail, movies like that of which could have been some inspriation to having these type of characters.  So it's not because the creator is some furry or furries in general, just don't.  Don't let that one single word sneer you away from this game.  You'll regret it, heavily.It's hard to give this a 9/10, it's just so damn well made and entirely perfect, including the port to pc.  A quick note about the pc port. It's amazing what can be done if you take your time doing it, not rushing it like some of these major ass♥♥♥♥ companies do today with their half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ports to pc from console.10/10 solid, it deserves that well.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												I played through the game on Hardcore difficulty and enjoyed it. This is one of the best Indie games I have played. It has amazing artwork, great sence of humour and intersting characters. The story keeps you interested and you will want to know what will happen next, who is everybody and why things are happening. There are some references from other games (some are very well hidden) but not too hard to find if you use your head. Some negative points worth noting:I used xbox 360 controller to play and sometimes found that using analog stick to perform certain actions might cause you to do the wrong move. This is really annoying when you try to do trials where time and precision is crucial. I failed so many times when my character jumped instead of ducking and sliding or vice versa. I do however recommend playing with a controller even though keyboard and mouse works great, controller is still better.You will probably want to play it once because once you know the story there will be no point in playing again so if you played on casual you are simply wasted your time because it was too easy and you can finish it in few hours. There are, however, 25 sidequestes which you can complete and you won't get all achievements unless you do them all.Difficulty curve is not ideal. On harcode mode is really hard to start that will cause you to die over and over until you reach some levels or keep killing same enemies over and over. Later on it when you level up and get some items it becomes too easy. Simply be patient and you will enjoy the game without any annoying issues.Overall it is great game that is worth your time. I spent over 30 hours and got all the achievements.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Simply enchanting.What makes a truly great game? Well, in my personal opinion, a great game isn't about showing off the best graphics or having mass appeal. A great game, to me anyway, is a true work of art and that's what I feel this particular one is. The visuals and soundtrack are two of the things I find to be the most remarkable about Dust: An Elysian Tail. Gazing into the vistas and listening to the BGM almost made me feel like I was playing one of my old all time favorite games ever. Legend of Mana. I felt that every track complimented each scene well and was enjoyable to even just stop and listen to for a moment without being too distracting at the same time.The movement and combat are fluid and easy to grasp. You rarely ever feel like the game is ever at fault for any mishaps. Combat is very fast paced and stylized like in Devil May Cry. It even has it's own little combo counter for those who like to show off their skills. And while your arsenal of attacks might feel a little limited, watching the protagonist soar back and forth across the screen in a whirlwind of blood and death never seems to get old. Level progression is also well balanced. I never felt like finding the newest upgrade for my equipment ever impacted the difficulty of the game too drastically or was ever essential for advancing in the story. Speaking of, the story isn't too bad either. The dialogue between the protagonist and the inhabitants of Falana(the in-game world) is humorous and well written, yet there have also been a couple parts that jerked a tear out of me too. As a bonus, throughout the entire game, you'll find lots of little references and easter eggs from other games dotted out through each map, if you're a big gamer of course.  It's also refreshing to play a game that doesn't require you to make some kind of moral decision at every turn for once. If there were anything at all I'd change about Dust, it would probably be the way the NPCs were animated. I just felt that the animations between the NPCS and protagonist clashed a little bit and while it's not a big detail, it certainly would have added some polish to an already amazing game.So if you've got some scratch to spare and enjoy games that are more art and less mass appeal, this one is definitely worth picking up.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												Dust is fantastic. A friend showed me the game long ago when it first came out, and I just recently got it for myself on this account. Getting to finally go through the game in full is awesome. The gameplay is simple, but still has plenty of flexibility between the swordplay and the magic. The art is fun, and the voice acting isn't so bad! Particularly the characters who 'matter'. Obviously many side characters don't have as much focus, but Dust, especially Fidget, Ahrah, and Haley are amazingly well voiced. And the many references are a lot of fun too.Did I mention Fidget is the best character ever? Because she is.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2016
												Dust: AET is quite possibly one of my favourite games of all time.  If not the number 1 spot.For me, the game blends beautiful visuals with a compelling storyline, with great characters, cracking gameplay, and one of the best soundtracks I've ever heard from an indie title to boot.It's not the longest game in the world, but you can stretch it if you love to get immersed and want to play it for all achievements (which, by design, will take a couple playthroughs anyway).  At times, the voicework is a little... wooden, but never really anything that will absolutely take you out of the story if you're having fun.I can't recommend it enough, huge props to Dean Dodrill for creating this work of art.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												This game as you can see is called Dust: An Elysian Tail... it didn't catch my attention. This game is about a blue fighter animal human named Dust with no memory of the past what so ever. His companions are a talking sword that guides Dust. His other companion is Fidget which is the flying orange Nimbat which is flying next to Dust in the screenshots. Also what really took my attention is the artwork and dialog. The artwork isn't like SUPER FANTASTIC ARTWORK THAT LOOKS REALISTIC, the artwork is nice bright and dark at the sametime. Me, as an artist in training and wanting to do an artistic job in the future, can see that this took some sort of work to make. Also it was made by an independant designer Dean Dodrill. Enough talking about the art. The dialog in this is good in my opinion. Not too much, not too little. I hate games with so much dialog but I also hate if I can't understand what is happening. The game is also a "furrie." What that means is that it as human-like animals. I never played games like these or watched anything like it, so it was an experience. (I don't see anything wrong with it.) The game is a side-scroller with RPG element. Those never were fun to me but Dust: An Elysian Tail was! 9/10 (Battle System made it not 10/10.)

content:
Posted: July 7, 2013
												So, where do I start... Possibly amongst the best games I've ever played in my entire life. It has some minor flaws, including a bug in the final boss fight which forces you to fight the boos all over again but other than that it's a masterpiece, a well polished PC port and a fine work of art. The soundtrack is relaxing and fits the game atmosphere very well. The combat is surprisingly satisfying, it combines brawling with hack and slash, in other words I can say that this is a Metroidvania ARPG Brawler. The combos are pretty good and the attack variety is somehow doesn't have alot of variety but it doesn't feel boring. The story is pretty great and overall that sells this game for me. I'm sure that pretty much anyone can enjoy this game and if you don't feel like paying full price for it, wait for a sale and then get it. I got it during a 50% sale but now I can safely say that the game is worth the full price, but this is only a matter of opinion. That said, please buy and play this, support the developer and MAYBE in the future there will be more games like this one.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												tl:dr - BUY IT.I'm a gamer for more than 15 years and this is one of my favorite games of all time.Graphics - Absolutely gorgeous. Music fits the graphics. Fighting system is simple but very enjoyable. It's fast, easy (From complexity standpoint) and visually appealing (everything explodes, shines, combos goes up to few hundrets). It's a metroidvania with a light RPG elements. Story is kinda generic, but it's satisfying, The only problem I had was how the characters looks like. Enemies looks relatively good, but NPC have that very cheap furry/cartoon style. I would rather like to see more "direct furry approach" or at least better quality of them  (shading, color pallete, more details, etc.). The only good looking NPC is Fidget (that flying cat/bat thingy... She's a Nimbat.). Characters are very good written. Oh, and Fidget is The Cutest character in video game I've ever seen. A want a plushie of her :3  (so I can keep her foreveeerrr....) 	 Anyway, Game took me about 13h to fully complete it, it's relatively hard on "hard difficulty", I haven't encountered any bugs or errors. I was playing it on Windows XP (Steam says it requires Vista/7). No slowdowns. In other words - Works good. Nothing much to say, really. It's a fantastic game, you should go and buy it. It's definitely worth your money.
