content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												The game overall is good, story is interesting, visuals are really pretty, and the combat is dynamic.However, as much as I like it, i can't help but be irritated by some parts of it.Note, that partially it comes from playing on hardcore (highest) difficulty.In multiple places things like jumps and drops (especially while climbing on vines), need to be done almost pixel-perfectly. I guess you could ignore that if you can simply retry, but a problem arises if when you fail, you end up on spikes or some other damage-inducing crap.Also, on vines you just never know how exactly will Dust jump, which in many cases means spikes to the face..Undeniably the most irritating part of the game for me was a piece of Cirromon Caverns around the middle bottom of the map.It consists of 2 tunnels filled with spikes that you have to jump over, with mushrooms between them, that spill damaging particles. The thing is, that these mushrooms work completely randomly, and they give you effectively no warning - technically they flash around 0.5s before they do something, but it barely gives you time to dodge- oh wait, i forgot that YOU'RE SURROUNDED WITH SPIKES SO YOU CAN'T EVEN DODGE. And there goes half of your hp.So there's no way to predict that they're gonna produce these particles, it's hard to dodge them, and even if you do, you end up on spikes. Of course, they're technically a part of the background, so you can't even 'kill' them.While it's not impossible, it's close to being it, if you need/want to do it while not getting hit even once. You just need luck, lots of it.Oh, for some reason, if you take damage by touching the fire, you bounce back few meters as if you took a ♥♥♥♥ing sledgehammer to the face. Yeah.When it comes to enemies, there are 2 that are a real pain:Demons, who will flank the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of you and instakill you from behind (yeah sure, you can dodge, right? but only so much, and then you die). Sometimes they will also jump on you with a spinning attack and kill you before you notice them. Thanks for great camerawork, game.Necromancers, which you can damage only with Fidget's projectiles that use up energy, which is also used to dodge Explosive Zombies spawned right in your face by these Necromancers, that explode after 0.5s and instakill you..This is some bad level design.Don't play on hardcore, kids.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												with simplistic graphics and combat, this game has become one of my absolute favorite Story-based games.  Although this game is hugely combat based (it could be argued that it is a brawler) the story is very well synced with that fact.  I absolutely LOVED the story, from start to finish.that aside, what really makes a game is what makes it fun, right?  so, yea..the combat.ohhhh the combat.MY GOD!  IS IT GOOD!This has got to be one of the best 2D combat engines ive ever had the pleasure to play with.  ESPECIALLY for an xbox to pc port game (its never this smooth).  although i find it hard to get into single weapon games, this one did it right by giving you a versatile arsenal of combos and manuevers that make even the cannon fodder fights really fun.  whats more important, though, is that the combat engine is SOOOOO responsive!  i can scarcely believe how much this indie title outclasses so many larger developer titles with its combat engine.IT IS PERFECT.there is plently of room for petty personal complaint, but as far as pure, solid fact goes, the combat in this game does EXACTLY what it's supposed to.  there are zero bugs with it.What I truly love about this game, though; aside from the entrancing story line and exciting combat, is the art.  and take that word loosely, because im talking the whole spectrum.  The animation for character and level design is beautifully done!  The music is absolutely breathtaking!  this game itself, is a work of art as far as videogames go.  It was created and brought to life by one man over 4 years, and you can easily see the passion and talent in his work.this game is much like the older castlevania and metroid games (metrovania?), and in my personal oppinion, if it had been released in that generation (give some modesty to the graphics and sound qualitly, of course) it would have been an instant classic.  There is no circumstance in which i can justify not telling you to buy this game at its current price of $15.  i would easily pay twice that price for a game of this quality.One of the best, most fun games ive played in recent years.

Posted: May 28, 2013
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is an action side-scrolling platformer game with a very fluid combo system and well animated attacks, giving the player a sense of simply being awesome in combat. I've played a lot of games, but nothing is quite as unique as Dust. The game gives the player the ability to move freely throughout the world, going to whichever areas they so desire to rack-up XP, explore or find hidden secrets in past levels. The story in Dust is one surrounded by mystery, the protagonist, Dust, starts off with amnesia and cannot recollect a damn thing about his past, which I know is very cliche but it suits Dust's story just fine. The protagonist is alway accompanied by a cat-ferret-bat creature by the name of Fidget (who is also the cutest damn thing I've seen since Tali in Mass Effect), who offers humorous dialogue and grants the player a ranged attack. To clarify: I f*cking love Fidget.Dust's combat system flows beautifully, utilizing a mere three buttons for attacks, the combat is simple but at the same time awe inspiring, easy to pick up on and very well made, when the player whipes out his/her first batch of enemies you immediately feel like an incredible badass and leaves you itching for more. As the game proceeds you acquire new abilities that complement your already formidible attack options and keep the game from getting stale, all the while maintaining a steady difficulty curve alongside an easy to understand XP and level-up system.Graphics-wise: It's an indy game, you don't come into it expecting mind-blowing graphics. Dust uses a simple but lovable anthropomorphic cartoon art-style that is both charming and outright adorable, but also dark and serious when it needs to be. All perfected with an amazing musical score and top quality voice acting. As well, Dust makes numerous quips at the expense of the fourth wall and makes references to other games, like Resident Evil 4 and Castlevania. The one flaw I've seen thus far is a somewhat finicky platform system. Sometimes if you don't land on a platform at exactly the right angle you're going through, which in a platformer game is a real kick to the groin.In conclusion: Dust: An Elysian Tail is fun, fluid, and highly addictive. I definitely recommend anyone reading this to pick it up immediately.

												I really don't know where to begin. I Initially bought this game because i loved the art (I'm a Graphic Designer =P), but i stayed for the gameplay. Posted: February 26, 2014
												Dust provides a gameplay experience much like any other in its genre.  The control feel (I used gamepad) is fluid and easy to pick up.  The brawling mechanism is redundant at times, particularly when you are grinding to push yourself one more level on the tougher difficulties.  Animation in this game is truly something that kept me in it for the long haul.  The soundtrack is good enough that you don't really give it a second thought while playing, however its not the best by any means.  Characters in this game are likable (even more so if you are a fan of furries) however the story felt lacking in my opinion.  Slight changes here and there could have made this an extraordinarily memorable experience however without them I am left after two full playthroughs (120% completion) simply satisfied.  Great game if you can get it on sale or in a bundle.  There are some fairly interesting side plots to occupy time and for the purpose of extending game run time and this game has a tendency to give major throwbacks to old school gaming that always put a smile on my face.  I definitely recommend playing it through at least once to anyone who is in to this sort of metroid-esque game.

												With a generally robust combat system, Dust has a lot to offer moreso than other games in the genre. Posted: January 14, 2014
												I was shocked, SHOCKED at how much fun this game was. It's not terribly difficult, but it is fantastically fun. It has some backtracking for loot, similar to Metroid, which is cool, although I know that a lot of nerds want to cry bloody murder whenever this happens, it's not TOO bad. Honestly guys? Why do you hate that so much? Either way, if you felt that backtracking is the unholy spawn of Satan himself, the game doesn't present itself with enough difficulty to actually HAVE to do it... If you wanted to like, make a political statement or something. Combat is fast and frantic, and presents itself with enough options to keep stuff interesting. One thing I found is that nearly EVERY strategy is a good one to accomplish monster murder, except not fighting, that is a terrible strategy. The story isn't going to win any Oscars, but its good enough to keep you interested, the voice acting is good as well, Figet is legitimately funny with her 4th wall jokes, so bonus. I only got stuck in a wall once, and that's the only technical problem I ever ran into, it was near the end of the game, so it already had me in it's smoothly animated clutches and I didn't mind too much. The game saves a lot, so if you ever ran into a bug it's unlikely that you would throw your beverage at your pets and start crying in the fetal position in your neighbors crawlspace or anything. For people who like bullets: -FUN-BUY-PLAY-YAYCheck out my youtube channel for a laugh (probably at my expense, but that's okay, sniffle) the link is in my profile.

Posted: March 28, 2014
												Have no fear, this game is completly abstinent! But I think that's to be expected from a game rated E 10+!Dust is an action, platforming, RPG. The sole mechanic is the "Dust Storm", a special move that lets you glide through the air and attack enemies. This move assists in combat as well as platforming.The game's level design is split up so that you are platforming half the time, and the other half you are mowing down bad guys. It is unfortunate that there are only two distinct moments when you are doing both at the same time, and I would have appreciated more moments that combined combat and platforming.Many areas are blocked off at the beginning of the game until you unlock the special ability that lets bypass the specific obstacle blocking your way. These blocked off areas don't conceal anything super special, but I find a lot of joy exploring the map trying to find all the hidden chests.The story is well written and well executed, and kept me engaged the entire time. There were certain sad moments that didn't effect me that much, but the chills I got at the cutscene before the final boss made up for that! There were countless jokes thrown in along the way that made me laugh!Overall, I think the game was a pleasent expierence and I would strongly recommend it!

Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game is one of those argument-ending 'Name one' games."Games aren't artistic! Name one!""PC ports are impossible, and they'll always be faulty. Name one that wasn't!""Actio brawlers can't have major plot twists! Name one!""Comic relief sidekicks are such a pain. Name one time that they did that right."Well... this is that kind of game, yes. The controls are smooth, the voice acting is gorgeous, the soundtrack deserves to be called 'epic,' even the scenery is chewing the scenery, and as for the story? It's the kind of story where you think you know what the twist is going to be early on, but then they throw a curve ball at you and do something pretty unexpected, even unique. All three of the main characters (yes, the sword is a character) are at least interesting, Fidget is downright brilliant on so many levels, and even the shopkeeper has a story. Yeah, not even kidding. The freaking SHOPKEEPER has a story, and it's not even a bad one. Probably best played with a controller, because there were instances where I struggled because I forgot you could jump diagonally by holding two keys at once (eheh...) but perfectly serviceable with mouse and keyboard, and its options menu is spot-on. There are features that you wouldn't think even existed. This game is a classic. It's iconic. And the controls are simple enough for someone new to games to pick up. Basically, in the spirit of the season, it's a good game for gamers and it's a good experience for non-gamers. All the beauty and heart of a Disney classic mixed with the action of a Nintendo classic. Definitely worth a look.

												Absolutely phenominal. Posted: March 1, 2014
												To start of, the art-style and art-design are extremely beautiful, giving a lot of life to the game. The characters are also very likeable, well written and have good voice-acting. The plot of the game while well written doesn't really do anything too new but the world itself is so deep that it's still very easy to get sucked into the world. You can't talk about this game without mentioning the music. It's extremely well composed and memorable. I'd even say it's worth picking up the soundtrack so you can listen to it whenever you want.As for the gameplay, it's basically a metroidvania, with a lot of the mechanics you would expect from such a game. Something it doesn't have is multiple types weapons but instead a lot of effort was put into the combat to make it more enjoyable. While you don't have that many combos you can perform, you can easily go from one to the next, making the combat really fluent.The only real negative I have is that the ending didn't give a real closure to the characters and ending a game on a low note isn't something you want since that's what the player will remember the most. Still, there's too much to experience from this game for the ending to bring it down.

Posted: January 5, 2016
												What can I say that hasn't already been said a bunch of times:  Just get the damn game!!!!!  Dust is what a fun 2D platformer is all about.1)  It has a story.  It doesn't break new grounds, but most games don't.  With that said, it is told not only well, but at the right pace.  It doesn't drag, nor does it race along.  It has a well though out plot, and an ending that will stay with you.2)  It makes you explore.  It isn't the most complicated map, but it has enough visit and revisit spots to keep those of us that like to find everything happy.   There are several spots on map and moving to and fro is quick and painless.  The places themselves get progressively more difficult to initially spot where hidden treasures are, but not mean spiritied or impossible like some games I could name.3)  Voice acting.  It doesn't stand out at all and from me that is the greatest compliment.  I can't stand VA that is so over the top, or the opposite that is just so god awful that you want to turn the sound  off and read subtitles.  The VA meshes perfectly with the story.4)  Artwork.  It is a nice blend of cartoonish hand painted with effects mesh.  It is also a perfect fit for the feel of the game.5)  Combat.  Combat is easy to as hard as you wat to make it with the different combos, but definitely forgiving.  It's not meant to be a brutal test, but it offers enough of a challenge to be satisfying.6)  Fun Factor.  So many platformers have zero replayability, especially story driven ones.  You finish and move on.  I played, replayed because I missed a couple of achievements, and then played again just to enjoy.  This is a game that will stay in your library as an old friend that you will just have to re-visit every once in a while.Overall, I would say if you are looking for a hard game to challenge you this is not the one.  If you are looking for an absolute joy of an experience do not pass up this game.  I can't wait to see what's next from the dev's!!!!!  Cheers!

Posted: December 28, 2015
												Forget "for the price tag" or "for an indie game", Dust: An Elysian Tail is an amazing experience which really reignited a passion for gaming that I wasn't sure if I had any more.This is not an 'artsy' game, although it does sport some of the best artistic direction that I've ever seen in a videogame, accompanied by a brilliant soundtrack. The story and characters, whilst kept behind gameplay in priority, are likeable and easy to follow. A few inconsistancies here and there, but an enjoyable experience with enough sidequests and secrets to keep you playing for 20 hours, easily.The mechanics are tight -- if you die, most of the time you're going to feel like it was your fault rather than the game cheesing you out of a death. I only played on hardcore mode, because I found the difficulty on this level was at the perfect point between challenging and tedious. One of my few gripes about the game is that the save spots could have been more considerately placed. I often found that after dying, I was re-doing tedious but simple parts of the game. The save spots should be after the tedious but simple parts, not before them. I want to re-do the part I died on, not the three screens before it (here's to you, Sorrowing Meadows).I did run into two possibly Linux-only issues, one was some sound distortion in certain areas of the game which required me to reduce the volume, and another was an issue with one of the secret rooms not displaying correctly. I e-mailed the developer about the latter issue and within an hour, had a response saying it is being looked into this week.The game's difficulty curve is brilliant, introducing new concepts and abilities as the game goes on so as not to overload the player with one of those half-hour tutorials which most of us skip. The first area is easy, and the final boss will challenge all of your mechanical abilities. I suggest starting on the highest difficulty level and working your way down if it's not enjoyable, it feels like Dust was designed to be played on hardcore.There is plenty of endgame content, as I'm finding with over 20 hours played that I still find things to do and treasures I haven't found yet. I have thoroughly enjoyed this game, and struggle to recall the last time I had this much fun playing a videogame.Thank you, Humble Hearts. I look forward to the next one.

Posted: December 26, 2015
												Nothing much to addThe game is a marvelous piece of art. Although the storyline is relatively straightforward and perhaps predictable, its gameplay makes it up for it. As a Metroidvania, you are continuously being challenged of revisting areas once you have unlocked new skills. However, this doesn't mean you can't try it without acquiring the skills. The majority of hidden secrets and/or treasures in each level is designed that it can be visited when not having the right skill. Having the right skill does make it easier on the other hand, but less of a challenge. Had enough of visiting areas? You can always try to think of practicing your skills by chaining your combos. Besides its gameplay, the soundtrack is extremely well done. Each piece of music fits the moment making it a great enjoyment for the ears when walking through the same area again due to backtracking.However, the game does suffer from a couple of small glitches. Interaction windows popping up while being far away from the shops or savepoints and in battle does hamper the game a bit. While not necessarily gamebreaking, it might be experienced as a nuisance when trying to chain a combo hit.Conclusion:For a game that has been written, programmed and drawn by one single person is an amazing feature. Even more amazing is that all elements in the game fit perfectly together: the gameplay and the OST are very well thought and executed. However, it doesn't mean the game doesn't suffer from some minor glitches. Interaction windows that unexpectedly pop up might be a bit annoying, but are not necessarily gamebreaking.Pro:+ Great OST+ Amazing art work+ Challenging gameplay: difficulty can be adjusted when necesary+ Good level design: majority of the secrets can be reached early in game for a bigger challenge. Having the adequate skill later in game facilitates reaching these secretsCons:- Game suffers from minor glitches at times- Storyline is a bit predictable

Posted: March 28, 2014
												Have no fear, this game is completly abstinent! But I think that's to be expected from a game rated E 10+!Dust is an action, platforming, RPG. The sole mechanic is the "Dust Storm", a special move that lets you glide through the air and attack enemies. This move assists in combat as well as platforming.The game's level design is split up so that you are platforming half the time, and the other half you are mowing down bad guys. It is unfortunate that there are only two distinct moments when you are doing both at the same time, and I would have appreciated more moments that combined combat and platforming.Many areas are blocked off at the beginning of the game until you unlock the special ability that lets bypass the specific obstacle blocking your way. These blocked off areas don't conceal anything super special, but I find a lot of joy exploring the map trying to find all the hidden chests.The story is well written and well executed, and kept me engaged the entire time. There were certain sad moments that didn't effect me that much, but the chills I got at the cutscene before the final boss made up for that! There were countless jokes thrown in along the way that made me laugh!Overall, I think the game was a pleasent expierence and I would strongly recommend it!

Posted: June 26, 2016
												For a long time, I had dismissed Dust as mere "furry" bait. An unfair judgement, I know. Anyways, I finally gave it a try because Hardcore Gaming 101 had the game in their "200 Best Video Games of All Time" book. Notably, they recommended Dust over Muramasa, a game I also really love. I'm really glad I ended up giving Dust a try because it ended up being one of the most enjoyable ARPGs I've played in a while. The story was engaging (and surprisingly even moving), the combat was satisfying and the entire thing is damn gorgeous. The only problem I have with the game is that I actually really suck at these combo-centric type ARPGs. The last boss battle destroyed me and eventually I had to lower the difficulty to finish the game. I hope to return to the game on a higher difficulty though and actually properly learn the combat systems. Anyhow, I don't know if I can praise Dean Dodrill enough, because what he made is genius.

Posted: November 24, 2016
												This game is one of those argument-ending 'Name one' games."Games aren't artistic! Name one!""PC ports are impossible, and they'll always be faulty. Name one that wasn't!""Actio brawlers can't have major plot twists! Name one!""Comic relief sidekicks are such a pain. Name one time that they did that right."Well... this is that kind of game, yes. The controls are smooth, the voice acting is gorgeous, the soundtrack deserves to be called 'epic,' even the scenery is chewing the scenery, and as for the story? It's the kind of story where you think you know what the twist is going to be early on, but then they throw a curve ball at you and do something pretty unexpected, even unique. All three of the main characters (yes, the sword is a character) are at least interesting, Fidget is downright brilliant on so many levels, and even the shopkeeper has a story. Yeah, not even kidding. The freaking SHOPKEEPER has a story, and it's not even a bad one. Probably best played with a controller, because there were instances where I struggled because I forgot you could jump diagonally by holding two keys at once (eheh...) but perfectly serviceable with mouse and keyboard, and its options menu is spot-on. There are features that you wouldn't think even existed. This game is a classic. It's iconic. And the controls are simple enough for someone new to games to pick up. Basically, in the spirit of the season, it's a good game for gamers and it's a good experience for non-gamers. All the beauty and heart of a Disney classic mixed with the action of a Nintendo classic. Definitely worth a look.

Posted: February 21, 2014
												To start off, I liked this game a lot, it had interesting gameplay and story. Graphics 5/5The graphics works really well with the environment that the story and characters were trying to portray. Each area looked beautiful with its paint style graphics. Also for the most part each area had something different to offer in the way of environment. Story 4/5I was extremely interested in the story. The story was pretty dynamic for how short it was. The main part of the story is Dust trying to figure out his mysterious past while he essentially helps people in need. Stories like this has definitely been done before, but for some reason Dust's story catched my interest a lot more then some others. With this said, the story left a lot of questions unanswered. For example, what was the background story for General Gaius? The story painted an interesting picture for General Gaius, but by the end, they just left General Gaius as the main Antagonist with very little explanation of why he did what he did. Also, the story could have gone two different ways. I think there could have been a possibility for two endings based off your choices. This could have made the story a little bit more interesting. Gameplay 4.5/5The gameplay was fun and rarely got boring. The game was a mix of 2d platform, rpg and action. You gain experience by defeating enemies and gain bonus experience depending on how high of a combo you can achieve. When you gain a level you are able to put one gem like stat point into one of the provided stats. Although levels were important it was mostly the abilities that you gained through the game that helped you the most in battle. The abilities you gained also looked extremely cool. At one point you were able to gain a fireball ability and if combined with Dust storm you were able to light most of the screen on fire torching your foes. With the right timing you were able to get a 1000 hit combo or more which was also very fun to watch and pull off. There were also many collectibles to keep you interested as well as challenge courses. I found the challenge courses difficult enough to get me angry after the 20th attempt which was fun but also a painful experience. The cameo characters were fun and sometimes difficult to find as well. These collectibles and challenges were not needed, but was a fun diversion from the main storyline. For the most part the gameplay was very well thought out but there were a few issues that I had with the gameplay. The combat was fun but did get repetitive at times. I feel like there needed to be more variety of skills to use, to keep the game from getting boring. The issue of repetitiveness was some what remedied by the shortness of the game, but I feel if the game went any longer I would have gotten very bored with the combat. Also near the end of the game I felt like I was overpowered. This may not be an issue with the game though considering I was probably overleveling while I was trying to get all the collectibles and finishing all the challenges. Sound/Music   5/5Nothing much to say here. The music and sound effects made sense for the environments and situations. The music sounded very good as well. Replayability 2/5Im trying to replay the game on a harder difficulty for the last few achievements but I find myself to lack the motivation to finish the game for the second time. There really isnt any thing different if you play it a second time besides the possibility to obtain some achievements and playing a more difficult setting. So a game plus option would have been nice or maybe a secret chapter where you can play as General Gaius and so on. Overall this game was amazing and well worth the money.

Posted: February 18
												This game is superb. If you are looking for a great indie 2D action platformer, this is a game to get. The game mixes level-by-level gameplay of older side scrolling games with secret hunting and exploration of a metroidvania.  Fuse that with a combo system that actively rewards the player with bonus XP for playing skillfully and you have one amazingly fun action-platform-metroidvania-brawler-whatever-it-is-but-who-cares-it's-great. The first thing that will hit you is the amazing hand-drawn art and animations. This is an absolutely beautiful game to behold. The voice acting is a bit spotty at times but overall, well executed. The bomb sprout puzzles are a bit tedious but so satisfying when you solve them, bosses were way too easy but still fun none the less, some of the diolague can be excized as it outright tells you a puzzle solution, but it doesn't handhold so often that it becomes patronizing, and the ester eggs are just adorable. I haven't found half of the secrets this game holds, so there's still a lot of stuff left for me to do. But, I did complete the story; I will not spoil the ending but I will say it is an ending that leaves lots of mixed emotions, but in a good way. TL;DR the game isn't perfect, but no game is. This is the most fun I had in a 2D game since Castlevania: Symphony of the Night. Some nitpicks here and there but those could be attributed to the fact that the development team was one person, and a multi-man team could have made more mistakes than fixed them. Overall, this game is a 9/10, one of my favorites, and it definately deserves the overwhelmingly positive reception it gets.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Gameplaywise, it's straightforward : you have one sword and learn several moves throughout the game. I thought this would limit the gameplay, making it boring at some point, but it didn't. The game is relatively short if you decide to do the campaign only, and becomes longer if you decide to do the subquest. You can find equipment to upgrade your sword & be more competitive in fights. The game itself is really easy, if you wish for a challenge, directly jump to the hardcore difficulty, where you really die easily if you gets hit (my advice : don't try to speedrun it, use combos & dodge as much as possible).Graphically : it's a cel-shaded style plat-former, who really take inspiration into Don Bluth's An American Tail animated movie in terms of artstyle (they even made the same pun). At first I thought it would be a problem since I'm really not a fan of the furry genre (due to what the Internet did to it, mostly) but it really only took inspiration in the Don Bluth movie style and never try to sexualize the characters like you can see many games do whenever they try to add androgynous animal characters. So yeah, I really felt I was watching an old animated movie, with the same kind of message Don Bluth himself would be able to convey (about war, destruction of nature, etc...)The story is cute, it's nothing great but it's very cute, very well acted, and I appreciate the voice actors' effort in the play.One big plus for this game is the music : the music is absolutely fantastic, and one of my favourite soundtrack in videogame's history. Not even kidding.It's charming, it's fun, it's pretty. The music is beautiful.It is a wonderful tail... I mean tale.

Posted: July 20, 2016
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a wonderful experience of a Side Scrolling Hack N' Slash game, and I'm here to tell you why.The game starts off with you playing as Dust, a... furry (?) who woke up in the middle of the forests who dealt with amnesia, and is awfully confused on whom he is, and is confronted by Fidget the Nimbat, and Ahrah the Sword. You set out on a perilious journey to discover Dust's past and face all kinds of wicked monsters across the world.The game features extremely satisfying and smooth combat despite it being limited to 2D, yet, it plays so well.The game's combo system works by pressing two buttons, one for slashing, and another for extra combos. You gain new abilities, most likely to help you in enemy confrontrations when you play more of the game.The game world is absolutely lovely and beautiful to look at, as well as the scenery you come across. It is quite expansive, as you head out to new areas to explore the world.The combat can sometimes get repetitive and tiring after a while, as the fight mechanics do not change, but the game can make up for this with it's wonderful speed and fluent style of gameplay, that happens so quickly. It is very awesome.The difficulty is not in any way lacking, unless if you have mastered the combat to the extreme, as it allows you to pick which difficulty you would prefer, easy, moderate, or hard.Sent on:3:02 pmThere are many characters and side quests to tackle on if you do not want to try and finish the main game's storyline, as they give you time to explore the world for secrets, treasures, and quests to start on your own time.It features a nice quick leveling up system, that once you've gained enough experience points, you can choose a stat you'd like to improve, as it keeps the game extremely fresh and impressive.The game allows you to craft new items to your liking that has stats you'd generally prefer to have and use, such as armor, sword buffs, pendents, rings, etc.Dust An Elysian Tail may seem short to some who've played and decided to go on a quick speed-through, but it is a fun experience nevertheless and I suggest buying at full price to support the developer 100%, since a lot of love andeffort to making this game. Kudos.HOPING SEQUEL COMES OUT IN THE FUTURE! MUAAAAAAH!

Posted: October 23, 2013
												Dust is a side scrolling RPG action platformer with surprisingly good aspects for an indie game. You play as Dust, a character weilding an ancient blade while suffering from memory loss. Although the idea has been used many times before, it carries out well for the story. The story itself is unique and I myself enjoyed wondering what could possibly occer next. The envierments range from forests to graveyards, snowy peaks to volcanic regions, all of which vividly colored and highly detailed. The animations for each character are smooth and the character models are great. Each NPC has an interesting personallity that defines them and I must applaud the voice acters for such a wonderful job. The humor is good enough to make me laugh a little, which gives a few lighthearted spots in the middle of all this seriousness. At times, the game will even break the forth wall, such as pointing out how you can pick up a sheep and store it in your inventory. The ending doesn't disappoint and personally left me a bit shaky. The downside of this game is, it's short. I clocked in at 12.2 hours after beating the game and that's doing the main quest, plus some side quests, plus screwing around. However, it's well worth the experiance of playing such an original game.My final rating: 8/10It's a fantasticly done game with little to no glitches and great storyline, however it is short.

Posted: May 30, 2013
												It is rare to see a game like this be this well done. Dust: An Elysian Tail was made by one man, and the game has the quality of that you see with teams of hundreds working passionately on a project.The game itself is a 2D Sidescroller inspired heavily by games like Metroid and Castlevania. You will find yourself exploring a fairly large open world, looking for items, money, and powers which will allow you to explore areas that were locked to you before. The aesthetic style of this game is truly amazing as well. The use of varied colors really helps the world and its residents come to life in ways rarely seen in games today. I would find myself staying in areas long after I should have left just look at the visuals and marvel at how breathtaking the vistas are. While it is cartoony, it serves the game very well. I would also travel the long way through areas, ignoring shortcuts I had opened, just to listen to the music. The music in this game is nothing short of spectacular, with each area having its own theme that sets it apart from the others, whether it be a mountain pass that screams for adventure, or the haunted remains of an old estate with creeping terrors around every turn, the music sets the tone and atmosphere for each area very well.The combat in this game is a blast to play as well. You will find yourself slicing your way through hordes of monsters, with a small but very versatile moveset that never gets old. It is actually possible to have a fight last upwards of a minute, without ever touching the ground.Another point about the world of this game that I wish more games outside The Elder Scrolls series would use is the use of anthropomorphic animals. All of the characters are some kind of anthro-morph, whether it is a fox, rabbit, mouse, lizard and many others. I really enjoy this kind of thing, and it really helps the game stand out on its own, instead of falling into the tired fantasy traps of the overused elves, dwarves, orcs, and so on, which have been used to the point of being a checkbox for fantasy.In terms of story, this game is a marvel. The plot is surprisingly mature despite the E10+ rating, and makes a lot of "Mature" rated games look childish and infantile, and should last you around 11 hours depending on how many side-quests you do. I found myself genuinely caring for a lot of the characters in this game, while eagerly anticipating advancing the plot just to find out what happened next. During the story's darker points I was even moved to tears, which does not happen very often.For $15, you get a game that does everything right, and will stick with you long after you have beaten it.

Posted: July 8, 2016
												Dust: An Eylsian TailGenre : MetroidvaniaRating: 9/10Comment : Wonderful world, marvellous characters, great story and good gameplayDust: An Elysian Tail is one my all time favourite games. Gameplay wise it follows the standard metroidvania rules. As you start the game a lot of areas are unreachable for you but as you progress you learn new abilites with which you can reach those regions later on. The game also has two rpg elements. For one it has a leveling system. Unfortunately it is very simple and doesn't allow for a real specialization. For another it has items that you can equip. The combats are fast and fun to play but in the long run they lack complexity too. Nevertheless the fights and the rpg elements were good enough to keep me motivated. But what makes this game that good for me?It's the world, the story and espcecially the characters. The main characters (Dust and Fidget) are simply amazing. The writing and the voice acting are superb in my opionion. Anyway I don't want to spoil anyhting from the story so just watch the trailer and decide yourself whether you like what you see. I myself can only recommend the game and I hope a sequel will soon be released.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												Dust has a beautiful background and badly drawn characters. The characters are also vaguely to highly annoying. Luckily, the main character isn't bad, but your "companion" is almost as annoying as Navi. If you're lucky, you can read fast and skip over the voice acting/bad dialogue writing. The story is also subpar and fairly predictable.But, then you may wonder why I've played this game for 14 hours (as of writing this review.) Well, that's because the game play is just fun. It's not quite a beat 'em up but there are small hoardes of weak characters with some stronger ones thrown in (not counting the bosses.) There is a hit-combo tracker in the top corner of your screen and a minor quest, plus the steam achievements drive you to really try to continuously hit as many times as possible. It's not simple. It also contains moves that are done using certain button pressing and joystick controls in a row or in combination. Beyond that, it contains "metroid-vania" skills that give you access to new areas, further parts of the story, and treasure you missed when first going through areas. There are side quests and the ability to buy or make armor/rings/weapon-improving items. There are definitely some things that I just would rather not deal with with this game, but it's all in the cut scenes/story which is not a huge part of the actual gameplay which is good, because the game play is fun and continuously makes me want to move forward in the game. (Except for the very beginning which I played maybe a half hour of, and then didn't pick up the game for several months.)I'd recommend getting it if it is on sale for cheap because it's fun, but it's not really all that original, and it's not all that polished.Additional note: I cannot speak to how the game plays with a keyboard&mouse or just a keyboard (both options). I played this game using an Xbox remote as it seemed to be easier on my fingers since there is a lot of action-button pressing and thumbs do that better than fingers.

Posted: June 30, 2014
												Dust defines itself very well in action platformer genre with a mix of RPG element. It's battle mechanic let you freely perform a mix of ground combats, aerial combats, and magics to built up combo counter for better bonus exp and bonus item drops. Every level up grants you a point to increase one of the four stat category (HP, Attack, Defend, and Magic). This game also offer you sidequests to explore in each regions for hidden items, bonus, blueprint (to crafting accessory), and lot of references from other games. Most regions on the world map in this game are big and has a lot of room to explore.Personally, I am really enjoy Dust as for it's RPG element and lot of contents to explor in each regions in the game. All hidden chests in this game are not really well hidden though, the game rather focus to challenge your skill of a platformer than a puzzle skill; making this game quite enjoyable and enthertain to most audiences. Also, most hidden chests contain several kinds of materials and blueprints, a solid rewards of exploration in this game is to finding these blueprints which most likely to grant you access to a better gear quickly.There are two big flaws in this game, one fall in a repeatitive battle mechanics and one fall in a flat story. Player will get access to several new items and new magic while advancing the main quest, however, none of them significantly affect the play style. You will fall back to performing a usaul mix of ground, aerial, and magic all the entire game. Enemies in this game may receives a uniques identity in each regions (each chapters) but all of them mostly fall to the same three major types consist of Normal size, Big size, and Flying type; the strategy to fight off these three types throughout the game are the same, offer not much of a challenge to the player when accessing to a new area (except for higher HP and higher damage). I also found another disappointment in it's story. If you only focus on the movement of main story and main protagonist then you may find an enjoyment to some extent, but it is very sad that other major characters received no solid background and being rendered as pure good and pure evil with no clear reason; making the story simply not very interesting, at least to me. Also, at first the game seem like to grant player a freedom to make his own decision that could affect other characters (this option even significantly apply to one of the sidequests) but that's that. This freedom simply disappear in the later of the game.The final word is I really love this game. A metroidvania gamer like myself may find the most comfort in this game from exploration, it is simply fun to explore chests, get blueprints, and farming for materials. The amount of sidequests throughout the game are not much but, at least, acceptable. Even though the combat mechanic is quit repeatitive, it is still fun to roaming around the field with what the game has to offers. Also, Dust was actually released in 2012 so it is assumable for the game to receives a huge discount at this time. I recommend this is a good Action/platformer game you should at least try with no worry about it's prices when compare to all contents you will find in the game.

												A short, but likeable game, Dust provides enough story to keep you interested, and gameplay fast and responsive enough to keep you engaged. At times the writing can get a bit threadbare, but there are some refreshing points, particularly the main antagonist. The voice acting is very good, and while the idea of a tiny comedic sidekick can be a cliché, Dust's answer is well rendered, actually useful, entertaining, and, perhaps most importantly, avoids being annoying.Yes, the writing could have gone leagues deeper, and I hate to say it, but I was less than thrilled with the ending. 												A game with a beautiful soundtrack, a lovely art-style, captivating characters, a unique story, ridiculously fun gameplay, deep character progression, great mechanics, and genious level design. I'm the kind of person who likes to seek out everything that is wrong with a game and then complain about it, because I believe it helps improve the specific game, as well as the industry in general, however, there are so very few things wrong with Dust that I shouldn't even mention them, really. Posted: February 15, 2014
												with simplistic graphics and combat, this game has become one of my absolute favorite Story-based games.  Although this game is hugely combat based (it could be argued that it is a brawler) the story is very well synced with that fact.  I absolutely LOVED the story, from start to finish.that aside, what really makes a game is what makes it fun, right?  so, yea..the combat.ohhhh the combat.MY GOD!  IS IT GOOD!This has got to be one of the best 2D combat engines ive ever had the pleasure to play with.  ESPECIALLY for an xbox to pc port game (its never this smooth).  although i find it hard to get into single weapon games, this one did it right by giving you a versatile arsenal of combos and manuevers that make even the cannon fodder fights really fun.  whats more important, though, is that the combat engine is SOOOOO responsive!  i can scarcely believe how much this indie title outclasses so many larger developer titles with its combat engine.IT IS PERFECT.there is plently of room for petty personal complaint, but as far as pure, solid fact goes, the combat in this game does EXACTLY what it's supposed to.  there are zero bugs with it.What I truly love about this game, though; aside from the entrancing story line and exciting combat, is the art.  and take that word loosely, because im talking the whole spectrum.  The animation for character and level design is beautifully done!  The music is absolutely breathtaking!  this game itself, is a work of art as far as videogames go.  It was created and brought to life by one man over 4 years, and you can easily see the passion and talent in his work.this game is much like the older castlevania and metroid games (metrovania?), and in my personal oppinion, if it had been released in that generation (give some modesty to the graphics and sound qualitly, of course) it would have been an instant classic.  There is no circumstance in which i can justify not telling you to buy this game at its current price of $15.  i would easily pay twice that price for a game of this quality.One of the best, most fun games ive played in recent years.

Posted: September 27, 2015
												One word to describe it? Mindblown.The moment I saw the screenshots and trailer for this game, I knew this game could be something special and I was ABSOLUTELY RIGHT! To put it simply:1. Story? Great story that both young and old audiences can enjoy.2. Characters? Very lovable characters (expect for the obvious "bad" guys lol) and I really like that most of them had "side quests" when talking to them and not just have them standing there, talking to you once and never hear from them again. I found myself revisiting a lot of them frequently, solving their issues as well as being rewarded for completing those side quests. Definitely love this approach!3. Graphics? Simply BEAUTIFUL/GORGIOUS WORLD with stunning views in almost all areas. While admittedly it took me some time to adapt to it (especially while running and fighting enemies), I got adapted to it rather quickly and have thoroughly enjoyed every level I played not just for the story/fights but also for observing the surrounding beautiful landscapes as well.4. Music? Absolutely brilliant! The music was calming at times, intense at other times, but it was always fitting to the scene and really helped get me totally "immersed" in the atmosphere of this great game!5. Fighting? Very fluid and you get more abilities (as well as power-ups for your companion "Fidget") as you progress so that you can revisit old areas and unlock hidden chests in areas that you weren't able to reach previously. Though, my ONLY "criticism" of this entire game is that, while you get new abilities/power-ups, you do NOT get any "new combos" as you progress, meaning you are stuck doing the SAME combos over and over again from start to the end of this game. So as a note to developers, for future similar games, please add more new combos to decrease the "repetitiveness" of killing the enemies with the same old combos over and over again.Nonetheless, the one criticism above does NOT have any major impact on my enjoyment of this game. Definitely a "must-buy" for those who enjoy stories that are told in an old style "cartoony" fashion with FULL VOICE ACTING for all dialogues as well as those who just enjoy side-scrolling fighting games in general.Final Rating: 10/10. (And hoping for a FUTURE SEQUEL to this game as well! :D)

Posted: October 4, 2015
												I picked this up on a whim when it was on sale for a couple bucks. I don't generally do side-scrollers, but the reviews got me wondering. Well, I officially LOVE this game. There are bits and pieces of various themes in literature and gaming throughout, many done so well, you might not catch them at first. Even the main character, Dust, has elements of the main character in the story Total Recall. Trust me, that's not giving anything away you won't guess in the first 20 min of the game... and it's nowhere near the whole story.The writing, controls, action, and level designs are well thought-out and implemented. Some of the "twists" really aren't and some are quite well done. In terms of gameplay, I've always liked the more intricate-but-not-overwhelming type of combat system used here. There aren't many combos, but with what there is, there's enough strategy between enemies that simply button-mashing won't get you through the entire game and it doesn't really get old... just comfortable. While made with a controller in mind, I finished the game just fine with a keyboard and mouse.While you can get most of the achievements with the first play-through, the achievement system within the game rewards you for geting them again on each play-through. There's only one that has a proper choice (two achievements, but you can only get one of the two on any given play-through) and the obligatory "beat the game on (higher difficulty)". I also though the additional challenge areas were a nice touch. I've only managed to get 4 stars on ONE of them so far.The animation is a bit clunky during the full-animation cut-scenes (of which there are only about 3 in the whole game), but the voice acting is spot-on and every character, no matter how small their part, has a distinct personality and not just some generic NPC plant with random sayings.I don't know if they plan to do another (I haven't looked that up yet), but I'd be on-board for a sequel, or at least a follow-up in the same universe. There's a lot they can still do with it, I think. But then, it's like finishing a good book; you really don't want it to be over. That was me after playing Bastion, after all...TL;DR version:Great game. If you have ANY enjoyment of story-driven action-adventure games, then: GET IT. PLAY IT. LOVE IT.

Posted: December 26, 2013
												Picked this game up on the recommendation of a few friends; have to say it was worth it. The graphics look stunning for a game made almost entirely by one person. The colors are very vibrant and really accentuate the atmosphere the rest of the game provides. The combat is very fluid, and it is quite entertaining using fidget powers with the dust storm flinging projectiles around the screen. Dust is littered with RPG elements from leveling up certain attributes to finding and crafting new equipable items (though his character sprite never changes). The story that unfolds as you proceed through the game is truly the icing on the cake which I will not spoil.However, Dust does suffer from its share of short comings. The replay value is not there, atleast from a new game file there isnt. You can collect all the items and most of the achivements in a single playthrough. The voice acting is mediocre and can sometimes be a little annoying (looking at you fidget..), but in the same breath has its moments. Overall I would rate this game an 7.5/10, and only because its a one shot wonder. So buy it on sale and enjoy!

Posted: February 20, 2014
												First of all, the design of the characters in this come from beautiful, hand-drawn animation. That alone, for me, gives it a reason to exist. Dust: An Elysian Tail is a very pretty game, and has more than a few surprises to back it up. A simple but sweet story, a likeable main character, and admittedly addicting combat makes Dust a fun little gem of an Indie game. There are some super sacchrine moments that border on narm and melodrama, but it's balanced out with enough charming moments that I can forgive it.And if your only hang-up about the game is that it's a darling of the furry fandom, get over yourself.

Posted: February 25, 2014
												At first glance I had a lot of assumptions about what this game would be, not anything to do with story or characters, but the type of genre the game inhabits and how it goes about that. In many ways it met those assumptions and while I was right it still managed to exceed my thoughts.A few screens and videos and to me this came off as a simplified metroid-like with a more straight forward beat-em up presentation. And my deep abiding love for any exploration based game was left mildly wanting to know that it really has more in line with Odin Sphere/Muramasa than Metroid it still has enough exploratory quirks to ever so slightly scratch that itch.What brings this simplicity bright, to me, is the trappings that are around the basic structure. The combat is fine to me, I don't find it completely compelling but it is satisfying in the way your character feels powerful and the agency through which you give him that power is what compels me through the game. Items, leveling up, quests. The depth is not great but it's all deep enough to just make the rest of it so easy to breeze through and feel constantly in a state of needing to get more from the game because it has the ability to give you more. I feel this lust for progress on the mechanical/statistical spectrum that drives me through the game itself elegantly.And that's not to say the story is creating any sort of roadblock to that. It's actually very well put together and while nearly cloying and childish at times it has an aspect that reflects back this younger version of yourself. Old Saturday morning cartoons, Disney movies, or even just any broadly aimed animated feature. It plays into that in a way that almost makes it okay to be so silly or ardent in child-like way. It's also interesting in how juxtaposed that is to the darker aspects of the story and how easily it accomplishes that without feeling overbearing or too self-serious. And it's startling how good the voice acting is in this game, disregarding some odd lines that sound re-recorded and not quite on point as the same voice from the same session.The gameplay itself may not be memorable to me but it really is fun to play and progress through. It may feel a little simplistic to start or jarringly sharp or oppressive in its presentation but I think its just so out of our usual context for that type of over the top character expression that it feels wrong at first, though over time it felt right at home.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												In short (and the game itself is short), this is a beautiful game. If you have a few hours to spare, you should give it a go. The visuals and music are both stunning, and I may even buy the soundtrack some time soon. The controls are pretty smooth (although pinpoint platforming sometimes gets a little troublesome), and while there are not that many combos to pull off, the battles are still fun and they make you look amazing as you pull off hundreds of chains and fly across the screen whilst tearing apart enemies. The characters and voice acting may be a bit cheesy, but I think it fits the overall style of the game and I found myself liking the interactions between them (primarily the two main characters). There are several side quests and challenge areas to do, so the possibility to deviate from the main storyline is there, if you like those kinds of things. I liked the number of side quests because it was not an overwhelming amount that caused me to lose sight of the main progression. If you're looking for a visually and audibly stunning hack-and-slash side-scroller, you should definitely try this game out!

												Absolutely phenominal.  Plays kind of like a sidescroller version of Ys (another good series if you don't know it; Oath in Felghana was especially great), has a relatively lengthy story, lots of sidequests (20~?) and if you like speedrunning, this game has a lot of tricks to master (currently mastering speedrunning myself on this game; dust storm op!).  10/10 would recommend to anyone. Posted: June 24, 2014
												This is a beautiful example of how to make a game when you don't have a Bethesda-class budget to play with.  The devs didn't try to go head-to-head with the latest hyper-realistic FPS or amazingly vast open world.  Instead, they took a very old, tried-and-true genre (the Metroidvania action platformer) and did it really well.The animation is smooth, and the sound is pleasant.  The storytelling allows itself some indulgent moments with overdramatic tropes, but then lightens up again with fourth-wall breaking, winking references to other games, and comedically petty sidequests for NPCs, rather than continually wallowing in melodrama.The style of gameplay is dated, and Dust can't compete on technical merits with big-studio offerings, but what makes this a pleasant experience is the degree of polish.  The devs put a lot of attention into this game, and it shows.

Posted: March 1, 2014
												To start of, the art-style and art-design are extremely beautiful, giving a lot of life to the game. The characters are also very likeable, well written and have good voice-acting. The plot of the game while well written doesn't really do anything too new but the world itself is so deep that it's still very easy to get sucked into the world. You can't talk about this game without mentioning the music. It's extremely well composed and memorable. I'd even say it's worth picking up the soundtrack so you can listen to it whenever you want.As for the gameplay, it's basically a metroidvania, with a lot of the mechanics you would expect from such a game. Something it doesn't have is multiple types weapons but instead a lot of effort was put into the combat to make it more enjoyable. While you don't have that many combos you can perform, you can easily go from one to the next, making the combat really fluent.The only real negative I have is that the ending didn't give a real closure to the characters and ending a game on a low note isn't something you want since that's what the player will remember the most. Still, there's too much to experience from this game for the ending to bring it down.

Posted: January 3, 2015
												Let me start off by saying this indie game is beautiful. The backgrounds are a joy to behold and the music compliments it well. Weather you are in the forest, in the caves, on a snow covered mountain or whatever, the environment is always very pretty to look at.Gameplay is wild. You hack and slash and spin and bombard your enemies into submission with the grace a tornado of ninjas. There really is something magical about it. I went through the game twice and throwing an enemy 80 feet into the air, flying up at him, grabbing him, and piledriving him back into the ground never lost its appeal. If I had oto complain about the combat, I'd say it can get very easy to lose track of what's going on in the chaos and that the player could have been given more attack combinations. However, as it stands it is visceral and amusing.Additionally the game has a Metroidvania style exploration aspect to it. It has keys to find to unlock treasure chests you find, some require upgrades to reach, and it has some puzzles to it help break-up any tedium you may feel from destroying you enemies all day.In short, if you like pretty, hack-n-slash, Metroidvania games you owe it to yourself to pick up this Indie title.

Posted: December 9, 2014
												So this was a case of needing something to occupy myself with while my wife worked on her second and third playthroughs of Dragon Age: Inquisition, so I went through my Steam library looking for something I hadn't tried yet. After seeing that Dust was an RPG metroidvania I decided to give it a try.After playing this I'm realizing I have a fondness for metroidvanias; while Guacamelee is the golden standard against which I will judge them all (that and Symphony of the Night, of course) it turns out Dust was pretty decent. The art style was pretty, though why all of the characters were anthropomorphized animals (aka furries) is beyond me. It didn't really help or hurt the game, but it did take me out of it a little. Why do some of them wear clothes, but your sidekick doesn't?Speaking of your sidekick, Fidget, ohmygoodness is her voice annoying. The game is well acted, but getting past Fidget's voice is a challenge. That said the dialog is surprisingly funny. Fidget does work as decent comic relief, "Why does it have knives for hands?! KNIVES FOR HANDS!" The overall plot is meh (evil general with ambiguous motives is trying to kill off the natives - I mean Moonbloods) though I liked the section where you are helping people in Mudpot. I found those characters way more interesting.Gameplay is solid. Standard unlock-powers-to-access-new-areas stuff (though, again, nowhere near as awesome as Guacamelee). There's also RPG stuff such as leveling up and managing gear. You can find recipes and make your own gear out of stuff you pick up from bad guys. There's a nice mechanic where if you sell an ingredient to the shopkeeper then the shop will periodically restock that ingredient, so later when you find a recipe that needs it you don't have to go grind a mob.The game's difficulty was all over the board. Sometimes I would feel like I was burning through all of my healing items and revival crystals (generally when I pushed forward in the main questline without doing side missions/looking for all the hidden treasure chests) yet by the end I had zero trouble with the final boss. Seriously, he was a chump. Also not interesting. If you're going to have me empty a boss' health meter 4 times at least have him change forms or vary his attack pattern. Not that it mattered because, as I said, he was a chump. I didn't need to bother studying the attack pattern.This game was a pleasant distraction for roughly 10 hours (didn't collect EVERY item, but did get most) and was well worth my time (especially considering I don't even remember buying it). That said, if you're looking for a metroidvania and you HAVEN'T played Guacamelee then, obviously, play that instead. If you're a fan of the genre then this is probably worth your time.

Posted: January 14, 2014
												I was shocked, SHOCKED at how much fun this game was. It's not terribly difficult, but it is fantastically fun. It has some backtracking for loot, similar to Metroid, which is cool, although I know that a lot of nerds want to cry bloody murder whenever this happens, it's not TOO bad. Honestly guys? Why do you hate that so much? Either way, if you felt that backtracking is the unholy spawn of Satan himself, the game doesn't present itself with enough difficulty to actually HAVE to do it... If you wanted to like, make a political statement or something. Combat is fast and frantic, and presents itself with enough options to keep stuff interesting. One thing I found is that nearly EVERY strategy is a good one to accomplish monster murder, except not fighting, that is a terrible strategy. The story isn't going to win any Oscars, but its good enough to keep you interested, the voice acting is good as well, Figet is legitimately funny with her 4th wall jokes, so bonus. I only got stuck in a wall once, and that's the only technical problem I ever ran into, it was near the end of the game, so it already had me in it's smoothly animated clutches and I didn't mind too much. The game saves a lot, so if you ever ran into a bug it's unlikely that you would throw your beverage at your pets and start crying in the fetal position in your neighbors crawlspace or anything. For people who like bullets: -FUN-BUY-PLAY-YAYCheck out my youtube channel for a laugh (probably at my expense, but that's okay, sniffle) the link is in my profile.

												I orriginally played this on the X-Box 360 and bought it here so access to the game will outlive my x-box (will likely purchase AGAIN if it makes it onto PS Vita) Dust is an oft times frenetic side scrolling beatemup with an aluring story that I wont spoil. Posted: June 26, 2016
												For a long time, I had dismissed Dust as mere "furry" bait. An unfair judgement, I know. Anyways, I finally gave it a try because Hardcore Gaming 101 had the game in their "200 Best Video Games of All Time" book. Notably, they recommended Dust over Muramasa, a game I also really love. I'm really glad I ended up giving Dust a try because it ended up being one of the most enjoyable ARPGs I've played in a while. The story was engaging (and surprisingly even moving), the combat was satisfying and the entire thing is damn gorgeous. The only problem I have with the game is that I actually really suck at these combo-centric type ARPGs. The last boss battle destroyed me and eventually I had to lower the difficulty to finish the game. I hope to return to the game on a higher difficulty though and actually properly learn the combat systems. Anyhow, I don't know if I can praise Dean Dodrill enough, because what he made is genius.

Posted: February 21, 2014
												To start off, I liked this game a lot, it had interesting gameplay and story. Graphics 5/5The graphics works really well with the environment that the story and characters were trying to portray. Each area looked beautiful with its paint style graphics. Also for the most part each area had something different to offer in the way of environment. Story 4/5I was extremely interested in the story. The story was pretty dynamic for how short it was. The main part of the story is Dust trying to figure out his mysterious past while he essentially helps people in need. Stories like this has definitely been done before, but for some reason Dust's story catched my interest a lot more then some others. With this said, the story left a lot of questions unanswered. For example, what was the background story for General Gaius? The story painted an interesting picture for General Gaius, but by the end, they just left General Gaius as the main Antagonist with very little explanation of why he did what he did. Also, the story could have gone two different ways. I think there could have been a possibility for two endings based off your choices. This could have made the story a little bit more interesting. Gameplay 4.5/5The gameplay was fun and rarely got boring. The game was a mix of 2d platform, rpg and action. You gain experience by defeating enemies and gain bonus experience depending on how high of a combo you can achieve. When you gain a level you are able to put one gem like stat point into one of the provided stats. Although levels were important it was mostly the abilities that you gained through the game that helped you the most in battle. The abilities you gained also looked extremely cool. At one point you were able to gain a fireball ability and if combined with Dust storm you were able to light most of the screen on fire torching your foes. With the right timing you were able to get a 1000 hit combo or more which was also very fun to watch and pull off. There were also many collectibles to keep you interested as well as challenge courses. I found the challenge courses difficult enough to get me angry after the 20th attempt which was fun but also a painful experience. The cameo characters were fun and sometimes difficult to find as well. These collectibles and challenges were not needed, but was a fun diversion from the main storyline. For the most part the gameplay was very well thought out but there were a few issues that I had with the gameplay. The combat was fun but did get repetitive at times. I feel like there needed to be more variety of skills to use, to keep the game from getting boring. The issue of repetitiveness was some what remedied by the shortness of the game, but I feel if the game went any longer I would have gotten very bored with the combat. Also near the end of the game I felt like I was overpowered. This may not be an issue with the game though considering I was probably overleveling while I was trying to get all the collectibles and finishing all the challenges. Sound/Music   5/5Nothing much to say here. The music and sound effects made sense for the environments and situations. The music sounded very good as well. Replayability 2/5Im trying to replay the game on a harder difficulty for the last few achievements but I find myself to lack the motivation to finish the game for the second time. There really isnt any thing different if you play it a second time besides the possibility to obtain some achievements and playing a more difficult setting. So a game plus option would have been nice or maybe a secret chapter where you can play as General Gaius and so on. Overall this game was amazing and well worth the money.

												This game is a 2D sidescrolling brawler, where you play Dust. Dust wakes up with amnesia and a talking sword next to him, and a strange animal that is like a squirel mixed with a bat. They go on adventure to discover what happened to Dust. A single playthrough is about 10 hours worth of gameplay, more if you want to go for the full 100% playthrough. There is only backtracking involved if you want to find all the secrets and hidden bonuses. The handdrawn visual style of the game is fresh and I personally liked it. The dev-team did some special effects too, but they sometimes obscured the screen a bit too much. Combat feels responsive with gamepad, but I cannot say if this also applies to keyboard. Towards the end I found the combat getting repettitive and I was getting a bit bored with the end stretch of the game. Still, I've very enjoyed playing it and as such I can recommend it.

Posted: December 9, 2014
												So this was a case of needing something to occupy myself with while my wife worked on her second and third playthroughs of Dragon Age: Inquisition, so I went through my Steam library looking for something I hadn't tried yet. After seeing that Dust was an RPG metroidvania I decided to give it a try.After playing this I'm realizing I have a fondness for metroidvanias; while Guacamelee is the golden standard against which I will judge them all (that and Symphony of the Night, of course) it turns out Dust was pretty decent. The art style was pretty, though why all of the characters were anthropomorphized animals (aka furries) is beyond me. It didn't really help or hurt the game, but it did take me out of it a little. Why do some of them wear clothes, but your sidekick doesn't?Speaking of your sidekick, Fidget, ohmygoodness is her voice annoying. The game is well acted, but getting past Fidget's voice is a challenge. That said the dialog is surprisingly funny. Fidget does work as decent comic relief, "Why does it have knives for hands?! KNIVES FOR HANDS!" The overall plot is meh (evil general with ambiguous motives is trying to kill off the natives - I mean Moonbloods) though I liked the section where you are helping people in Mudpot. I found those characters way more interesting.Gameplay is solid. Standard unlock-powers-to-access-new-areas stuff (though, again, nowhere near as awesome as Guacamelee). There's also RPG stuff such as leveling up and managing gear. You can find recipes and make your own gear out of stuff you pick up from bad guys. There's a nice mechanic where if you sell an ingredient to the shopkeeper then the shop will periodically restock that ingredient, so later when you find a recipe that needs it you don't have to go grind a mob.The game's difficulty was all over the board. Sometimes I would feel like I was burning through all of my healing items and revival crystals (generally when I pushed forward in the main questline without doing side missions/looking for all the hidden treasure chests) yet by the end I had zero trouble with the final boss. Seriously, he was a chump. Also not interesting. If you're going to have me empty a boss' health meter 4 times at least have him change forms or vary his attack pattern. Not that it mattered because, as I said, he was a chump. I didn't need to bother studying the attack pattern.This game was a pleasant distraction for roughly 10 hours (didn't collect EVERY item, but did get most) and was well worth my time (especially considering I don't even remember buying it). That said, if you're looking for a metroidvania and you HAVEN'T played Guacamelee then, obviously, play that instead. If you're a fan of the genre then this is probably worth your time.

												What a fantastic experience this game was. Even on its third of four difficulties, I only felt genuinely challenged at a couple points, but that didn't stop me from enjoying it thoroughly.Aesthetically, the game is beautiful. Every area feels distinctly different, and none of it feels fake or half-baked. Characters and animations are great, and even the voice acting, for the most part, isn't bad.Storywise...I don't feel like I'm ever qualified to criticize a game's plotlines, but it felt good, solid, strong enough to carry the game.Functionally, things are spot on. Not once did I ever feel like I got screwed over by being unable to control myself precisely how I needed to. The game has a good system behind the numbers, even if the exponential stat growth does lead to being immensely overpowered in the latter parts.Plus, all the characters are anthros, and they're not badly done. It's not necessarily a furry game, but it certainly appeals to us.Buy it, play it, love it.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												In short (and the game itself is short), this is a beautiful game. If you have a few hours to spare, you should give it a go. The visuals and music are both stunning, and I may even buy the soundtrack some time soon. The controls are pretty smooth (although pinpoint platforming sometimes gets a little troublesome), and while there are not that many combos to pull off, the battles are still fun and they make you look amazing as you pull off hundreds of chains and fly across the screen whilst tearing apart enemies. The characters and voice acting may be a bit cheesy, but I think it fits the overall style of the game and I found myself liking the interactions between them (primarily the two main characters). There are several side quests and challenge areas to do, so the possibility to deviate from the main storyline is there, if you like those kinds of things. I liked the number of side quests because it was not an overwhelming amount that caused me to lose sight of the main progression. If you're looking for a visually and audibly stunning hack-and-slash side-scroller, you should definitely try this game out!
