Posted: August 23, 2015
												So, first of all, this is my first review.Difficulty: Normal; 17h played; lvl 46 - 47Something to the game and the chars.* The game is a 2D World in the art of the Trine game-series.* Each time you left a map-square, it will respawn (endless farm & lvl potential until maximum ?).* The combat system is simple but is entertaining; you have some combos you can easily do like jump hit 3 times and right click to throw your enemy to the ground, especially good in the late stage in my opinion.* There are 12 (?) friends you can "unlock"; each gives you a +5% HP bonus.* Fidget seems extremely childish and annoying during the good first half of the main quest.* Dust don't know who he is and is looking for answers, which makes him sometimes angry because of mental pressure.* Ahrah is the blade which Dust is carrying. He speaks with Dust and advise him through the magical journey.* If you are on the map, you can watch upwards and see Fidget eating or sleeping on a tree bough.* You can forge your weapons; they aren't always buyable in the shop.Story.Pretty much this: Dust.The entire story is build around the main character which we as customers are playing. Dust wanders through the world and helps people. He seems to remember them all, but no one remembers him. You will interact in the world and you have up to three or four dialogue options.You will find many quests through your way in the world.A note here: It's a deep philosophical game; it handles about life and death and about his understanding in the world.Positives and Dislike.The only thing I dislike are the fact that self-made weapons aren't more gold worth, while selling, than the actual cost of forging it. It seems there are some troubles with my graphic card driver too (AMD Radeon HD 7650M).Q: What is your opinion on the Story ?A: 10/10Q: How do you liked the overall content (smithing etc) ?A: 10/10Q: Opinion about Quests and Dialogues ?A: 10/10Q: Is the combat system entertaining enough ?A: 10/10Q: Did you share tears at the end of the game ?A: 10/10Q: Would you buy a Fidget-puppet on amazon ?A: 10/10Q: Would you buy a wallpaper/drawing of Fidget gifting you a Fidget-Drawing ?A: 10/10Q: Do you recommend this game ?A: 10/10Q: Overall experience and commenting ?A: I love this game. I'll play it for sure again. It's an awesome job. Can we have Fidget-puppets on sale online ?

Posted: May 21, 2015
												This game encompasses everything I love about video games. The graphics are beautiful, the story is engaging, and the music draws you right in. This is, however, an action RPG/Metroidvania, so none of that would matter if the gameplay and level design wasn't up to snuff. Luckily, that's not the case. The controls are tight and snappy. Dust does exactly what you want him to do, when you want him to do it. Although more simplistic, I almost felt a Devil May Cry influence in the combat. It's action packed and relentless. The level design is varied and entertaining. I eagerly looked forward to what I was going to find on the next screen. The enemy designs were also quite good. The headless zombie things in the third section made me smile every time I saw them. The one complaint I have with this game is the same one everyone else has. The boss fights. While not bad, they just don't measure up to the rest of the game and they're definitely a bit on the easy side. But you should absolutely not let that one small thing stop you from experiencing this game.Dust: An Elysian Tail is just plain fun, no matter how you look at it. I can't wait to play it again on a harder difficulty once I get through some of my backlog and I'll eagerly await a sequel.9.5/10

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Gameplaywise, it's straightforward : you have one sword and learn several moves throughout the game. I thought this would limit the gameplay, making it boring at some point, but it didn't. The game is relatively short if you decide to do the campaign only, and becomes longer if you decide to do the subquest. You can find equipment to upgrade your sword & be more competitive in fights. The game itself is really easy, if you wish for a challenge, directly jump to the hardcore difficulty, where you really die easily if you gets hit (my advice : don't try to speedrun it, use combos & dodge as much as possible).Graphically : it's a cel-shaded style plat-former, who really take inspiration into Don Bluth's An American Tail animated movie in terms of artstyle (they even made the same pun). At first I thought it would be a problem since I'm really not a fan of the furry genre (due to what the Internet did to it, mostly) but it really only took inspiration in the Don Bluth movie style and never try to sexualize the characters like you can see many games do whenever they try to add androgynous animal characters. So yeah, I really felt I was watching an old animated movie, with the same kind of message Don Bluth himself would be able to convey (about war, destruction of nature, etc...)The story is cute, it's nothing great but it's very cute, very well acted, and I appreciate the voice actors' effort in the play.One big plus for this game is the music : the music is absolutely fantastic, and one of my favourite soundtrack in videogame's history. Not even kidding.It's charming, it's fun, it's pretty. The music is beautiful.It is a wonderful tail... I mean tale.

Posted: January 30, 2016
												Dust is not a masterpiece. I'd say it's nowhere close to a masterpiece. The story is nothing special, the character art and designs are honestly fairly poor, and there were more than a few sequences I felt were just badly-designed. It's got its share of flaws, and its strengths don't completely make up for them. But for a game produced independently by a single man, it's still very impressive.The scenery is beautiful, the combat is fun (albeit not nearly as great as it sounds; the combat is, in fact, not difficult to master and does not increase in complexity from the beginning of the game), and it's an enjoyable experience. As a whole, the story failed to enrapture me, the characters didn't appeal to me (with the sole exception of Fidget, and even then, it's nothing overly memorable), but I still think I had fun playing it.This isn't a game I'd go out of my way to recommend. But if you're interested, you might as well give it a go.6/10. Above average, but not exceptional.

Posted: May 8, 2014
												This game is a 2D sidescrolling brawler, where you play Dust. Dust wakes up with amnesia and a talking sword next to him, and a strange animal that is like a squirel mixed with a bat. They go on adventure to discover what happened to Dust. A single playthrough is about 10 hours worth of gameplay, more if you want to go for the full 100% playthrough. It incorporates a castlevania style of gameplay as well, where you learn new tricks to overcome particular obstacles. There is only backtracking involved if you want to find all the secrets and hidden bonuses. The handdrawn visual style of the game is fresh and I personally liked it. The dev-team did some special effects too, but they sometimes obscured the screen a bit too much. Combat feels responsive with gamepad, but I cannot say if this also applies to keyboard. Towards the end I found the combat getting repettitive and I was getting a bit bored with the end stretch of the game. Still, I've very enjoyed playing it and as such I can recommend it.

Posted: January 19, 2015
												I highly recommend this game.  What first got my attention for this game was the artwork.  And it is beautiful.  But then I found it's a 2D 'platformer' game, which I'm not that big on.  However I did enjoy Castlevania and some other reviews here likened it to that game too.  Then I learned that it was almost entirely done by a single person - animation, programming, everything, other than voices and music.  So then I was very impressed.  Especially with all the other very positive reviews.  So with it being on sale I went ahead and picked it up.And 70-some hours later I'm extreamly glad I did.  I still love the artwork, but have also fallen in love with the characters and the story.  Very enjoyable voicing.  I totally love Fidget (the Nimbat that looks to be a cross of a bat and fox).  There is a very serious and interesting story told, but also lots of fun and humor mixed in.  The fighting which you do a lot of was just fine for me.  Enough challenge to be fun and worthwhile, but not to the point of frustraition.  And the platforming is more exploration and puzzling than having to make pixel-perfect jumps, for which I'm glad.All in all, if this game even looks a little interesting to you, by all means pick it up and have fun.  Even at full price it's not all that much, but on sale it's a no-brainer.

Posted: December 9, 2014
												So this was a case of needing something to occupy myself with while my wife worked on her second and third playthroughs of Dragon Age: Inquisition, so I went through my Steam library looking for something I hadn't tried yet. After seeing that Dust was an RPG metroidvania I decided to give it a try.After playing this I'm realizing I have a fondness for metroidvanias; while Guacamelee is the golden standard against which I will judge them all (that and Symphony of the Night, of course) it turns out Dust was pretty decent. The art style was pretty, though why all of the characters were anthropomorphized animals (aka furries) is beyond me. It didn't really help or hurt the game, but it did take me out of it a little. Why do some of them wear clothes, but your sidekick doesn't?Speaking of your sidekick, Fidget, ohmygoodness is her voice annoying. The game is well acted, but getting past Fidget's voice is a challenge. That said the dialog is surprisingly funny. Fidget does work as decent comic relief, "Why does it have knives for hands?! KNIVES FOR HANDS!" The overall plot is meh (evil general with ambiguous motives is trying to kill off the natives - I mean Moonbloods) though I liked the section where you are helping people in Mudpot. I found those characters way more interesting.Gameplay is solid. Standard unlock-powers-to-access-new-areas stuff (though, again, nowhere near as awesome as Guacamelee). There's also RPG stuff such as leveling up and managing gear. You can find recipes and make your own gear out of stuff you pick up from bad guys. There's a nice mechanic where if you sell an ingredient to the shopkeeper then the shop will periodically restock that ingredient, so later when you find a recipe that needs it you don't have to go grind a mob.The game's difficulty was all over the board. Sometimes I would feel like I was burning through all of my healing items and revival crystals (generally when I pushed forward in the main questline without doing side missions/looking for all the hidden treasure chests) yet by the end I had zero trouble with the final boss. Seriously, he was a chump. Also not interesting. If you're going to have me empty a boss' health meter 4 times at least have him change forms or vary his attack pattern. Not that it mattered because, as I said, he was a chump. I didn't need to bother studying the attack pattern.This game was a pleasant distraction for roughly 10 hours (didn't collect EVERY item, but did get most) and was well worth my time (especially considering I don't even remember buying it). That said, if you're looking for a metroidvania and you HAVEN'T played Guacamelee then, obviously, play that instead. If you're a fan of the genre then this is probably worth your time.

Posted: February 28, 2016
												Dust is a 2-D hack & slash action platformer with RPG elements and branching paths, similar to the Castlevania series.  Unlike those games, however, Dust eschews heavy exploration and technical battles in favor of lightning-fast mobility and hordes of enemies that will often have the player racking up combos of several hundred hits as they leap from target to target seamlessly without ever touching the ground.APPROXIMATE LENGTH10 hours for the main story, plus another 10 for all the sidequests & secretsPROS(+) The combat system is magnificent both mechanically and visually: easy to learn, fun to use, and amazing to watch(+) Beautiful visual style in both backgrounds and sprites(+) Music is fully orchestrated and blends well with the settings(+) Complete voice acting for all dialog, with high quality performances all around(+) Fidget is adorable and hilariousCONS(-) Plot & dialog can get pretty melodramatic(-) Items & crafting system is little more than a forced burden(-) Animated cutscenes are of mediocre quality and feel out of place(-) Difficulty curve starts very steep, then overabundant healing items make the game too easyYOUR MILEAGE MAY VARY(?) All characters are anthropomorphic “furries”.  Some people like that.  Others don’t.OVERALLDust is a game that is just plain fun to play and experience, and feels very professionally made.  Has some issues, but overall delivers on what it sets out to do.

Posted: April 1
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a beautiful game. The art style is so entrancing that it's worth noting how easy it is to get drawn into this world before discussing anything else. Yes, it has anthropomorphic protagonists, but that really shouldn't keep you from giving this game a chance. The combat is tight and fast paced, providing some challenge without ever feeling overwhelming. I was able to get through most of the game without too much trouble fighting enemies, all of which match each location well and build a world you want to explore. I came much closer to 100%-ing the game than I ever planned to, because I had so much fun using the game's many platforming mechanics to explore every inch of each level. There are plenty of collectibles for people who enjoy that kind of thing, but if you'd rather plow through each level and just complete the story, you'll still have a great time. I do want to give the writing some credit here. While I can't say I was particularly surprised by where it led, the game does a great job fleshing out the characters and getting the player invested in uncovering the secrets that hide what really happened in our hero's past (yes, it's an amnesia story. Yes, it goes exactly where you think it will. No, that doesn't hurt your enjoyment of this game). The variety of movement options to explore the map are all fun and rewarding when you pull off each combo just right. I'm still amazed all of this was created by a solo developer. It truly raises the bar for a personal project like this.If I had to give a criticism, I'd say the ending is a pretty harsh difficulty spike. The final boss has multiple steps to it, and the final level is WAY more difficult that anything you've played to that point. It's not brutal, per se, but it does feel like a more gradual curve could have helped brace the player for enemies who know how to block your combos effectively. However, this is the most minor of nitpicks.I loved this game, and if you enjoy story-based adventure/platformers, you'll likely love this too. I couldn't recommend it more highly.

Posted: April 3
												Dust is a medium sized, hack'n'slash/platformer/RPG with big bucks behind (similar to what got the famous 2012 game, journey).The game graphics are rich and beautiful.  The animation is great. Dust animation is "anime-like" in contrast with the non-playable characters who get a smooth animation. The story is good enough for me. The sound (including voices) and the music (final fantasy-ish) are on the same high level. But I still wonder how they managed to draw such an ugly world map.The gameplay is relatively easy assuming you are patient enough to be grinding XP for levels. The gameplay will be boring/repetitive, because some stages are a bit too long, and many times, suffer from a lack of "density of action". That knowing you will have to re-run many stages several times with different abilities in order to acheive 100% completion... also there, you will be grinding XP for levels in order to make the game clearable.There is a common default in RPGs: either you miss levels and the game is super hard, either you did a lot of boring XP grinding and the game is super easy because you are way over-leveled. So the stages are calibrated to be reasonably clearable at a specific level: if you are below, it's unreasonable, if you are above, it's too easy. This balance issue should be addressed in all RPGs, here it's not the case then you are free to torture yourself like a masochist or get bored at over-leveling your Dust and then slice throught the game like a hot knife in butter.Technically, I got a few bugs (exceptions), and the controls felt slooooow/unresponsive in fight. It does run on linux based OSes with a recent mesa3D.On the overall, I do recommend this game.

Posted: March 7, 2015
												Okay, here's the short version of this review.This game is absolutely AMAZING!!!Now for the long version of this review.Dust: An Elysian Tail is one of the most well-crafted video games I have ever played, and it's easily in my top 5 favourite games of all time.  The gameplay is insanely satisfying; any fans of hack-and-slashes or Metroidvanias will most likely enjoy this game big-time.  The story is well-written and surprisingly dark for such a colourful world, and the game puts a lot of emphasis on pretty much every character in the game, even the minor characters!The visuals of this game, in my opinion, might be the best I've ever seen in any video game.  This game's visuals are absolutely BREATHTAKING, especially when the weather effects kick in.  You will not believe how many times I was at a loss of words for how beautiful the game looked at times (you should've seen me when I got to Blackmoor Mountain XD).  As for the soundtrack, it's straight-up majestic.  The OST is beautifully composed, and help capture the mood for pretty much every scene they're assigned.The only complaints that I really have with this game are that the boss fights are pretty meh (with the exception of the game's final boss), but even then, there's so few bosses in the game that it's not a major issue; plus, the characterization given to the bosses is actually really impressive.  The only other issue I have with the game is that Chapter 3 is pretty pointless and, admittedly, kinda boring, but the rest of the game makes up for it in spades.So, long story short, if you have the money for this game and you're just staring at the store page wondering if you should click on that Add to Cart button, I'd say that you should.  Chances are, you will not be disappointed by this game.  I sure wasn't.9.5/10

Posted: December 28, 2013
												Gameplaywise, it's straightforward : you have one sword and learn several moves throughout the game. I thought this would limit the gameplay, making it boring at some point, but it didn't. The game is relatively short if you decide to do the campaign only, and becomes longer if you decide to do the subquest. You can find equipment to upgrade your sword & be more competitive in fights. The game itself is really easy, if you wish for a challenge, directly jump to the hardcore difficulty, where you really die easily if you gets hit (my advice : don't try to speedrun it, use combos & dodge as much as possible).Graphically : it's a cel-shaded style plat-former, who really take inspiration into Don Bluth's An American Tail animated movie in terms of artstyle (they even made the same pun). At first I thought it would be a problem since I'm really not a fan of the furry genre (due to what the Internet did to it, mostly) but it really only took inspiration in the Don Bluth movie style and never try to sexualize the characters like you can see many games do whenever they try to add androgynous animal characters. So yeah, I really felt I was watching an old animated movie, with the same kind of message Don Bluth himself would be able to convey (about war, destruction of nature, etc...)The story is cute, it's nothing great but it's very cute, very well acted, and I appreciate the voice actors' effort in the play.One big plus for this game is the music : the music is absolutely fantastic, and one of my favourite soundtrack in videogame's history. Not even kidding.It's charming, it's fun, it's pretty. The music is beautiful.It is a wonderful tail... I mean tale.

Posted: May 27, 2014
												6/10Overall I enjoyed this game. It's fun, the artwork is beautiful, and the story really comes together in surprising ways at the end.But there are a few complaints.The big one is the health system. When you level up, you can choose to upgrade your choice of four things, one of them being max health. There is virtually no point in upgrading your maximum health. There is no natural health regeneration, and there are no inns or any other sort of place that you can go to restore your health. Completing a level does not heal you. The ONLY way is by buying health items from a shop. 20 health costs 80 gold. Sure, you can buy an item that restores 40 health for 160 gold, or 120 health for 480 gold, but there is no discount as you go up. No incentive to buy better healing items. No reason to increase your max health until enemies literally one shot you.Moreover, the amount of damage the enemies do doesn't seem fair. They either do virtually no damage, or they do a TON of damage, but not much in between. So you are either just flying through an area virturally ignoring all the enemies, or you are using up all your health items in a five minute period.The voice acting isn't of the best quality either, which the exception of the main characters. When I talk to someone, I don't hear the character's voice. I hear a person trying to do a silly voice. As I talk to more characters, I can hear what is clearly just a small handfull of voice actors trying to do a bunch of different silly voices.Because of flaws like these and more, I wouldn't give the game a perfect score. But there is enough about it that IS done well that I will give it a positive score.

Posted: January 26, 2015
												Dust is a serious adventure RPG that can be turned way simple for easy fun / exploration, or way hard into true hardcore 2D bash-em combat with an impressive combo system that can do various types of attacks, from ground to slide to jump and much fancier aerial moves. The plot is relatively simple. You are Dust. You woke up in a field, not knowing yourself, when a sword... yes, a flying and TALKING sword floated up to you and addressed you as Master. Then Fidget, a Nimbat, showed up and wil accompany you on whatever quest you are supposed to go on since she comes with the sword. As you head toward the village in the distance hoping for answers, you hear fighting... Some sort of monsters are attacking the town, and you leapt into action... The graphics are quite good, sort of Disney-esque type animal humanoid that looks far cuter than it should for all its seriousness, about finding one's true self and all the war and attack and civilian casualties, and good vs. evil and all that. Sound is also quite good. There's some debate whether the protagonist voice sounds a bit too young, but sounds okay to me. (And you have to play the game to see why.)There are basically three attacks (later there's a fourth, the ground slide/kick) blade, dust storm, and Fidget burst. It is the combination that makes things deadly. Blade plus jump is an aerial attack. Blade plus jump plus dust storm yields an aerial super attack. Dust storm and Fidget burst creates attack swarm. As you level up each ability through EXP (via quests and kills) you'll gain additional attacks and combos. (On casual difficulty this is done automatically)You will also encounter various types of equipment: armor, amulet, left ring, right ring, and "augment" (weapon enhancement). You will often encounter blueprints to build more advanced equipment... provided you find the blacksmith and have enough materials. Some stuff are available at merchant. There are many sidequests in the story as you encounter more NPCs. Some will ask you to find X ingredients, while others want you to retrieve something or someone, or reach a particualr area and search for something. Doing them yields extra EXP to level you up. Other activities that yields EXP are just talking to every NPC you come across (but you only get that once). There are special "treasure chests" in the world for you to find, and most involve some sort of a puzzle. Usually it is to pull a "bombfruit" toward an alloy gate to blast it open, but the bombfruit can be at a challenging place so it can be difficult to pull it properly esp. when the bomb fruit may come with a timer (after X seconds, kaboom!) There are also special "friend chests" (12 of them in the world) for you to find as you unlock your "friends" captured in the cages. It's another type of collectible, but a fun one. As you learn new skills, such as floor slide (to get through narrow low tunnels), double jump ( to reach extra high places), iron grip (to climb the vines) , you will discover new areas you haven't been able to reach before, and often that is how you find these extra treasure chests and cages. So exploration is a must. You will be told percentage of areas you missed and/or treasure you missed, so don't fret. The game autosaves when you pass through a "save point" (temple) which also heals you. You can also trigger a manual save on a savepoint. The savepoint also serves as a teleport point that allows you to leave the map region, if you bought some teleport gems (not that expensive, and you did get a few for free). The game never felt too frustrating, except the problem of opening up a certain area before you are ready. For example, there's a mission where you need to find a girl in the "Hidden Cove", except you can't explore that area unless you have Iron Grip skill, which is only available at the end of Sorrow Meadows. The game doesn't always make this clear. There are also some quests that are a bit too whimsical, or even on casual, way too difficult without advanced skills like double jump. However, if you are the type that goes for every bit of completion, you will no doubt feel frustrated now and then, even on casual. There are also six "trials", sort of a "speed-run" through a certain level where you try to take as little damage as possible, while fighting your way past monsters and environmental hazards. And they award high level equipment, depending on how well you do, with rating of up to 4 stars (depending on score). All in all, Dust is a very good game that, IMHO, looks way too cute for its own good that people will have problems taking ti seriously. If you can get past it, you will find a rewarding action-adventure with good puzzles and challenging bash-em on higher difficulty levels.

Posted: May 24, 2014
												My apology for not writing a review for this amazing game in the past, for some reason it escaped me.I just noticed the game is on sale 5/24/2014 and I STRONGLY recommend it even at full price. JUMP on this now, if you already haven't been blessed by getting to own and play this spectacular experience.  It pulls off amazing combat with cool abilities to string attacks together, you'll feel like you are flying through the air a.k.a. "Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon" combat style...and while this happens you will enjoy beautiful music and graphics that are top notch...imagine Disney/Pixar quality in the best way.  Some people will tell you that this is an Xbox port but I believe that the author has stated that this game was originally written  on the PC.  I personally prefer to use a controller to play but it works with mouse and keyboard.  There is a lot to this game and you can go back and discover things that your character wasn't previously powerful enough to handle.  Combat is so fun repeating some areas does NOT feel grindy or boring at all.  Its hard to say that this is "the best platformer on the pc" because its so much more than just a platformer.  You really need to experience the amazing and fluid brawler/combat...Although button mashing will get you a little ways, you really need to have finesse when you play.  Adorable characters, amazing story...I hate to give things a numerical rating but in this case I'll give it 99 out of 100.  There is a LOT to this game and plenty of gameplay...the only reason I didn't give it 100 is I don't know if there will ever be that absolutely perfect game but this one is a razor's edge close to it. Once again--do yourself the favor of buying this game.  Encourage the developer to bring us more fantastic games.Not sure on this:  This game was somehow written by ONE person (and I believe he hired people to do voiceovers and music) but not certain.<3 Dust An Elysian Tail <3

Posted: September 27, 2015
												One word to describe it? Mindblown.The moment I saw the screenshots and trailer for this game, I knew this game could be something special and I was ABSOLUTELY RIGHT! To put it simply:1. Story? Great story that both young and old audiences can enjoy.2. Characters? Very lovable characters (expect for the obvious "bad" guys lol) and I really like that most of them had "side quests" when talking to them and not just have them standing there, talking to you once and never hear from them again. I found myself revisiting a lot of them frequently, solving their issues as well as being rewarded for completing those side quests. Definitely love this approach!3. Graphics? Simply BEAUTIFUL/GORGIOUS WORLD with stunning views in almost all areas. While admittedly it took me some time to adapt to it (especially while running and fighting enemies), I got adapted to it rather quickly and have thoroughly enjoyed every level I played not just for the story/fights but also for observing the surrounding beautiful landscapes as well.4. Music? Absolutely brilliant! The music was calming at times, intense at other times, but it was always fitting to the scene and really helped get me totally "immersed" in the atmosphere of this great game!5. Fighting? Very fluid and you get more abilities (as well as power-ups for your companion "Fidget") as you progress so that you can revisit old areas and unlock hidden chests in areas that you weren't able to reach previously. Though, my ONLY "criticism" of this entire game is that, while you get new abilities/power-ups, you do NOT get any "new combos" as you progress, meaning you are stuck doing the SAME combos over and over again from start to the end of this game. So as a note to developers, for future similar games, please add more new combos to decrease the "repetitiveness" of killing the enemies with the same old combos over and over again.Nonetheless, the one criticism above does NOT have any major impact on my enjoyment of this game. Definitely a "must-buy" for those who enjoy stories that are told in an old style "cartoony" fashion with FULL VOICE ACTING for all dialogues as well as those who just enjoy side-scrolling fighting games in general.Final Rating: 10/10. (And hoping for a FUTURE SEQUEL to this game as well! :D)

Posted: January 15, 2016
												First and Foremost, while there are a large amount of support staff, this game is largely the result one man's work.  Dean Dodrill did a phenominal job bringing this to life and while I'm usually not willing to give leniance to games simply because of they have a smaller dev team, I feel this game is worthy of an exception.The game is quite pretty and you can tell that Dean's first love is animation.  There is beautiful detail in a lot of the work and the environments ooze character and personality.  It's the kind of art direction that a larger studio would never really get 'right' because Dust's art is the result of a singular vision, not designed by a committee.  While the artistic front is not as polished and as jaw-dropping as say, Ori and the Blind Forest, it's definitely a strong point and again, for a single person who kinda just wanted to do animation, it's nothing short of fantastic.The combat is fluid, fair, and manages to feel pretty good.  The mechanics follow a lot of the standards that are expected in a action-combat game.  While the game feels pretty good to play, it lacks depth and has a lot of contextual actions that trade fine control for ease of combat.I bought this game because I wanted to find a 2D Devil May Cry and I learned a something playing through Dust:  DMC is hard to make.A game like DMC4 has systems are ultra tight and provide a platform for the player to do amazing things if you invest the time to learn them.  It has a skill ceiling that might as well be infinite due to the shear number of options you have as a player, and as difficulty ramps up, the game will expect you to use those options with a kind of fluency that takes hours and hours to master.  Dust does not have that kind of depth.  A lot of the combat systems aren't perfect.  Attacks in the air kind of auto-target anything close by, sacrificing player control at times when you'd rather not.  You can lock almost every enemy into an infinite loop of uninterruptable damage in a couple different ways, none of which are terribly difficult to perform.  Bosses have pretty predictable patterns that are easy to abuse and instead of fighting a dynamic fight that requires action and reaction, you are kinda stuck just doing 'the thing that works'.There are a few other problems with the systems in place.  Attacks that would kill you will leave you at 1 HP as long as you have at least 50% of the HP the attack would do.  This means, that healing past that threshold is a mistake, and that max HP is effectively worthless.  You get bonus XP based on your combo, but you can farm combo with your secondary attack from your friendly NPC and since combo isn't damage, but rather hit count, it is in your best interest to keep her damage as low as possible while you just spam a screenwide AoE, allowing you to easily push your combo to several hundred with just a handful of monsters on the screen, which translates to easy levels.  There are a lot of counterintuitive systems that are ripe for abuse.I was kinda hoping for a game with as tight of design as a modern DMC and I didn't really get that, but regardless, the game is a fine entry in it's own right.  Despite their flaws, the mechanics aren't frustrating and as long as you go into the game with the right expectations, You'll find an enjoyable experience.

												Dust is a very well balanced mix of metroid and castlevania with a brawler-like combat system and rpg elements. The story is well implemented, and supported by a great soundtrack, beautiful art and fun gameplay. The game mechanics are solid with a great leveling system, that rewards high combos in a intreresting way and fine-tuned controls. Posted: September 3, 2014
												The short version: I would consider this the side-scrolling equivalent of Okami. It's beautiful to look at; elegant controls; robust skill progression; an original, well-told story; and a fitting soundtrack.Having experienced the evolution of gaming from the Commodore 64/Odyssey days through today, playing a game that is inspired by previous generations, be it in terms of graphics (the glut of 'pixel' art games) or gameplay (sidescrolling/platforming) is a hard sell for me.Dust: An Elysian Tale blew me away. The story was engaging, with plenty of memorable characters, and surprisingly voice acted. The art style, whether you are talking about the beautifully hand painted backgrounds, the smooth combat animations, or the anime style cutscenes, all fit together perfectly, with each location a treat to look at.I would buy this again in a heartbeat, and hope, one day, to return to the world of Elysia.

Posted: May 28, 2013
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is an action side-scrolling platformer game with a very fluid combo system and well animated attacks, giving the player a sense of simply being awesome in combat. I've played a lot of games, but nothing is quite as unique as Dust. The game gives the player the ability to move freely throughout the world, going to whichever areas they so desire to rack-up XP, explore or find hidden secrets in past levels. The story in Dust is one surrounded by mystery, the protagonist, Dust, starts off with amnesia and cannot recollect a damn thing about his past, which I know is very cliche but it suits Dust's story just fine. The protagonist is alway accompanied by a cat-ferret-bat creature by the name of Fidget (who is also the cutest damn thing I've seen since Tali in Mass Effect), who offers humorous dialogue and grants the player a ranged attack. To clarify: I f*cking love Fidget.Dust's combat system flows beautifully, utilizing a mere three buttons for attacks, the combat is simple but at the same time awe inspiring, easy to pick up on and very well made, when the player whipes out his/her first batch of enemies you immediately feel like an incredible badass and leaves you itching for more. As the game proceeds you acquire new abilities that complement your already formidible attack options and keep the game from getting stale, all the while maintaining a steady difficulty curve alongside an easy to understand XP and level-up system.Graphics-wise: It's an indy game, you don't come into it expecting mind-blowing graphics. Dust uses a simple but lovable anthropomorphic cartoon art-style that is both charming and outright adorable, but also dark and serious when it needs to be. All perfected with an amazing musical score and top quality voice acting. As well, Dust makes numerous quips at the expense of the fourth wall and makes references to other games, like Resident Evil 4 and Castlevania. The one flaw I've seen thus far is a somewhat finicky platform system. Sometimes if you don't land on a platform at exactly the right angle you're going through, which in a platformer game is a real kick to the groin.In conclusion: Dust: An Elysian Tail is fun, fluid, and highly addictive. I definitely recommend anyone reading this to pick it up immediately.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												with simplistic graphics and combat, this game has become one of my absolute favorite Story-based games.  Although this game is hugely combat based (it could be argued that it is a brawler) the story is very well synced with that fact.  I absolutely LOVED the story, from start to finish.that aside, what really makes a game is what makes it fun, right?  so, yea..the combat.ohhhh the combat.MY GOD!  IS IT GOOD!This has got to be one of the best 2D combat engines ive ever had the pleasure to play with.  ESPECIALLY for an xbox to pc port game (its never this smooth).  although i find it hard to get into single weapon games, this one did it right by giving you a versatile arsenal of combos and manuevers that make even the cannon fodder fights really fun.  whats more important, though, is that the combat engine is SOOOOO responsive!  i can scarcely believe how much this indie title outclasses so many larger developer titles with its combat engine.IT IS PERFECT.there is plently of room for petty personal complaint, but as far as pure, solid fact goes, the combat in this game does EXACTLY what it's supposed to.  there are zero bugs with it.What I truly love about this game, though; aside from the entrancing story line and exciting combat, is the art.  and take that word loosely, because im talking the whole spectrum.  The animation for character and level design is beautifully done!  The music is absolutely breathtaking!  this game itself, is a work of art as far as videogames go.  It was created and brought to life by one man over 4 years, and you can easily see the passion and talent in his work.this game is much like the older castlevania and metroid games (metrovania?), and in my personal oppinion, if it had been released in that generation (give some modesty to the graphics and sound qualitly, of course) it would have been an instant classic.  There is no circumstance in which i can justify not telling you to buy this game at its current price of $15.  i would easily pay twice that price for a game of this quality.One of the best, most fun games ive played in recent years.

												Moderately fun side scrolling hack and slash plat forming RPG game. Played on the second hardest difficulty with a usb playstation controller and it took about 10 hours to beat it just doing the main quest line. About 2 hours of that was just grinding because I didn’t bother with the crafting system so my gear wasn’t that good. The enemies are not that difficult until you get to the last area. The greatest challenge came from the platforming as jumps were often very difficult to make. Your regular jump often does not reach high enough so you have to attack in mid air to get that extra height boost, but this makes sticking your landing in the right spot more difficult. You also often just randomly fall through platforms when you land on them which can be frustrating. I also had to restart the game on several occasions because I would just randomly fall through and get stuck inside of walls. The good thing is there are a lot of save points so even if you get stuck you don't have to restart that far back. The story line/dialog is kind of cringey, but I just skipped most of it. The environment looks pretty nice, but sometimes it is hard to tell what you can jump on or what hurts you as the background and foreground kind of blend in with the main area at times. I wouldn’t recommend buying this game at full price, but since it was included in the humble bundle 11 you can probably get it for cheap.

Posted: January 13, 2014
												One of my best games. Great artwork, charming characters and an excellent story. What more could you wish for from a game?It's all designed in a "An American Tail" (or similiar) style with extremely fluent combat. Whats even more impressive is that it's all made by one developer alone over 4 years.

Posted: January 14, 2014
												I'd love to thank Dean Dodrill and Alex Brandon not only for this amazing game, but also Jazz Jackrabbit 2. Re-living my childhood through this game, listening to its music, watching its beautiful animation, getting sucked into the deep story, I had an absolutely amazing time with it, and wish it wasn't over.The music alone will send you on the epic journey, and bring you back home again:http://hyperduck.bandcamp.com/album/dust-an-elysian-tail-original-soundtrackGet this game.

Posted: July 5, 2013
												A bit Castlevania, a bit Devil May Cry, a bit Secret of Mana. This game takes cues from good games old and new and combines them with modern sensibilities and original design to create something great. Beautiful visuals and memorable characters punctuate a touching story of a character with a conflicted origin, crossing both tragedy and epic heroism as the protagonist of the story, Dust, crafts his true destiny. Dust starts with little more than a vague recollection of times long past and quickly finds himself in a position to help those in need, and through his travels learns of dark deeds that have sunk the land into an oppressive sorrow, as well as his role in this situation, both past and present. Many would turn a blind eye or side with those who hold power, but there's something different about this one...It's well worth the paltry price being asked, if you enjoy broad gamplay and exploration. A combo system that allows you to juggle entire spawns of enemies and fly around like a madman, as well as tag team attacks allowing you to amp up your signature attack and become a human lightning rod, are combined with an action RPG leveling system and metroidvania exploration. Beatiful hand painted levels beg you to explore them and find every little hidden secret, with a surprising level of detail hidden around every corner.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												I bought this game at a severely reduced price during a sale. If I had any idea what playing it would be like, I wouldn't have minded paying full price. $15 USD is a STEAL for a game this fantastic.I wasn't 100% sold on some of the voice acting at first, but then I took a step back and realized just how amazing it is to have a fully voiced 2D game to begin with. Dust has voice acting throughout, for the main character, and every other character you meet, which really aids the immersion in the world.The combat is fun and exciting, and even though it teaches you most of what to do, there are little quirks that you need to discover on your own as well.The story (what I've played through so far) is interesting, and makes me want to find out what happens next.PLAY THIS GAME!

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												11/10 Bashed a rock column with a talking sword and a prestine, fully cooked, ready to eat, roasted chicken fell out when it finally crumbled. Review is edited because this one wouldn't actually post:But in all seriousness...I bought this game for the Xbox360 when it first released, when I had heard it was released for the PC, I didn't hesitate to buy it again, at the full price. Yep, this game was valuable enough to me to BUY IT TWICE.How this game, made by ONE person specifically for the Xbox360, gets a better PC port than most Triple A titles just goes to show the lack-luster effort devs with literally hundreds of millions of dollars at their disposal throw at trying to satisfy their customers. One guy was able to do it better than an entire team of hundreds of people.This calls back to a time when games were made by gamers, for gamers - for enjoyment. Not by Publishers, for money - because f**k you. The game basically sells itself.People look at cliches with a stigma of "It's bad" when really most stories are just variations of the "Seven Basic Plot Points". Without revealing too much you've got: Generally quiet, withdrawn protagonist with memory loss, with the comedic relief side-kick and a literal facist antagonist. If you haven't stopped reading this review by now, buy the game dammit.As for the Genre, it's a heavy mix of Side-Scroller, Beat'Em Up, with some RPG leveling aspects in the background. This is a game you play for the gameplay and the story, not the genre itself, of which Dust: An Elysian Tale can't really figure out which category it's in.Speaking of gameplay, it's more akin to well, Halo's difficulty curve - veteran Halo players will know that Legendary isn't that difficult once you figure out the technique. Enemies hit hard, and have more health the further you push it up. So people looking to be an unstoppable force should start the game on Normal, it's easy enough. The biggest jump between difficulties is that Checkpoints regenerate less and less health the harder the difficulty. 100, 50, 25, and 10 percent respectively from Easiest to Hardest. Once you find an item that regenerates your health, you just go AFK and wait for Dust to heal while you grab a snack or something. I mean you could use all that food you've collected/bought - but why would you? Gotta save that resource, of which you have no limit to the number of items you can hold, all the way to the end of the, by which time you've beaten it and went through like all 14 hours of the game without eating a damn thing while, considering the moves you can pull off, Dust has to be burning like 10000 calories an hour here.Infact, that's probably my one critique, having to handicap yourself to make the game more difficult, even on the hardest difficulty. "BUT REACH IT SAYS YOU HAVEN'T BEAT THE GAME ON TOUGH OR HARDCORE." You got me skippy, I haven't... it's one of the few games for the Xbox360 I have to be completely finished for all achievements, back when it was released.Other things I should probably address:-"REACH, I SEE ANTHROS IN THE TRAILER AND THUMBNAILS UP ABOVE." It's the art style, honestly, I think anthropomorphic characters suit the design and direction better anyway. Pay no attention to it, the characters, save the talking sword, talk mostly normal save a few monologues. This isn't some spat-up Tumblr/Deviantart Anthro R34 garbage. Just by playing the game you can see the time and effort the creator dumped into making this game.-"Reach, why are you posting this review so late in the day if you bought it all the way back when?" I rarely post steam reviews, and only for game I consider to be extraordinary. This was on the front page because of the Steam Summer Sale, 2016 and I went "Huh, I should post a review on that, it's a good game."Ending notes:-Buy it-It's awesome-Lots of fun-Good story-Great gameplay-Feel the effort put into the game-Find all the goodies and extrasFinal thoughts: Didn't get poisioned at all on my first run through of the game. Second play through got over confident and finally got poisoned. Found out there was dialogue for being poisoned the first time. Purposely get poisoned first chance I get for the dialogue. 9/10 missed opportunity first time around.Talking sword said I shouldn't cause an avalanche. Flying nimbat said it was the only way to climb further up the mountain. Protagonist agrees with flying nimbat, not the sword he uses. 8/10 would tell Arrah to f**k off agian.Mouse guy named Avgustin is totally Canadian no matter what anyone says. 10/10 best game ever, most accurate portrayal of a Canadian.Game has hologram projectors to talk to a black smith that can somehow transport materials I'm carrying with me, along with money to the Blacksmith at the top of a huge hill and send them back to me whereever I am. Still only have a sword as a weapon. 7/10 want my Shotgun for fighting zombies.I bashed a metal flying aircraft with a sword, hooked it by the tip and slammed it into the ground. 10/10 MGS Revengence ain't got♥♥♥♥♥♥on Dust: An Elysian Tale.Wet suit has better defense stat than a Chain Mail vest. 3/10 no realism.

Posted: May 27, 2013
												Can't recommend this game enough:- Most satisfying day-one purchase I've made in some time, topping Fez even- The game is the full package - art, music, gameplay, story- Scratches that Metroidvania itch very nicely - best game of this genre I've played since 2008's Castlevania: Order of Ecclesia- The main character handles incredibly gracefully and smoothly, making combat feel like a balletApproximate length: roughly 15 hours to 100%

Posted: July 31, 2016
												Alright-y. I have just finished the game with roughly 14 hours worth of playtime, and oh boy what a game. I loved it. The world was deep and rich with lore, all the characters were well rounded with ample story to give them plenty of life. The main character is well thought out in terms of his purpose and what makes him special. The game can be rather changing and isn't afraid to bite you in the♥♥♥♥♥♥if you aren't ready for it. And the in game secret challenges were well thought out and hard. For a long time I struggled with healing items making it a real challenge fighting all the enemies (specially the bigger ones).  Sometimes I struggled with the direction I had to go and I think that might just be because I was thick. The backdrops and scenery are GORGEOUS they are made so well and there is one in particular that was very eye catching (Giant♥♥♥♥♥statues).The bosses were amazing, and really challenging, especially the last boss he was a real challenge and I found it very fun to verse him even though I had to burn through all my healing items (even on normal holy♥♥♥♥♥♥. However it would have been nice if as I was fighting him the health bar didn't completely refill after every little story moment, it would have been far better to make one health bar and have it drain far slower then in the X number of times you have to fight him after a story moment (I wont tell you how many), both was though do tell you roughly how long the fight is going to go, my way leaves it less a mystery however. I thoroughly enjoyed the music and ambient noises (save for the mansions after you had to do a little running) and the voice acting was top quality though 2 or 3 voices had gotten a little grating at times.Overall it is a great game and I highly recommend it if you love side scrolling fighting games. The mechanics are just right for the game and the way it introduces it to you is just right, just watch out all that clicking may warrant a new mouse (Or J, K and L Keys). The music is perfect and the lore is able to pull you in and keep you interested in the world you are fighting for.9.6/10P.S. I have more hours then this. I just don't have a constant internet connection.

Posted: July 23, 2014
												This game. Is ♥♥♥♥ing FANTASTIC. Oh my god.So it's an excellent, well-designed side-scrolling action RPG with a well-designed, well-polished combat system and awesome graphics, and it runs smoothly on even my garbage 4-year-old laptop. But the real selling point is the storyline. Holy ♥♥♥♥, the storyline. Riveting, well-written, YEARS ahead of what you'd expect from an indie action RPG.Also, quests, a cool, new level-up system, and Fidget.Fidget, the little orange creature seen on the cover of this game, is a selling point on her own. She's cute, funny, she's not just there for fanservice, she actually helps you learn the game mechanics and helps you through the storyline. And she's shaped like an ancient sex goddess. She ♥♥♥♥ing radiates sex appeal in everything she does.Buy this game. Seriously.

Posted: January 11, 2014
												Dust is a great action RPG game. It has decent story and good amount of secrets to uncover. It has  a lot of influences from the old Metroid games from the map system to the "come back when you have the ability to climb here" kind of stuff.I really liked the crafting system, and the side quests give that good extra to the game.The one thing that bugged me a lot was how easy it is, the battle resumes itself as a compulsive button smash craziness. Even the bosses doesn`t require any level of extra ability. Many are even easier than a few regular monsters. If you want some challenge start off at least in hard mode.

Posted: December 7, 2014
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a truly special game.Done in the style of hand-drawn animation, while playing it I couldn't help feeling like I was back in my living room watching the Saturday morning caroons of my youth.  I did experience some display issues (flickering on the screen) but if you're like me, a child of the 80's,  and you experience it, I recommend pretending that you're just watching a well-worn VHS tape.  For me, that just added to the experience and even made it all the more endearing.The story is compelling and you'll likely get sucked in and want to play this exclusively until you get through it.  There are some fun Easter Eggs that you can unlock as you go along as well.  Additionally, the progression is nicely paced between leveling up and the gear that becomes available throughout - I never felt like Neo until the very end despite rarely feeling like I was in danger of dying.I chose not to 100% this game becuase I wanted to save myself some aggravation.  The collectables can be quite challenging to get (or even to find) but there is a wealth of information out there online should you choose to go that route.Between the nostalgic feel and comfortable gameplay, I would recommend this game to anyone.

Posted: January 26, 2015
												Simple, joyous, fun in a wonderfully crafted package. This game has a great deal of heart and though put into it, both of which have been sadly lacking in most independent studios rush to market these days. Every part of this game sings, from it's simple practical platforming to it's top-notch voice acting, to it's combat. The combat will start simple and eventually have you flying through the sky hurling lightning bolts, throwing airships, and striking 800 hit combos. Yes!A note: I held off on playing this game because of the setting. I do not generally enjoy this style of animation, or anthropomorphic animal protaganists. But this game's superior writing and acting absolutely won me over. I played it non-stop for three days, and now I'm sad it's over. Give it a try.

Posted: March 7, 2014
												A very nice game is every aspect.The story is well written in my option. Some cases you can see what is coming a mile away and some you don’t notice until it hits. It flows and should you want to stop the main story and explore some of the side quest it doesn’t stop you. There is only I do believe 21 side quest in the game. But some take a while and others not that long. There is a Yen and Yan ordeal all around the main character, which makes it interesting.Graphics have a neat art/graphical design to it. It is in a way kind of like an anime color to some areas bright and other dark. It is in I do believe a 2d side scroller is what it is called.Character design was also very well done. You will find yourself most likely liking the main character dust and his side kick figet. As well as many of the side characters. They all have their own personality set to them, despite there not being that many other npcs in the game. It makes it worthwhile to just hear what each on has to say. When leveling up your character you get to choice from 4 major areas to level up. My only complaint in this area is the fact that you couldn’t raise a skill more than 4 times without leveling all the other skills. You had to keep all your skills within 4 levels of each other. So you can’t just max out attack or defense if you choice. You will also find yourself looking for better equipment most likely if playing on hard or high difficulty. It has the rpg element to grind mobs for money or items to upgrade or buy better and stronger items.Combat is fun but takes a little getting use to if playing on hard difficulty. It can get a bit addicting in some cases. Especially if lining up combos of over 200. Take note no you are not killing 200 enemies. You are chaining attacks together on 1-6 enemies and possible moving onto the next group while keeping that chain. Depending on you attack damage you can chain bosses very high. Some areas you can run into up to maybe 20+ enemies but that is if you just run past everything and let it follow you.Voice acting is done really well also. Some will say it’s nothing special, but I’ve heard plenty of voice acting in full games that just don't compete with this game. It has a neat art workReplay ability is a little bit of a different story. There is not a lot that will change if you play and start a new game. Only one quest in the game can be changed, depending what choice you choose. Other than that, everything else will play out the same. Not that hard to get all the achievements if you’re looking to get 100% in the game. You could power run though the game in a few hours if you desired, but I took me time and explored and hunted down everything in the game. It took me around 18 hours to complete cause of that. The game is also easy to pick up and stop within minutes of starting the game with save points never being too far away.Difficulty can range from very easy to very hard. Should you wish to play it for just the story but still enjoy the combat, you can set it to easy. This will allow you to die as many time as you wish without hurting your characters progress, story, are the combat you are in. Only drawback is you lose your current chain. Personally you need to set it to hard to even get a challenge out of it. This will make death permanent and you will be sent back to your last save unless you have a revivable stone. Which should you need to you can buy them from shops which have unlimited amounts. You can see all the time the developer took into making this game with the amount of settings and design that went into the game. This game was mostly done by one person over the course of 4 years.  He needs a pat on the back for making such a good game. Really this is how good games should be. Over all this is a great game. And well worth the time and small investment depending if you buy it at full or on sale on steam. In the end you will definitely be tipping your hat to the author.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a side scrolling beat em' up with beautiful 'hand painted' backgrounds, and an exciting story about an amnesia-stricken warrior fighting his way through many unique environments to try and remember who he is.Though the game starts off with a Shadow the Hedgehog vibe, and the dialogue can be sorta cheesy (At least Fidget's, who fits in as the over-excited side kick who doesn't stop talking), it branches away from the "edgy furry confused with the world" as the prologue progresses, and Fidget sorta grows on me.Update:After finishing the game, I can safely say that it was amazing. I didn't finish all the sidequests/get all the treasure yet, but I have about 14 hours on the game. Pretty good amount of gameplay for the money I spent on it. (On sale for $3), but even if I bought it at normal price, it would be worth every penny. The combat in the game is pressing either the right and left mouse buttons, or J and K. All of your attacks will be done with these keys, and you can with dodge/dash forward with Q and E. I've seen people complain how the combat gets stale, but that's not true. Each enemy is designed to be fought a certain way, and you're forced to think strategically when fighting many of them at once. One enemy can be killed with simple melee attacks while the another enemy will parry all of your attacks, and you must strike him right as he's about to attack in order to land a blow on him. This can prove difficult in the later rounds, but it also keeps the game interesting.My only real complaint about the game is the boss difficulty. In Normal Mode, the bosses are not that hard. The first boss is one of the easiest intimidating bosses I've ever fought, so I was a bit disappointed, especially because he's a key part of the story. You'd think he'd prove more difficult to fight. Each boss, obviously gets harder to fight, and the final boss fight is very satisfying in terms of difficulty. But the difficulty in general seemed too easy, but perhaps I'll just need to replay the game on Hard mode.To conclude;The story is great, the designs are great, and while many people will ignore the game solely because of the animal characters, I'm glad I gave this game a shot. The combat is exciting, the enemies are unique, the environments are beautiful and the story is compelling. While some bosses are too easy ( or I'm too good :^) ), the Final Boss stands as quite a challenge, and defeating him rewards you with an ending that truly settles the dust.I'd give it a 9/10, I highly reccomend it.

Posted: December 28, 2015
												Forget "for the price tag" or "for an indie game", Dust: An Elysian Tail is an amazing experience which really reignited a passion for gaming that I wasn't sure if I had any more.This is not an 'artsy' game, although it does sport some of the best artistic direction that I've ever seen in a videogame, accompanied by a brilliant soundtrack. The story and characters, whilst kept behind gameplay in priority, are likeable and easy to follow. A few inconsistancies here and there, but an enjoyable experience with enough sidequests and secrets to keep you playing for 20 hours, easily.The mechanics are tight -- if you die, most of the time you're going to feel like it was your fault rather than the game cheesing you out of a death. I only played on hardcore mode, because I found the difficulty on this level was at the perfect point between challenging and tedious. One of my few gripes about the game is that the save spots could have been more considerately placed. I often found that after dying, I was re-doing tedious but simple parts of the game. The save spots should be after the tedious but simple parts, not before them. I want to re-do the part I died on, not the three screens before it (here's to you, Sorrowing Meadows).I did run into two possibly Linux-only issues, one was some sound distortion in certain areas of the game which required me to reduce the volume, and another was an issue with one of the secret rooms not displaying correctly. I e-mailed the developer about the latter issue and within an hour, had a response saying it is being looked into this week.The game's difficulty curve is brilliant, introducing new concepts and abilities as the game goes on so as not to overload the player with one of those half-hour tutorials which most of us skip. The first area is easy, and the final boss will challenge all of your mechanical abilities. I suggest starting on the highest difficulty level and working your way down if it's not enjoyable, it feels like Dust was designed to be played on hardcore.There is plenty of endgame content, as I'm finding with over 20 hours played that I still find things to do and treasures I haven't found yet. I have thoroughly enjoyed this game, and struggle to recall the last time I had this much fun playing a videogame.Thank you, Humble Hearts. I look forward to the next one.

Posted: July 5, 2016
												Dust: An Elysian Tale is one of the best side scrolling action platformer out there! It features a great story, some rpg elements and some metroidvania style upgrades! You control Dust on his quest to find who he is and you are accompanied by 2 quite colorful characters, the blade of Ahrah, a sentient artifact sword that has a serious and mentor-like character and that you use for combat, and Fidget, the guardian of the sword and a comical character overall, she will make you giggle quite many times!Firsts things first! The visuals are marvelously pleasing, an eye candy of sorts! The animations for both Dust and the enemies feel fluid and clean making combat a good feature instead of a filler through the story parts. The sounds and music as well as voice acting are right on point making the game an even greater gaming experience. To add to that the story is really compelling as you will find yourself, quite many times, in a spot where you will want to play just a bit more to uncover the next part. To add to that it’s the type of the game where I didn’t want to finish, as the gameplay, along with the story left me with a void when I finished it.The main features of the game is its combat and exploration. The combat can be as easy or as demanding as you like, as the games difficulty affects this aspect only. Easy difficulty will result in enemies dying easily and doing less damage as well as you healing at check points, while higher difficulties can result in certain enemies being able to kill you if you don’t counter at the right time. Generally you have your base attacks and combos that you can do with Ahrah, and with Fidgets help you can unleash a powerful duststorm that will serve as your aoe attack. Small and normal sized enemies, besides bosses, do not require any special approach. However bigger enemies, like rock giants and trolls, can be a threat! Shield wielding enemies are immune to frontal attacks and since they will always face you, you need to counter their attack in order to stun them. While stunned all enemies take a lot more damage, so countering does feel rewarding no matter the enemy!  If you want that extra satisfaction from this game, I recommend higher difficulties for your first playthrough.As you progress the game you will earn experience and upgrades for your skills. Experience is gained from completing quests, main or side, talking to characters and by killing enemies. Additionally while you kill enemies you can chain hit them, resulting in a combo meter, after the combat ends you will get additional experience depending your combo meter! Each level up will give you a stat point that you can use to increase 1 out of 4 base stats. Attack, Defense, Health and Fidged (yes she is actually a stat too!). The first 3 are obvious to what they offer, Fidget on the other hand increases the potency of your aoe, the duststorm. Personally this was my favored stat as I used duststorm a lot and because you will find gear that sadly overshadows the increase one skill point adds to that stat.  Also as you venture the lands of Elysium you will encounter certain shrines that will either augment a skill or give you a new one, skills like sliding or climbing are in this category. Finally after each major boss you will get an upgrade for duststorm, giving Fidged a new element for it! The cool part of this system is that you get to visit older areas, that were previously had an exit out of reach, to find secrets or easter eggs and the challenges! The challenges are hidden rooms with speedrun courses. You do not have to ace them to get the reward but if you like the challenge you can try get those 4 stars! All these are marked to your map, so you can see each areas completion and where is something hidden, the twist is, that besides that info, you do not have detailed map of each area, so you need to explore it yourself!The controls are easy to grasp and fully customizable, keyboard or controller. Having tried both I did not find a more favorable, it depends on your playstyle!The only negative of the game is its crafting feature. Throughout the game you will find blueprints for gear that once you gather the materials required you cab craft. However quite many times the vendor offered the best version for a slot or even after making a good gear for a slot, inferior gear and blueprints dropped. Generally I did not get to use the crafting system that much since I rarely got an actual upgrade.Overall, Dust: An Elysian Tale is a great game, and a game that definitely is worthy of its price! I recommend it with my eyes closed!-------------------------------------------I reviewed this game for the steamified group.For similar reviews and great giveaways feel free to visit http://www.steamified.com

Posted: April 29, 2014
												Probably the most cliched, hackneyed story ever. The gameplay is pretty repetitive and degenerate, and there are numerous extremely exploitative mechanics that make the game's challenges ridiculously trival.It's cute, I guess, but extremely overrated. The hand-drawn art is actually pretty bad, with the exception of Fidget. I feel like much more effort was spent drawing her than every other character in the game. The other characters have really awkward proportions and look really terrible. Dust looks OK until he takes his hat off or you look at him from any perspective except the ones shown in the normal dialogue windows.Criticism aside, onto the good points. The gameplay looks really good. For all the mediocre drawing, the ingame character art works really well and the particle effects look nice. Visually the game can get very cluttered and noisy, but the individual elements look really good.The voice talent is really good. Fidget's voice actress (who is also Miss Fortune from Skullgirls) really executes the character well. Dust's voice actor is, for the most part, really well-executed too. The other characters aren't quite as well-done, but this is probably due to fewer takes than it is a lack of talent on the part of the actors and actresses. The main issue with the voices is really that the writing is so terrible that it's impossible to take the characters seriously.The best parts of the game are in the middle, when the characters aren't talking about anything serious. The lightharted banters are really the strength of the game. Unfortunately, this is hampered by the repetitive and exploitable gameplay.Dust's moveset is very limited, with only three ground combos and one air combo. In total he has a whopping 5 different options total, including both in the air and on the ground. Most of his moveset is obsoleted by Fidget, whose spells can be comboed with Dust's 'dust attack' to unleash completely absurd magical hell all over the screen. Her magical power can be amplified so much that the final boss can be defeated in only a few spells without ever requiring any risk even on the hardest difficulty setting.It's hard not to recommend this game though, if only because of what this game represents. I'd like to see more games like this, with a bit more polish. It really shows that the game was created by one person, but that doesn't mean it's necessarily bad. I do hope that the people behind the game observe the failings of this title and go on to create newer and better things.

Posted: July 11, 2016
												Dust: An Elysian Tail starts off with a very simple concept, yet it stands up to what it promises.Speaking of the gameplay, it's platforming mixed with action fighting.The fighting system is rather simple, you have a few skills need to learn to use in the right combination and situation considering the hazards around you and the enemies you're facing. Especially on higher difficulties, you really want to know what enemies can stagger after how many hits, or when you need the energy to dodge instead of using Fidget attacks. Knowing your surroundings is mandatory as you need to manage your movements while fighting. The attacks and combos are limited, but that means you have less to work on, and you need to make the best with what you have.The platforming parts are fun, but they can get really annoying, especially on higher difficulties: Playing Hardcore from the start, I found myself loading and repeating the same sections lots of times, since the damage the obstacles deal are increased with difficulty. I guess it's my fault for making a mistake if I land on a spike, but when I find myself in front of unpredictable hostacles, I can't really be blamed, since the lack of regular pattern just made me jump towards my own death, or sometimes you'll find yourself stopping a jump in midair to avoid that obstacle falling on other ones (Like Mudpot mushrooms and Mountain icicles). Another annoying thing was the trials: fun challenge, but a restart option would have been nice since you need an almost perfect run to get 4-star ratings, instead of having to clear the whole course just to get another shot at it.The classic RPG-styled system for EXP, gold and items is nicely managed. Except for the huge boost you get from almost-end game items, the character build up speed is just right to keep a good challenge if one doesn't stop grinding at the first obstacle. The only problem I could find is that you'll need to buy usable health items even if you're in a town, where there could be a classic inn to fill up your health bar (I found myself buying from the town store after clearing a dungeon where the only damage I got was from the last rooms, usually containing bosses).The game experience in general is quite astonishing. There are some clichés here and there, but the storyline and ambience are what really got me.  Trying to understand who the protagonist is during the main quest, how he behaves, Fidget, the rising climax towards the end of the storyline really got me glued to the screen. The variety of landscape, ambients, enemies, and weather are simple yet effective addictions to an original art style. Some sloppy animation during cinematics, but consindering what I just said, it's not a big deal.Intriguing storyline after the amnesia cliché starts developing, Fidget, exciting gameplay, original art style, Fidget, variety of characters and landscape, Fidget... If you have the chance, give it a go, you won't regret it. I'd say a solid 9/10

Posted: December 5, 2013
												This game... this game is easily the greatest game ever created in my opinion.  To be made by one man, with such beautiful art, solid game mechanics, and an absolutely amazing story with incredible charcters; it just is a work of art.  Never before has a game immersed me so much, made me love and cherish the characters like none before it.  This is a game that can be a challenge if desired, or it could simply be an immersive story.  You will learn the truth about Dust's past through an adventure with so many characters that grab your heart.  With Fidget by his side, and with her comic relief, you will slowly slip into an entirely new world.  Nothing can compare to it.  When you finally beat the game, you will feel as though your entire life has been changed forever, and can never feel like this again.  Ashes to ashes, Dust to dust...

Posted: January 5, 2016
												What can I say that hasn't already been said a bunch of times:  Just get the damn game!!!!!  Dust is what a fun 2D platformer is all about.1)  It has a story.  It doesn't break new grounds, but most games don't.  With that said, it is told not only well, but at the right pace.  It doesn't drag, nor does it race along.  It has a well though out plot, and an ending that will stay with you.2)  It makes you explore.  It isn't the most complicated map, but it has enough visit and revisit spots to keep those of us that like to find everything happy.   There are several spots on map and moving to and fro is quick and painless.  The places themselves get progressively more difficult to initially spot where hidden treasures are, but not mean spiritied or impossible like some games I could name.3)  Voice acting.  It doesn't stand out at all and from me that is the greatest compliment.  I can't stand VA that is so over the top, or the opposite that is just so god awful that you want to turn the sound  off and read subtitles.  The VA meshes perfectly with the story.4)  Artwork.  It is a nice blend of cartoonish hand painted with effects mesh.  It is also a perfect fit for the feel of the game.5)  Combat.  Combat is easy to as hard as you wat to make it with the different combos, but definitely forgiving.  It's not meant to be a brutal test, but it offers enough of a challenge to be satisfying.6)  Fun Factor.  So many platformers have zero replayability, especially story driven ones.  You finish and move on.  I played, replayed because I missed a couple of achievements, and then played again just to enjoy.  This is a game that will stay in your library as an old friend that you will just have to re-visit every once in a while.Overall, I would say if you are looking for a hard game to challenge you this is not the one.  If you are looking for an absolute joy of an experience do not pass up this game.  I can't wait to see what's next from the dev's!!!!!  Cheers!
