Posted: February 28, 2016
												Dust is a 2-D hack & slash action platformer with RPG elements and branching paths, similar to the Castlevania series.  Unlike those games, however, Dust eschews heavy exploration and technical battles in favor of lightning-fast mobility and hordes of enemies that will often have the player racking up combos of several hundred hits as they leap from target to target seamlessly without ever touching the ground.APPROXIMATE LENGTH10 hours for the main story, plus another 10 for all the sidequests & secretsPROS(+) The combat system is magnificent both mechanically and visually: easy to learn, fun to use, and amazing to watch(+) Beautiful visual style in both backgrounds and sprites(+) Music is fully orchestrated and blends well with the settings(+) Complete voice acting for all dialog, with high quality performances all around(+) Fidget is adorable and hilariousCONS(-) Plot & dialog can get pretty melodramatic(-) Items & crafting system is little more than a forced burden(-) Animated cutscenes are of mediocre quality and feel out of place(-) Difficulty curve starts very steep, then overabundant healing items make the game too easyYOUR MILEAGE MAY VARY(?) All characters are anthropomorphic “furries”.  Some people like that.  Others don’t.OVERALLDust is a game that is just plain fun to play and experience, and feels very professionally made.  Has some issues, but overall delivers on what it sets out to do.

												Quite the charming game, the amount of love and care that has gone into its production is evident from the off. Posted: February 18
												This game is superb. If you are looking for a great indie 2D action platformer, this is a game to get. The game mixes level-by-level gameplay of older side scrolling games with secret hunting and exploration of a metroidvania.  Fuse that with a combo system that actively rewards the player with bonus XP for playing skillfully and you have one amazingly fun action-platform-metroidvania-brawler-whatever-it-is-but-who-cares-it's-great. The first thing that will hit you is the amazing hand-drawn art and animations. This is an absolutely beautiful game to behold. The voice acting is a bit spotty at times but overall, well executed. The bomb sprout puzzles are a bit tedious but so satisfying when you solve them, bosses were way too easy but still fun none the less, some of the diolague can be excized as it outright tells you a puzzle solution, but it doesn't handhold so often that it becomes patronizing, and the ester eggs are just adorable. I haven't found half of the secrets this game holds, so there's still a lot of stuff left for me to do. But, I did complete the story; I will not spoil the ending but I will say it is an ending that leaves lots of mixed emotions, but in a good way. TL;DR the game isn't perfect, but no game is. This is the most fun I had in a 2D game since Castlevania: Symphony of the Night. Some nitpicks here and there but those could be attributed to the fact that the development team was one person, and a multi-man team could have made more mistakes than fixed them. Overall, this game is a 9/10, one of my favorites, and it definately deserves the overwhelmingly positive reception it gets.

Posted: January 24, 2016
												Excellent platformer. The visuals are outstanding. Each location is gorgeous. The crafting system, while limited, is simple and wields worthwhile results. The story is entertaining with moments are sadness. The revelation of who Dust is was unexpected and creative, an outcome that worked extremely well with the story being told.The combat is simple and enjoyable, though it does grow repetitive and tiresome after a while. It's basically hack and slash your way through everything with a few special moves thrown in.The voice acting is solid, though a little over-acted at times. Fidget added a lot of humor to the story, though some people might find her high-pitched voice annoying.It's a very linear game but as you progress and gain new abilities, you are able to go back through levels and acquire treasures. The treasures aren't particularly mind-blowing, though I did get an excellent ring at the end. Most of my best items were acquired through crafting. I finished the game without 100% completing all the treasures, but never felt a need to go after them. By 7-8 hours into the game, I just wanted to finish, due to the repetitive combat. The last area or two did mix things up a bit with increasingly difficult platformer aspects. My game froze repeatedly with one glitch in the Abadis Forest. It wasn't game-breaking though would have prevented 100% completion. Other than that, the game ran excellently on my PC. XBOX wired controller for Windows worked great. Seemless switching between controller and keyboard/mouse, but I did play exclusively on controller.

Posted: December 26, 2015
												Nothing much to addThe game is a marvelous piece of art. Although the storyline is relatively straightforward and perhaps predictable, its gameplay makes it up for it. As a Metroidvania, you are continuously being challenged of revisting areas once you have unlocked new skills. However, this doesn't mean you can't try it without acquiring the skills. The majority of hidden secrets and/or treasures in each level is designed that it can be visited when not having the right skill. Having the right skill does make it easier on the other hand, but less of a challenge. Had enough of visiting areas? You can always try to think of practicing your skills by chaining your combos. Besides its gameplay, the soundtrack is extremely well done. Each piece of music fits the moment making it a great enjoyment for the ears when walking through the same area again due to backtracking.However, the game does suffer from a couple of small glitches. Interaction windows popping up while being far away from the shops or savepoints and in battle does hamper the game a bit. While not necessarily gamebreaking, it might be experienced as a nuisance when trying to chain a combo hit.Conclusion:For a game that has been written, programmed and drawn by one single person is an amazing feature. Even more amazing is that all elements in the game fit perfectly together: the gameplay and the OST are very well thought and executed. However, it doesn't mean the game doesn't suffer from some minor glitches. Interaction windows that unexpectedly pop up might be a bit annoying, but are not necessarily gamebreaking.Pro:+ Great OST+ Amazing art work+ Challenging gameplay: difficulty can be adjusted when necesary+ Good level design: majority of the secrets can be reached early in game for a bigger challenge. Having the adequate skill later in game facilitates reaching these secretsCons:- Game suffers from minor glitches at times- Storyline is a bit predictable

Posted: December 28, 2013
												I highly recommend this game to anyone who's a fan of "Metroidvania" style exploration-based action adventure games. This game is most reminiscent to me of Castlevania: Order of Ecclesia in how the game is split up into multiple explorable areas linked together by a world map (as opposed to it being just one huge map like many of this style of game have). Also, as with this style of game, backtracking is a must as there will always be some section of the map or hidden chest that you just can't reach without one of the additional abilities you'll learn throughout the game. But they do make it easy to figure out where you need to return to thanks to a helpful map system.Fluid animation, great art style and voice acting, and an engaging narrative also give this game a high recommendation from me.

Posted: June 27, 2013
												You will often find, among gamers and critics alike, diverse opinions that state the positives and negatives of various games, with things such as "the game is good" or "the game was too short" or "the controls suck."This is not the case with Dust: An Elysian Tail.  I have been a gamer my entire life, ostracized as a child in school by the very people now addicted to Call of Duties and Madden NFLs.  I have watched the evolution of gaming from the 8-and-16-bit era of Mario and Sonic, the evolution of PC gaming from text based RPGs to DragonAge and Skyrim.Of all the games I have played, from casual Runescape to the intensely cerebral Europa Universalis, from the flashy twitch gaming of Smash Brothers to the thought-out fights of Guild Wars.  "Dust: An Elysian Tail" is by far one of the most defining creations in the Gaming Industry.  What makes it more spectacular and amazing is the story of a single man hand-drawing and developing the game from scratch over years, of an indie developer given a chance on Xbox Arcade.Dead Dodrill has brought to us a game that, in collaboration with secondary writer Alex Kain, and composers Alexander Brandon and HypderDuck Soundworks, defines everything we love about gaming.  He brings us back to the core elements of a video game.I can say, without a doubt in my mind, that Dust: An Elysian Tail is, by far, the greatest representation of Video Games as an Artform.  If there ever any confusion or concern if games could be consider Art, Dead Dodrill has proved us otherwise.No amount of praise I could give would satisfy my love for this game.  For 17 years, Blizzard Entertainment's Starcraft franchise has held a special place in my heart as my favorite game of all time.  Upon completion of this artistic masterwork, I can say that this has changed.Dean Dodrill, Alexander Brandon, and everyone else that not only made this game possible, but brought it to the attention of the general public.  I thank you, and I heartily reccommend this game for anyone.

Posted: January 5, 2016
												What can I say that hasn't already been said a bunch of times:  Just get the damn game!!!!!  Dust is what a fun 2D platformer is all about.1)  It has a story.  It doesn't break new grounds, but most games don't.  With that said, it is told not only well, but at the right pace.  It doesn't drag, nor does it race along.  It has a well though out plot, and an ending that will stay with you.2)  It makes you explore.  It isn't the most complicated map, but it has enough visit and revisit spots to keep those of us that like to find everything happy.   There are several spots on map and moving to and fro is quick and painless.  The places themselves get progressively more difficult to initially spot where hidden treasures are, but not mean spiritied or impossible like some games I could name.3)  Voice acting.  It doesn't stand out at all and from me that is the greatest compliment.  I can't stand VA that is so over the top, or the opposite that is just so god awful that you want to turn the sound  off and read subtitles.  The VA meshes perfectly with the story.4)  Artwork.  It is a nice blend of cartoonish hand painted with effects mesh.  It is also a perfect fit for the feel of the game.5)  Combat.  Combat is easy to as hard as you wat to make it with the different combos, but definitely forgiving.  It's not meant to be a brutal test, but it offers enough of a challenge to be satisfying.6)  Fun Factor.  So many platformers have zero replayability, especially story driven ones.  You finish and move on.  I played, replayed because I missed a couple of achievements, and then played again just to enjoy.  This is a game that will stay in your library as an old friend that you will just have to re-visit every once in a while.Overall, I would say if you are looking for a hard game to challenge you this is not the one.  If you are looking for an absolute joy of an experience do not pass up this game.  I can't wait to see what's next from the dev's!!!!!  Cheers!

Posted: August 1, 2016
												I really enjoyed the game "despite" the gameplay issues I mention below. To be honest the atmosphere simply sucks you in and the mix of platforming, combat and RPG works out quite well. Positives- A game with a signature mechanic which looks and feels very, very cool. - A good amount of combat and platforming. The latter becomes increasingly trickier.- Stunning graphics. Basically all of them are hand-made. - Great music and voice acting is well-done.- Cliché story (homage to retro games) with a good twist.- A good mix of serious and cheesy/funny dialogues.- RPG Elements such as customizing your different pieces of armor. Upgrades are available throughout the entire game. - Very gamer-friendly mechanics. No material grinding or unnecessary backtracking! - Talking to NPCs is literally rewarding as each dialogue grants exp - and often a side-quest. - Opening treasure chests is fun as each of them requires you to beat a mini-game. - Completing the game grants you a rather unique reward!- Many Easter eggs and references to older games.Negatives- Gameplay... is the biggest issue as the combat becomes very repetitive. 1) Spamming two moves is not only the strongest, but also the most-exp-earning move in the game. 2) The main character doesn't learn any new combat moves. 3) Later on in the game, most of your regular moves will be blocked, so we're back at 1).  4) Intermediate and chapter bosses don't feel that much different from regular mobs. - "Normal" gamemode is not challenging at all, even for average players like myself. There is no difficulty spike. I'd recommend playing it on a harder setting from the very beginning. - 1 mandatory BS Indie game secret (which the game openly admits with a cutscene). - Only one coin of the story is shown. Unfortunately the other half was cut due to time pressure (more information available in the post-mortem which you can find on the discussion boards).

Posted: April 1
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a beautiful game. The art style is so entrancing that it's worth noting how easy it is to get drawn into this world before discussing anything else. Yes, it has anthropomorphic protagonists, but that really shouldn't keep you from giving this game a chance. The combat is tight and fast paced, providing some challenge without ever feeling overwhelming. I was able to get through most of the game without too much trouble fighting enemies, all of which match each location well and build a world you want to explore. I came much closer to 100%-ing the game than I ever planned to, because I had so much fun using the game's many platforming mechanics to explore every inch of each level. There are plenty of collectibles for people who enjoy that kind of thing, but if you'd rather plow through each level and just complete the story, you'll still have a great time. I do want to give the writing some credit here. While I can't say I was particularly surprised by where it led, the game does a great job fleshing out the characters and getting the player invested in uncovering the secrets that hide what really happened in our hero's past (yes, it's an amnesia story. Yes, it goes exactly where you think it will. No, that doesn't hurt your enjoyment of this game). The variety of movement options to explore the map are all fun and rewarding when you pull off each combo just right. I'm still amazed all of this was created by a solo developer. It truly raises the bar for a personal project like this.If I had to give a criticism, I'd say the ending is a pretty harsh difficulty spike. The final boss has multiple steps to it, and the final level is WAY more difficult that anything you've played to that point. It's not brutal, per se, but it does feel like a more gradual curve could have helped brace the player for enemies who know how to block your combos effectively. However, this is the most minor of nitpicks.I loved this game, and if you enjoy story-based adventure/platformers, you'll likely love this too. I couldn't recommend it more highly.

Posted: April 3
												Dust is a medium sized, hack'n'slash/platformer/RPG with big bucks behind (similar to what got the famous 2012 game, journey).The game graphics are rich and beautiful.  The animation is great. Dust animation is "anime-like" in contrast with the non-playable characters who get a smooth animation. The story is good enough for me. The sound (including voices) and the music (final fantasy-ish) are on the same high level. But I still wonder how they managed to draw such an ugly world map.The gameplay is relatively easy assuming you are patient enough to be grinding XP for levels. The gameplay will be boring/repetitive, because some stages are a bit too long, and many times, suffer from a lack of "density of action". That knowing you will have to re-run many stages several times with different abilities in order to acheive 100% completion... also there, you will be grinding XP for levels in order to make the game clearable.There is a common default in RPGs: either you miss levels and the game is super hard, either you did a lot of boring XP grinding and the game is super easy because you are way over-leveled. So the stages are calibrated to be reasonably clearable at a specific level: if you are below, it's unreasonable, if you are above, it's too easy. This balance issue should be addressed in all RPGs, here it's not the case then you are free to torture yourself like a masochist or get bored at over-leveling your Dust and then slice throught the game like a hot knife in butter.Technically, I got a few bugs (exceptions), and the controls felt slooooow/unresponsive in fight. It does run on linux based OSes with a recent mesa3D.On the overall, I do recommend this game.

												So, first of all, this is my first review.Difficulty: Normal; 17h played; lvl 46 - 47Something to the game and the chars.* The game is a 2D World in the art of the Trine game-series.* Each time you left a map-square, it will respawn (endless farm & lvl potential until maximum ?).* The combat system is simple but is entertaining; you have some combos you can easily do like jump hit 3 times and right click to throw your enemy to the ground, especially good in the late stage in my opinion.* There are 12 (?) friends you can "unlock"; each gives you a +5% HP bonus.* Fidget seems extremely childish and annoying during the good first half of the main quest.* Dust don't know who he is and is looking for answers, which makes him sometimes angry because of mental pressure.* Ahrah is the blade which Dust is carrying. He speaks with Dust and advise him through the magical journey.* If you are on the map, you can watch upwards and see Fidget eating or sleeping on a tree bough.* You can forge your weapons; they aren't always buyable in the shop.Story.Pretty much this: Dust.The entire story is build around the main character which we as customers are playing. Dust wanders through the world and helps people. He seems to remember them all, but no one remembers him. You will interact in the world and you have up to three or four dialogue options.You will find many quests through your way in the world.A note here: It's a deep philosophical game; it handles about life and death and about his understanding in the world.Positives and Dislike.The only thing I dislike are the fact that self-made weapons aren't more gold worth, while selling, than the actual cost of forging it. Posted: October 30, 2013
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a piece of art. I'm not a big fan of side-scrollers, not because I don't like the concept of sidescrolling games itself, but because they usually don't offer what this game has. Story, good characters, good RPG elements (not just leveling up - side quests too, with their own stories!).The story is fine, it's not really solid as a rock, but it is still pretty interesting and makes you want to keep playing. But the big deal here are the characters. Every character in the game has a perfectly defined personality, and in certain situations you may even emotionally engage with them. The voice acting is amazingly good for a video game, which helps.The music is pretty well done, and there are several memorable tracks (especially at the beginning of the game... and at the end).The art style is very appealing, almost everything is made on 2D, every scenery is colorful and full of details and the animations are smooth and feel damn fine. And the characters are furries. I think it has a resemblance to Captain Claw.Now about the gameplay: it's awesome. There's a limited amount of moves to use, but they're enough, and combined with all that the character can do (dodge/sprint, parry, "gliding" and more) it just make you feel amazingly empowered.There are a lot of challenges you can do and RPG elements, and they truly make the game more fun. Treasure hunting, item crafting, side quests, and even some kind of... parkour-dungeons or whatever, if you feel like testing your skills.

Posted: October 18, 2014
												I can't say enough good about this game. When I first saw the trailer, I had high hopes. I knew it was going to be good. And when I did finally buy it, my expectations were more than exceeded - and that's an understatement. It is incredibly fun to play, and offers a decent amount of challenge even on the easiest difficulty setting; at least, it did for me. I'll do my best to keep this review spoiler-free.I'll start with the obvious protagonist, Dust. A living mystery, he's a little bit of a rogue; even though he's on the side of good and has a strong sense of valor and justice, he's not afraid to cut down any who oppose him or threaten the innocent. He's a bit generic at first glance, but some people (me) find a really cool character under that equally cool hat.The hack-and-slash combat can be either really fun or really boring, depending on the person. A rather small variety of techniques are available to use from the beginning. You can uppercut your target to the skies to perform aerial strikes, parry and counterattack from the ground, or just button-mash to cleave your way through the crowd. You can also launch projectiles that are weak at first, but then amplify their power to wreak mass destruction upon the battleground. Projectiles can range from magic missiles to fireballs, which can be powered up to missile storms or flame pillars.The music is probably the best part about this game. I can't get enough of it. Sometimes it's calm, and sometimes it's tense. But it's always encouraging, thrilling, and outright epic. There's nothing like dashing through a rainstorm and slashing down monsters with that loud, exhilarating violin and piano in the background.The story is linear and straightfoward, but is really quite touching at some points. Dust travels through the land of Falana after waking up without memory. A magic sword arrives as his generic sage-guide, and leads him to specific areas because reasons. Throughout the story, Dust helps out whoever he can and takes down villains, all the while trying to find clues as to who he really is. Though not much is explained, a big reveal near the end clears up a lot of potential confusion and can be traced back to the beginning of the game. While the story is linear, it's still pretty well thought out.The characters are a little flat. While most people in the game have distinct personalities, they usually just have one character trait and can be described in about two sentences. However, that does not mean that they can't be charming. You'll meet a lot of people throughout the game, and while each one has his or her own unique role, whether you love or hate them is entirely up to you.One of the biggest elements of this game is the treasure hunting. There is a limited number of keys hidden throughout the world, and each one is expended after opening a treasure chest. Some treasure is very easy to find, especially in the early levels, but some is really cleverly hidden. Sometimes you might actually have to read a note that you picked up to be able to find a secret! The horror!There are, of course, a few cons to this game. However, they are rather minor.There's not much replayability. More or less, it feels like the same game over and over again. Although it's great to experience the story again, and the higher difficulties add much more challenge, it's not a game that will last forever.Combat is precise but strange. Sometimes, if you fall from a large height, one or two enemies will be waiting for you on a lower platform and will attack as soon as you land. It takes either great reflexes or a bit of luck to avoid damage from these "ambushes."The boss fights are basic and potentially unmemorable. They have little to no strategy and can be beaten by simply spamming The Undoing, which strikes your target helpless and throws them to the ground for massive damage.I still love them, though.It is definitely not the longest game in the world, and once you've done everything story-related, completed all of the sidequests, and collected all of the treasure, there's not much else. In fact, it's the exploration and treasure hunting that stretches the game out. The story itself is rather short and linear, and the game has quite a closed end.I love this game and usually like to defend it. However, it does have its minor problems. All in all, though, the game is a masterpiece, especially when you consider that most of it was done by one guy alone. I'd like present to Dust: An Elysian Tail a score of 9/10.

Posted: May 30, 2015
												Great metroidvania.Dust: An elysian Tail is a a 2d hack and slash platformer.PlotYou play as a swordsman called 'Dust' who has amnesia and finds himself in a forest. Along with a couple of entertaining companions, Dust will explore the land of Falana through mountains, forests, volcanos and tunnels solving quests, stopping genocidal monsters and finding the truth about his dark past...GameplayDust plays similar to metroid and castlevania games. The game is seperated into areas  which can be reached by moving from one end of the screen to the other (left to right and vice versa). There are platforming elements incorporporated, with you needing to use a few moves to reach certain places, though it's not as difficult unlike guacamalee. Combat is a great. You start of with limited moves with your one and only weapon, the Blade of Ahrah. As you defeat enemies you gain experience points which you can use to upgrade health, stamina and unlock new moves. You also find money which is used to buy items (like health recovery etc) at stores in the few towns you visit. Along your travels you will encounter a variety of foes including mines, melee guys, zombies, gjosts and gunships. There are also some boss battles in the game as well. Besides followuing the main quest, there are a few side quests you can partake in which offer a variety of rewards in return.  I played this game with a controller and I highly recommend you do the same as it feels more fluid and natural than keyboard and mouse.GraphicsMost of the graphics are great. The 2D animations are colourful and attractive to look at. However, the 3D models aren't well detailed and doesn't fit well with the 2D sprites. Overall howeevr, the game looks vibrant to look at.AudioExcellent. The character voice acting for the main charcters are great and humorous (in a good way).   Other voice acting is decent. The music is great to listen to and fits well with the game. An excellent and entertaining game that will surprise and satisfy fans of metrodvania and new comers alike.

Posted: October 18, 2014
												I can't say enough good about this game. When I first saw the trailer, I had high hopes. I knew it was going to be good. And when I did finally buy it, my expectations were more than exceeded - and that's an understatement. It is incredibly fun to play, and offers a decent amount of challenge even on the easiest difficulty setting; at least, it did for me. I'll do my best to keep this review spoiler-free.I'll start with the obvious protagonist, Dust. A living mystery, he's a little bit of a rogue; even though he's on the side of good and has a strong sense of valor and justice, he's not afraid to cut down any who oppose him or threaten the innocent. He's a bit generic at first glance, but some people (me) find a really cool character under that equally cool hat.The hack-and-slash combat can be either really fun or really boring, depending on the person. A rather small variety of techniques are available to use from the beginning. You can uppercut your target to the skies to perform aerial strikes, parry and counterattack from the ground, or just button-mash to cleave your way through the crowd. You can also launch projectiles that are weak at first, but then amplify their power to wreak mass destruction upon the battleground. Projectiles can range from magic missiles to fireballs, which can be powered up to missile storms or flame pillars.The music is probably the best part about this game. I can't get enough of it. Sometimes it's calm, and sometimes it's tense. But it's always encouraging, thrilling, and outright epic. There's nothing like dashing through a rainstorm and slashing down monsters with that loud, exhilarating violin and piano in the background.The story is linear and straightfoward, but is really quite touching at some points. Dust travels through the land of Falana after waking up without memory. A magic sword arrives as his generic sage-guide, and leads him to specific areas because reasons. Throughout the story, Dust helps out whoever he can and takes down villains, all the while trying to find clues as to who he really is. Though not much is explained, a big reveal near the end clears up a lot of potential confusion and can be traced back to the beginning of the game. While the story is linear, it's still pretty well thought out.The characters are a little flat. While most people in the game have distinct personalities, they usually just have one character trait and can be described in about two sentences. However, that does not mean that they can't be charming. You'll meet a lot of people throughout the game, and while each one has his or her own unique role, whether you love or hate them is entirely up to you.One of the biggest elements of this game is the treasure hunting. There is a limited number of keys hidden throughout the world, and each one is expended after opening a treasure chest. Some treasure is very easy to find, especially in the early levels, but some is really cleverly hidden. Sometimes you might actually have to read a note that you picked up to be able to find a secret! The horror!There are, of course, a few cons to this game. However, they are rather minor.There's not much replayability. More or less, it feels like the same game over and over again. Although it's great to experience the story again, and the higher difficulties add much more challenge, it's not a game that will last forever.Combat is precise but strange. Sometimes, if you fall from a large height, one or two enemies will be waiting for you on a lower platform and will attack as soon as you land. It takes either great reflexes or a bit of luck to avoid damage from these "ambushes."The boss fights are basic and potentially unmemorable. They have little to no strategy and can be beaten by simply spamming The Undoing, which strikes your target helpless and throws them to the ground for massive damage.I still love them, though.It is definitely not the longest game in the world, and once you've done everything story-related, completed all of the sidequests, and collected all of the treasure, there's not much else. In fact, it's the exploration and treasure hunting that stretches the game out. The story itself is rather short and linear, and the game has quite a closed end.I love this game and usually like to defend it. However, it does have its minor problems. All in all, though, the game is a masterpiece, especially when you consider that most of it was done by one guy alone. I'd like present to Dust: An Elysian Tail a score of 9/10.

Posted: October 30, 2013
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a piece of art. I'm not a big fan of side-scrollers, not because I don't like the concept of sidescrolling games itself, but because they usually don't offer what this game has. Story, good characters, good RPG elements (not just leveling up - side quests too, with their own stories!).The story is fine, it's not really solid as a rock, but it is still pretty interesting and makes you want to keep playing. But the big deal here are the characters. Every character in the game has a perfectly defined personality, and in certain situations you may even emotionally engage with them. The voice acting is amazingly good for a video game, which helps.The music is pretty well done, and there are several memorable tracks (especially at the beginning of the game... and at the end).The art style is very appealing, almost everything is made on 2D, every scenery is colorful and full of details and the animations are smooth and feel damn fine. And the characters are furries. I think it has a resemblance to Captain Claw.Now about the gameplay: it's awesome. There's a limited amount of moves to use, but they're enough, and combined with all that the character can do (dodge/sprint, parry, "gliding" and more) it just make you feel amazingly empowered.There are a lot of challenges you can do and RPG elements, and they truly make the game more fun. Treasure hunting, item crafting, side quests, and even some kind of... parkour-dungeons or whatever, if you feel like testing your skills.

												I really cant recommend this game strongly enough. An indie beat m up with a metroid-vania world you should pick up post haste. Any sceenshots you see of this game won't do it justice. While Dust has vibrant and colorful visuals, all hand drawn, you need to see this game in motion to get the full sense of its superb animations and fluid action. Following  the story of an amnesiac swordsman, a magic sword and its guardian sprite you travel through the world of Elysian to discover Dust's past. While the story may not sound like a block buster the game is filled with top notch voice acting that surpasses most triple-A titles and hides some very dark themes that belie its bright art direction. This is a game made by a small team of one, thats full of heart (no pun intended: Humble Hearts studio), has great game-play and art, with an interesting story to tell, and it tells it very well. Don't pass this up!

Posted: December 27, 2014
												One of the most impressive and best games I've played. I came into this game will minimal knowlegde of what it was and this game was quite the surprise. The gameplay was very fun with the whole hack and slash system in a 2-D plane and being able to use different moves and combos to fight. At first you could think that the combat was basically just button mashing but the enemies get stronger and learn to block and you have to adapt to their new fighting styles. Definitely a part that I can't leave out is the story, the story is so well written that even the character that most people find annoying in the beginning becomes funny and a character that you came sympathize with.  Also the villians are not only badass but sad in some cases as well which explains why they do what they are doing. The main character in general becomes very in depth with how he feels and who he is. This game is definitely worth the price it's worth.

Posted: December 3, 2013
												Dust is a game of preference. The biggest thing that people will notice is the whole “Furry” debate. Now if you could care less if you are in a world of animals, have watched any cartoon or game as a child that used animals, or just have common sense, Dust is for you. Gameplay wise, it’s a hack and slash/RPG/puzzler/adventure. If you enjoy hitting things with a sword, this is a good game for you. If you like combining powers for devastating results, this game is for you. If you like puzzles, but don’t want to rip your own hair out due to difficulty, this game is for you. If you like exploring, plundering, and/or simply hanging out in a hub, this game is for you. This game’s story is also a matter of preference. I don’t want to ruin anything for you, so if your iffy on story lines, know that the side quests will fill whatever void within you. What more, the many Easter eggs that you can find will really make any gamer smile.All in all, Dust isn’t a long game, but what it does have is hours of entertainment. If you are at all interested in this game, I would recommend buying it. And if you’re still on the fence, just wait for a sale, because this game is worth it.

												I can't really say enough good things about this game, especially considering it was only on Xbox Live Arcade for a while. Maybe being a furry, I'm biased, but humans humans humans, maybe an orc or elf, and more humans in all games out there kinda gets old anyway. Having animal people isn't a bad thing, I find myself not even noticing it at times, everything just goes so well together.Pick this game up nao, even if you end up hating it, there are a lot worse games out there for the same price or more.

Posted: September 20, 2015
												Coming from an old school 2s Caslevania and Metroid player I have to say I realy enjoyed this game. I could go on about all the pros of the the game, but that has already been done in droves, and they are all correct the game is great. There were a few things I think could have made Dust better. First off if you are a sesoned player, just start on Hard. I found the default difficulty of this game a bit easy, in fact like a derp I hadn't even equiped up other than drops that I found or were provided through story about 2/3 of the way through the game. The fact of the matter was I just didn't get hit that often partially from the difificulty and partially because of the very refined controls. The game is also a bit short, I played through getting about 90% completion in about 15 hours on normal, this is forgivable as it is an indie game and it has a low price point, but I was wanting more at the end, and franky why not, its a good game.The only other comments I would have to leave is story and characters, no spoilers here I promise. It has an anime-ish style to it, obviously seen in the screen shots, it looks great, but the choice to use a animal-human hybrid for the games characters makes it feel a little kidish, thats a style thing and I get that, it certainly doesn't detract from the game, but I don't think it really adds anything to it either.  The story is interesting and has some good deep mature themes in the since of a tomented hero coming to grips with his past for 1 example, but then you get some dialog that pops in rarely that feels it should be part of a Saterday morning cartoon. Kind of like how Avitar the Last Airbender was, again this isn't something that was bad, but for me it briefly disconnects from a great story.All in all the is a realy good game, well worth the price and I hope to see bigger and better games come from this team.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												Fun/Interesting story, Great Sound track, Hand drawn art, Fun Gameplay, Voice acting, Funny sidekick. What else could you want.     STORY-  *without spoilers* The story follows the main character Dust on his to quest to find his identity. Kept me on my seat trying to unravel the mystery.    SOUNDTRACK- All 37 tracks are well done and great at capturing the feel of the game. I havent liked a soundtrack this much since to the moon. Most  of the time id rather have a good soundtrack then good graphics.    GRAPHICS- This game is truely gorgeous. Its hand-painted and it moves very well. Its very easy to forget its hand drawn.    GAMEPLAY- Just so you know i used a controller. I feel the game was made to work with one since it was origanaly a xbox live game. The fights make you feel like a Bad A**.  So many Slashes, and explosions its sometims hard to see what happened untill the Dust settles (See What I Did There) or as Fidget says "DID YOU SEE THE SCREEN"     VOICE ACTING- Some people say the voice acting is not to good. I really liked the voices expetaly Fidgets voice and Dusts voice is good at capturing his lost feeling. Its awesome that it even has voices, i somtimes get tired of reading text after awhile.  So dont think the voice acting is bad till you hear it.    Must play, That is unless you dont care for Storylines and only like 3D games like Call of Duty.

Posted: June 3, 2013
												I really cant recommend this game strongly enough. An indie beat m up with a metroid-vania world you should pick up post haste. Any sceenshots you see of this game won't do it justice. While Dust has vibrant and colorful visuals, all hand drawn, you need to see this game in motion to get the full sense of its superb animations and fluid action. Following  the story of an amnesiac swordsman, a magic sword and its guardian sprite you travel through the world of Elysian to discover Dust's past. While the story may not sound like a block buster the game is filled with top notch voice acting that surpasses most triple-A titles and hides some very dark themes that belie its bright art direction. This is a game made by a small team of one, thats full of heart (no pun intended: Humble Hearts studio), has great game-play and art, with an interesting story to tell, and it tells it very well. Don't pass this up!

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												If you'd rather not read the entire review, and would like a simple awnser at the beggning, here it is: Buy this game. It can't get simpler than that. This game is well deserving of its price, and I would've payed five dollars more for it. Let me walk you through reasons why you should buy this:1. StorylineYou play as Dust, a quite and charming protagnist weilding a speaking blade of Elysium. Oh, and not to mention Fidget, whom is the most cuddly and possibly the best compainion to ever exsist. The game is littered with cute dialoge, and any moment the player has a thought the character comments on whatever just happened almost the same way the player thought, like if a character seemed dickish or just plain insane, Dust and Fidget immediatley have a small talk afterwards about just that, giving insane immersion. The characters are loveable, and there are almost no characters I wouldn't want to speak to. It has a perfect little twist of comedy in all the seriousness, with Fidget being adorable as ♥♥♥♥ and small little refrences to other games that'll just make you sit in your chair smiling at the computer going "Ahhhhh, I see what chu did there", and it is overall just an amazing experience.2. Gameplay.The gameplay is insanley fluent and is amazing to say the least. From the get go, there's not too much challenge, so the game isn't very frustrating allowing for a very casual expereince. With many combos using really only left-click, right-click, and W. You will hardly have a moment where you don't just go "How the ♥♥♥♥ did I do that!?!?" like throwing an enemy into another before throwing them into the air again or shooting off into the sky for no reason killing several enemies in the process. It's just fluent, balanced, and overall an enjoyable expereinece. As far as quests go, you unlock new abilities at a nice pace, and you'll always find yourself learning new tricks. The side quests, though few in number, are very well thought out and innovative for each and every one. Try saving Corbin or finding Reed's Box. These are both sidequests that are done astonishingly well. You have a sense of a new experience, plus you get to just straight up see characters happy. It actually immerses you as a character.3.  ♥♥♥♥ THREE. BUY THIS GAME.

												I really don't know how to explain it correctly... The game in general it's very well done: The gameplay is easy and allows the player to perform nice combos and Extreme difficult could be a challenge to most of people. The landscapes are beautiful and detailed, the particles flying around while the character performs the Dust Storm makes it quite inmersive and the enemies are very well placed depending on the area. The originality of making furry characters makes the game had its adorableness touch.The storyline is very well developed and easy to understand but pretty hard to predict which will be the result of Dust's decisions. There is no dubt;'' Dust: An elysian tail '' it's a game that must be played at least once in life. Just too many emotions able to bring tears to my eyes. This is for far one of the best games i've ever played. Thank you Sr. Dean Dodrill, and thanks to all the people who make this story earn a place in my heart.

Posted: January 18, 2015
Simply awesome. Dust has pretty much everything I want from a fun and entertaining RPG, and more. The story might seem straightforward at the very beginning, but as you progress in the game you understand that it's not as easy to predict as you thought. The action component, which includes combos with the (sentient) sword and magic, is really well balanced and extremely fun. It fits perfectly with the RPG-like evolution of the character, with experience points to spend in improving skills and even a crafting system not to be underestimated (you can put together quite the equip if you take it seriously). Add to all of this the beautiful sceneries, artworks, and the epic, EPIC conclusion and you'll get a game experience you won't forget.

Posted: December 13, 2013
												This game has very few flaws, but it has something I've not seen in complex games in years, pure fun. The combat system is unbelievably exhilarating and fulfilling. You play a character named Dust who has amnesia and has forgotten his past (one of the few flaws, considering how cliche that is.), with your little flying pal who's mostly used for comedic relief. Posted: December 18, 2013
												By far one of the best indie games I've played.  If you enjoy games such as Shadow Complex, Castlevania: SOTN, and Super Metroid, then there should be no reason why you can't get into this game.There are multiple difficulty levels and the blueprint, item, equipment, and consumable system is rather nicely implemented.  The difficulty can be challenging at times but in a nice way.  It doesn't drive you to frustration like veteran mode in Call of Duty, where you're getting shot at from thin air.I love the art style and music in this game also, and it is worth noting that it runs and looks very good.  The aspect of running up combos and managing your chains in-between avoiding enemies and not exhausting yourself is very nice.Definitely recommend this game to basically anyone, especially if it is on sale, however, the regular price is very fair.

Posted: March 6, 2014
												I'm rarely Impressed by something. And when I say "rarely", I really MEAN it. And between the hundreds of games I played, those I really liked, can be counted on a single person's fingers.Yes, Dust is officially in my top ten of favourite games I ever played.So, gameplay: it's an hack and slash. Actual attacks can be done by pressing only 4 different buttons, and if you're crouched, in the air, and if you did one move or another before pressing a button, you can achieve various different moves. So, the game is a lot easier to handle than your average hack and slash (to the point it can be easily played with a keyboard). The protatonist is extremely fast in attacking, resulting in... well, a lot of slashing happening on screen. Enemies will for this reason appear in mass, resulting into extremely satisfying "slashsplosions". Ordinary enemies will rarely be a threat, only bossess will sometime be a bit of a nuisance. Yes, the game is quite easy, so I suggest you outright start at the max difficulty setting if you are used to hack'n'slash games.There are some platforming sections that range from easy to very hard: I played at max difficulty, and many traps had the attitude of killing my character instantly, even on full health. I had to retry some sections a few times to get them right. Yup, platforming sections (if you play on max difficulty) are a bit better balanced than fight sections. Still, most of them are quite easy anyway.As for the graphics: Well, the full scenery and mobile background, including almost all of the characters, both ally and enemy, are hand drawn. I'm not saying it's beautifoul to look at, but at times you will REALLY be noticing the passion that was put in creating the environments. This is not your ordinary sidescroller: It's really well done graphics wise. Only thing is that characters, especially npcs and the protagonist itself... ok, maybe it's me, but at times It looked to me that said characters were just animated sketches, rather than fully drawn frames. Luckily, I only noticed this when closely watching the animations, and it wasn't that much of an issue after all, the whole animations still look great.Yeah so far it's a good game, but not a great one. So, the real reason I found this game amazing? Stupidly enought, it's because characters are extremely well characterized. That's an aspect I usually don't care that much about, maybe it's really that great after all.The protagonist, the npcs, even enemies always have a weighty character on them. You know, it ain't about the plot, it's about how you tell it. And all characters in the game are excellent narrators of the story, both because of their graphical expressivity and because of their well made voice acting. Despite the story itself being kinda clichey (it's your typical "knight with no memories" story), I ended up attached to it, and I ended up attached to the characters themselves, to the point I felt sad when I completed the game.So, the full motor of the story is the storytelling and voice acting, and it's wheels is the hand drawn style.For the rest gameplay is fun, but way too easy, and platform sections are kinda good made, too.Because of this, follow my advice: START IMMEDIATELY AT HARDCORE DIFFICULTY. Otherwise, you may end up finishing the game in 6 hours, and you will not enjoy it as much as you would.And yes, I am advicing this game. Even if you're not much into hack'n'slash games, it's worth a try. If you like hack'n'slash, then I definetly advice you to buy it. If I were to rate this game, I would give it a 8/10.

Posted: March 14, 2015
												A beautifull, fun, awesome, emotional game. A gem of a game. A must play.Dust is a 2D side scrolling hack n slash game. You take the role of Dust, a warrior who has lost his memories in a world ravaged by war, and his only hope is to follow the advice of a talking sword and his companion FIdget and set out into the world to figure out what is going on and who he is.First of all, the story is great.The twist is not really what you expected which is a great, and overall the story is very good and keeps you hooked.The writing and voice acting is AWESOME.This game has the best voice acting ever put in a game. Period. Every line is delivered perfectly and...I just don't know how to describe how perfect it is.The graphics are pretty good, everything is colorful and beautiful, and the environments are diverse, from snowy mountains to lava caves, and it all looks great.The gameplay...great. The action is great and responsive,you don't have that many combos, but it's still very fun and has room for variety.And it's alwaysnice to see your combo meter rise, especially once it goes over 1000 :D With a wide variety of enemies to beat up, you will never get bored. Your character can also equip various mods and improve his stats, so there is room for customization of how your character will play as well.Overall, this is a beautiful experience, one I will never forget.The story,characters,music, everything fits together perfectly.10/10

Posted: December 3, 2013
												Dust is a game of preference. The biggest thing that people will notice is the whole “Furry” debate. Now if you could care less if you are in a world of animals, have watched any cartoon or game as a child that used animals, or just have common sense, Dust is for you. Gameplay wise, it’s a hack and slash/RPG/puzzler/adventure. If you enjoy hitting things with a sword, this is a good game for you. If you like combining powers for devastating results, this game is for you. If you like puzzles, but don’t want to rip your own hair out due to difficulty, this game is for you. If you like exploring, plundering, and/or simply hanging out in a hub, this game is for you. This game’s story is also a matter of preference. I don’t want to ruin anything for you, so if your iffy on story lines, know that the side quests will fill whatever void within you. What more, the many Easter eggs that you can find will really make any gamer smile.All in all, Dust isn’t a long game, but what it does have is hours of entertainment. If you are at all interested in this game, I would recommend buying it. And if you’re still on the fence, just wait for a sale, because this game is worth it.

Posted: December 4, 2013
												This is more of a preview, rather then a review as I've just started playing it and am only 2 hours in. So after a couple of hours of experiencing Dust: An Elysian Tail last night, I have to say I was quite impressed. Visually it's amazing (Don't need to go into that further, as it's plan to say this was made visually incredible). Game play is spot on and fluid (and I'm surprised yet again with a 2D game. I was impressed with Trine [and it's sequel] as well for that reason), but that's not what I liked best about this. It's the audio...OMG! The music is gripping and beautiful! I loved it, and even the voice acting is really quite good. I was worried that I would find Fidget annoying with so much dialog for her, but I didn't find her that at all. I'm quite impressed and look forward to spending more time with it.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												First of all, let me say that I enjoyed Dust immensly. It is a great mix of hack n slash / RPG with platforming elements. It is a 2d sidescroller similar to games like Castlevania so, if you enjoyed those series, this is right up your alley. It features quests and sidequests that you need to complete, and you can revisit previous areas through an extremely simple and functional map system. Revisiting is mandatory if you wish to get the full experience out of the game, since it is drowning in collectibles and easter eggs, which i found really creative.The RPG element consists of finding/crafting/buying armour, weapons and various trinkets that have a lot of different abilities allocated to them, so that you can have your own gameplay style, although you most probably will go with higher armor/attack, so there is not so much variety as you might originaly think. You also get experience by killing creatures and completing quests, and when you hit the mark, you gain a level and allocate one point(gem) in one of four different stats.There is a lot of exploration and cool fights in Dust, that will probably keep you invested if you like this type of game. The story is also quite interesting, since it is not what you will probably think at first. I wont go into details to avoid spoiling it.All in all, a great action/rpg that kept me going for 15 hours, until i found everything. Highly recommended to action/rpg fans, similar to Castlevania.

Posted: December 27, 2013
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a rare gem of a game. It might seem very childish or bland at a first glance, but beneath the surface is a true labor of love. The aesthetics are fantastic and the world is colorful and vibrant, which is a wonder considering it was made by a single man. The voice acting, while somewhat spotty at worst, was delivered by believeable and capable people, even if they may be amateurs, they never felt grating or cheesy.The sound design, namely music, is top notch and fits the pace and the feel of the game very well. The rest of the sounds feel at home, and I can't recall anything that ever really popped out.The enemy design is varied and interesting, although understandably each area only has a few enemy types each. The characters are interesting to talk to, whenever they have something to say, and listening to the vast amount of dialog the game offers is pleasant and interesting to listen to. The game tells you just enough about the world to keep you immersed, while leaving the less important bits aside.What I might complain about would be the bartering system. There is no easy way to sell a large quantity of items, which forces you to hammer either the mouse button, A or D or the arrow keys repeatedly for literally hundreds of times, whether you're buying or selling.The weapon augments and armors don't have interesting effects to speak of, and are very linear upgrades. Thankfully pendants and rings offer some more interesting choices.And while the platforming is generally enjoyable, I at times felt that the character was somewhat floaty, or did not control as tightly as I'd hope, but it was a fairly small annoyance compared to the twenty hours of enjoyment I managed to rake in from this wonderful, beautiful game.If you were to blitz through the game, you might expect around ten hours of gameplay, if even that. However, if you wish to go beyond 100% like me, you may easily get 15-20 hours or joy out of the game. Of course, if you hadn't seen any pictures or videos of the game, the game features anthromorphic animal characters aplenty, and if you are not a fan of them, you might want to ponder whether you can stomach it or not. The game nor the characters ever bring this up, however, so it's not exactly shoved in your face and down your throat. For people who love said style of characters, you are in for even more of a treat.<3 Fidget

Posted: October 30, 2013
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is a piece of art. I'm not a big fan of side-scrollers, not because I don't like the concept of sidescrolling games itself, but because they usually don't offer what this game has. Story, good characters, good RPG elements (not just leveling up - side quests too, with their own stories!).The story is fine, it's not really solid as a rock, but it is still pretty interesting and makes you want to keep playing. But the big deal here are the characters. Every character in the game has a perfectly defined personality, and in certain situations you may even emotionally engage with them. The voice acting is amazingly good for a video game, which helps.The music is pretty well done, and there are several memorable tracks (especially at the beginning of the game... and at the end).The art style is very appealing, almost everything is made on 2D, every scenery is colorful and full of details and the animations are smooth and feel damn fine. And the characters are furries. I think it has a resemblance to Captain Claw.Now about the gameplay: it's awesome. There's a limited amount of moves to use, but they're enough, and combined with all that the character can do (dodge/sprint, parry, "gliding" and more) it just make you feel amazingly empowered.There are a lot of challenges you can do and RPG elements, and they truly make the game more fun. Treasure hunting, item crafting, side quests, and even some kind of... parkour-dungeons or whatever, if you feel like testing your skills.

Posted: October 18, 2014
												I can't say enough good about this game. When I first saw the trailer, I had high hopes. I knew it was going to be good. And when I did finally buy it, my expectations were more than exceeded - and that's an understatement. It is incredibly fun to play, and offers a decent amount of challenge even on the easiest difficulty setting; at least, it did for me. I'll do my best to keep this review spoiler-free.I'll start with the obvious protagonist, Dust. A living mystery, he's a little bit of a rogue; even though he's on the side of good and has a strong sense of valor and justice, he's not afraid to cut down any who oppose him or threaten the innocent. He's a bit generic at first glance, but some people (me) find a really cool character under that equally cool hat.The hack-and-slash combat can be either really fun or really boring, depending on the person. A rather small variety of techniques are available to use from the beginning. You can uppercut your target to the skies to perform aerial strikes, parry and counterattack from the ground, or just button-mash to cleave your way through the crowd. You can also launch projectiles that are weak at first, but then amplify their power to wreak mass destruction upon the battleground. Projectiles can range from magic missiles to fireballs, which can be powered up to missile storms or flame pillars.The music is probably the best part about this game. I can't get enough of it. Sometimes it's calm, and sometimes it's tense. But it's always encouraging, thrilling, and outright epic. There's nothing like dashing through a rainstorm and slashing down monsters with that loud, exhilarating violin and piano in the background.The story is linear and straightfoward, but is really quite touching at some points. Dust travels through the land of Falana after waking up without memory. A magic sword arrives as his generic sage-guide, and leads him to specific areas because reasons. Throughout the story, Dust helps out whoever he can and takes down villains, all the while trying to find clues as to who he really is. Though not much is explained, a big reveal near the end clears up a lot of potential confusion and can be traced back to the beginning of the game. While the story is linear, it's still pretty well thought out.The characters are a little flat. While most people in the game have distinct personalities, they usually just have one character trait and can be described in about two sentences. However, that does not mean that they can't be charming. You'll meet a lot of people throughout the game, and while each one has his or her own unique role, whether you love or hate them is entirely up to you.One of the biggest elements of this game is the treasure hunting. There is a limited number of keys hidden throughout the world, and each one is expended after opening a treasure chest. Some treasure is very easy to find, especially in the early levels, but some is really cleverly hidden. Sometimes you might actually have to read a note that you picked up to be able to find a secret! The horror!There are, of course, a few cons to this game. However, they are rather minor.There's not much replayability. More or less, it feels like the same game over and over again. Although it's great to experience the story again, and the higher difficulties add much more challenge, it's not a game that will last forever.Combat is precise but strange. Sometimes, if you fall from a large height, one or two enemies will be waiting for you on a lower platform and will attack as soon as you land. It takes either great reflexes or a bit of luck to avoid damage from these "ambushes."The boss fights are basic and potentially unmemorable. They have little to no strategy and can be beaten by simply spamming The Undoing, which strikes your target helpless and throws them to the ground for massive damage.I still love them, though.It is definitely not the longest game in the world, and once you've done everything story-related, completed all of the sidequests, and collected all of the treasure, there's not much else. In fact, it's the exploration and treasure hunting that stretches the game out. The story itself is rather short and linear, and the game has quite a closed end.I love this game and usually like to defend it. However, it does have its minor problems. All in all, though, the game is a masterpiece, especially when you consider that most of it was done by one guy alone. I'd like present to Dust: An Elysian Tail a score of 9/10.

Posted: June 27, 2013
												Oh man, what a surprise this game is. Mixing the best elements of a Metroidvania game and a Beat'em all with huge combos, this little indie game is a demonstration of what makes a game good and fun. Quests, sidequests, loot, freedom and cool animation and colors are the strong points of Dust : An Elysian Tail, and the execution is flawless.One only complain I might have would be the art style and character design which I hate and is kinda less impressive than anything else. If you hate furry, you're not going to have a great time looking at the characters in the conversation cutscenes. But the game is really good and once you pass that weird look, you're going to have a blast making 500 hits combos and searching for the secrets and friendly cameos hidden in all levels.Definitely a game to try if you like 2D action platforming adventure with Metroid like elements and a good ten hour of gameplay, you're going to love this fantastic one man made game. I have spend about 18 hours and I'm almost in the end, having done everything I could so far, still having a few secrets left in some levels, and a couple of sidequests. Definitely worth a try at any price.

												This is probably one of the best games I have ever impulsed buyed from a Steam Market.Characters are engaging and have wonderful designs. The voice Actors truly feel like they loved working on this game. Level design can be a little difficult to work with, but you will never feel like the game is being unfair. With plenty of side paths to explore, you will eventually find that this game doesn't expect you to 100% this game. In fact, it goes past 122% with all of the secrets you are capable of finding. From hidden "characters", keys, map exploration and Time Trial areas to complete, you will always have something to do.On top of this, the combat is very fluid. It is clearly designed to be super flashy and strange, but I truly love this aspect. The combat itself is incredibly easy to learn and moderately difficult to master. As a result, you will never feel like you got hurt due to gameplay issues, but you will quickly lose track of your position if you just spam the keys.So I highly recommend this game, especially if it is on sale. I truly believe the game is worth the full amount, however this is a one-time playthrough type of game. You will enjoy the experience to no end, but it lacks in replayability. For anyone that wishes to see gameplay before buying, I recommend viewing my videos below:Playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLJZtGKFNc15a2pjs2CdvKzJ2vRgP4UnNtSteam Videos: http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198041976310/videos/

Posted: September 20, 2015
// Introduction //Dust: An Elysian Tail is one of my very favorite games of all time.  I thought it was only fair to begin with that, and now I'll explain why I feel that way!  First, this game is a story-driven 2-D action platformer.  This means there is a fair amount of jumping and timing involved, and a lot of fighting.  A great deal of care and art went into the crafting of this extraordinary title, and I will now proceed to list what sets it apart from the norm.// Art - Music - Visual Concept //As the title says, this section will discuss the creative concepts of the game, the art.  The art is breathtaking!  The characters sprites are well-animated, the portraits they use to talk are well-rendered and offer a variety of expressions ranging through their various emotional states.  The backgrounds in the stages are beautiful and often surreal with their fluffy and warm imagery, while others are morbid and quite spooky.  The enemies are surprisingly well done, and evoke an emotional response of mild disgust (e.g. They look barbed and rocky and slimy and the like).  The music is a sublime score that never fails to meet the occasion by offering immersion and creating the mood for a particular fight, or a jaunt through a spooky haunted house, or warm soothing tones for having reached a safe place and met new people!  The visual concept disturbs some people and takes a little while to get used to, if one hasn't seen many anthropomorphized animals before.  Every character in the game, as far as I am aware, is an animal in human form.  Dust himself is some type of white fox, I believe.  His companion, Fidget, is a flying red fox.  This adds a certain fantasy flare and otherworldliness to the entire game's setting.  Others may criticize the motif, but I find it refreshingly child-like and innocent.// Voice Acting and Story //Every line of dialogue in this game is fully voice acted, and it is all superb!  Some may express a deep resentment and critique for the voice of Fidget, which is quite childlike with a heavy lean towards sillyness, but I find it entirely appropriate and amusing for the character!  Dust is a compassionate hero with a dark past, and his voice matches accordingly.   Ahrah, your talking sword, is a deep and wise sagely type, who tells you all of what he knows while being ever prescient about future events.  The villagers are appropriately frightened, grateful, and emotional when the situation calls for it.  Scenes are quite emotionally touching.  Add to this the well-designed portraits, which have basic animations, nothing fancy, and you get the qualitative effect of a good book or radio program.   Very moving, if you let your imagination run even a little free.As to the story at large, I don't want to give anything detailed away.  At the very beginning, Dust awakens with amnesia.  This sets the tone for the rest of game.  Who is he? What was he like? Where can he find the answers he seeks? Who are his friends, and who are his enemies? Will he ever know the truth about his past? This allows the player a greater deal of immersion into feeling as though they are the hero, Dust.  Dust has no strong past at first to define him, so the character can place their own persona in his.  As his story develops, one finds that his past is quite complicated.  It leads to emotional revelations and has a deep and meaningful affect on the player, in my opinion.  A good game knows not only how to provide a story, but how to immerse the player within that story.  That you feel you are there, that is important.// Graphics //2-D isn't exactly new, I know.  But Dust: An Elysian Tail does it with style!  The sprites are animated, the edges are smooth, the effects of spells are spectacularly specular, with good lighting effects!  The weather and lightning add immersion, there appears to be a very low PC requirement overall, and this game runs smooth as sherbert on my very antiquated computer.// Gameplay //This one is the most important to many.  How does it play?  Like you wield an arcane blade of martial knowledge that imbues you with the power of a hundred champions before you!  The combos are rather simple and easy to pick up.  There are two main attacks for Dust, and one for Fidget.  The primary attack has a simple combo, and the secondary attack can be added to mix it up.  X, X, X, X is simple and effective, with a knock-back at the end that clears the enemies in front of you, giving you breathing room.  X, X, Y, Y is a straight-forward smash and grab, you beat them a bit, then run forward, and suplex an enemy, effectively attacking and knocking back any that are behind you.  X, Y launches the attacked enemy into that air, where follow up combos are endless.  Holding Y causes your blade to spin, which is an infinite combo in itself, save that it will cause you to heat up and eventually hurt yourself if you use it for very long periods.  One can also jump and use the blade spin, causing them to essentially fly in an arc, or towards the nearest enemy.  This allows them to stay in the air indefinitely, and literally shoot upwards into the sky if there are enemies nearby.  Aerial combat in this game is probably the best I've seen in any action platformer.  It's easy to mess up and fall, but with the right training, it's much easier to stay in the air and endlessly attack all of your enemies.  Ground targets jumped into your path? Press X, Y and you'll attack, then grab, and body slam them into the ground, knocking back, and shooting upwards, other enemies.  Allowing you to essentially always be in the air attacking, avoiding the ground completely if you wish.This brings us to Fidget.  Fidget's attacks are magical, she learns several spells as the game unfolds.  When she casts a spell, it is a joke, a lackluster affair, and it has no range at all.  However, if you use your blade spin while she casts an attack, it multiples the number of projectiles, and their strength, and becomes an AoE slugfest of doom for all of your enemies.  I play this game on Hardcore, and Fidget is the path to victory.  Her attacks deplete your 'Energy' meter, but this refills quite easily in a matter of mere seconds by slashing a few enemies inbetween spells. What this effectively works out to is this, you can fly through the air spitting pillars of fire, and endlessly launching enemies and decimating them to refill your meter.  The game's enemies are smart enough that they will attempt to jump behind your current facing direction, and will attempt to time attacks for when you land and when you are most vulnerable, at the cooldown on your combos.Add to this that there is a right and left dash that completely evade attacks, while using a modest amount of energy, and a parry system that allows you to daze and counterattack almost any opponent (this is actually almost essential for the stronger opponents) and you arrive at a game that puts many others to shame with the sheer fun of its combat!  The game also incorporates an inventory and equipment system.  You find items that aid in your base attributes, and offer some limited special abilities, like light radius around Dust for those dank, dark caverns!// Mood - Immersion //One of the most important elements in any game, to me; this game succeeds in all categories.   From the art, to the music, to the voice acting, to the combat, to the scenery.   You will travel from high-reaching statues of a bygone age of greatness standing like monoliths over grassy knolls and mountainsides, to dark and forboding swamps that seem quite full of danger, to haunted houses in sorrowful, barren, spooky and dark environs.   From snow to rain and back again.  Also, my personal favorite, caverns!  You will spend a considerable amount of the game in the underworld!  These caverns, in my humble opinion, are simply beautiful! In conclusion. Buy this!

Posted: December 23, 2013
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is without a doubt a fantastic game. Gameplay wise its commonly seen as a Brawler Action-RPG where you stick with one weapon but continue to learn new combos and upgrade its power (along with other stats). The animations as well as the world design are top notch and surprisingly all done by one man. The story is pretty good, the music is very well composed, and there is plenty to do in the game.As a PC port its perfect, plenty of options that aren't present in most PC ports. I without a doubt recommend this game to anyone that has interest in the games. At full price this game is more then worth it but if you can get it at a 50-75% off sale then please do yourself a favor and pick this one up, you likely won't regret it if you're interested in its gameplay style.

Posted: December 18, 2013
												By far one of the best indie games I've played.  If you enjoy games such as Shadow Complex, Castlevania: SOTN, and Super Metroid, then there should be no reason why you can't get into this game.There are multiple difficulty levels and the blueprint, item, equipment, and consumable system is rather nicely implemented.  The difficulty can be challenging at times but in a nice way.  It doesn't drive you to frustration like veteran mode in Call of Duty, where you're getting shot at from thin air.I love the art style and music in this game also, and it is worth noting that it runs and looks very good.  The aspect of running up combos and managing your chains in-between avoiding enemies and not exhausting yourself is very nice.Definitely recommend this game to basically anyone, especially if it is on sale, however, the regular price is very fair.

Posted: November 26, 2013
												First of all, let me say that I enjoyed Dust immensly. It is a great mix of hack n slash / RPG with platforming elements. It is a 2d sidescroller similar to games like Castlevania so, if you enjoyed those series, this is right up your alley. It features quests and sidequests that you need to complete, and you can revisit previous areas through an extremely simple and functional map system. Revisiting is mandatory if you wish to get the full experience out of the game, since it is drowning in collectibles and easter eggs, which i found really creative.The RPG element consists of finding/crafting/buying armour, weapons and various trinkets that have a lot of different abilities allocated to them, so that you can have your own gameplay style, although you most probably will go with higher armor/attack, so there is not so much variety as you might originaly think. You also get experience by killing creatures and completing quests, and when you hit the mark, you gain a level and allocate one point(gem) in one of four different stats.There is a lot of exploration and cool fights in Dust, that will probably keep you invested if you like this type of game. The story is also quite interesting, since it is not what you will probably think at first. I wont go into details to avoid spoiling it.All in all, a great action/rpg that kept me going for 15 hours, until i found everything. Highly recommended to action/rpg fans, similar to Castlevania.

Posted: December 13, 2013
												This game has very few flaws, but it has something I've not seen in complex games in years, pure fun. The combat system is unbelievably exhilarating and fulfilling. You play a character named Dust who has amnesia and has forgotten his past (one of the few flaws, considering how cliche that is.), with your little flying pal who's mostly used for comedic relief. But it doesn't go overboard on comedy either, the game is a perfect blend of art, fun, rpg, brawler, and platforming. Not having too much of any except fun.

Posted: December 26, 2016
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is possibly the best platforming beat 'em up on the market. The game's tutorial is quick-paced yet informative. Combat is fun and captivating from the very start till the very end of the game. The level-up, item, and ability progression is done very well, and the soundtrack is one of the best that I've ever heard. The very, very few downsides to this game are that it's not very long (I beat it 100% in ~16 hours on tough), the boss fights are easy, and the voice acting could be a little better. This game is a solid 9/10 and a must play for any gamer.

Posted: December 26, 2016
												Dust: An Elysian Tail is possibly the best platforming beat 'em up on the market. The game's tutorial is quick-paced yet informative. Combat is fun and captivating from the very start till the very end of the game. The level-up, item, and ability progression is done very well, and the soundtrack is one of the best that I've ever heard. The very, very few downsides to this game are that it's not very long (I beat it 100% in ~16 hours on tough), the boss fights are easy, and the voice acting could be a little better. This game is a solid 9/10 and a must play for any gamer.
